reviewText:
A NASA crew on Mars evacuates during a bad storm, Mark (Matt Damon) is believed dead and is left behind. However, he is not dead and needs to be resourceful to survive until the next mission, over a year away. However it it not as bad as "Gravity" or "Cast Away" without Wilson. Mark (plot spoiler) manages to make contact with Earth and we have a subplot to break up the monotony of a one man play.

The film is designed primarily for science geeks. There is a lot of terms for them, many are broken down, some inanely as when a sling shot effect had to be explained to the head of NASA, something they do all the time.

With all the hype of an Oscar nomination, I thought the film would have been better. It was good, I enjoyed it, but I don't believe it belongs in the Science Fiction hall of fame. There are no space aliens, ghosts, or anything crazy like that. Science fiction, not science fantasy.

As far as science goes, NASA is leery of sending anyone to Mars as the radiation dose they will get on a round trip would be considered a lifetime dose for the astronauts, ending their careers and greatly increasing the risk of a latent radiation induced cancer etc.

Guide: 2 spoken F-bombs, a few mouthed F-bombs and WTF, and a writing of "f***ing" for the F-bomb. Male butt nudity. Nice LOTR reference, although I would have made Sean Bean ignorant of it.

?? 3 reviews so far, and they all say it's "Rocky"????????

It's not Rocky.

If you want to say its Robinson Crusoe, fine, but Rocky, not at all.

My bottom line is that its technically and visually excellent, follows the books storyline very closely, but totally fails to tell the story.  I would recommend reading the book first.  If you read the book after seeing the movie, the books spoiled for you, but vice-versa, no.  In fact there are  a lot of things in the movie that don't make sense if you haven't read the book.  Oh, youll still follow the general outlines OK, but a lot of things just don't work very well because they're slavishly, but incompletely and ineffectively, copied.

I haven't seen the disc; I just recently saw the movie, in a theater, in 3D, so I'm reviewing the movie, not the Blu-Ray disc version.
My opinion, the 3D adds little and is not worth the trouble.
I've read the book, so that's where I'm coming from.  I'm evaluating this as an adaptation of a book-- and I would give the book 5 stars, or maybe I did; I don't remember whether I ever reviewed it or not.
If you've read the book, there are only mild spoilers for the movie in this review, nothing really worth worrying about.

Technically, I think the movie is excellent, and for a Hollywood blockbuster movie, its much better than expected.  It doesnt butcher the original, in fact follows it too slavishly, but it totally fails, over and over again, to deliver the punch of the story, the dramatic impact.  Based on that, it would rate it much, much lower, but sort of grading it on a curve as a Hollywood project, Ill knock off only the one star.  One star as a drama, Im sorry.  Five stars as a Hollywood SF movie.  Weighted average, 4 stars.

First of all, the movie, for a Hollywood adaptation of a book, is very very good, though that's kind of a low bar.  I mean, the acting, direction, all technical aspects are excellent, maybe impeccable.  The script doesn't really do anything terrible to the original; in fact it follows it very closely except for a couple of silly Hollywood things at the end.  I disagree with some of the casting choices; Mindy Park should be Asian, for heaven's sake, and people like Sean Bean and Chiwetl Ejiofor are wasted.  If they have to have Chiwetl in the movie, I would much rather have seen him as Watney (the lead, if you haven't seen or read it).  That would have been much more interesting.  No reason Watney has to be white; I'm not sure if that's even specified in the book.  Actually Damon may be wasted too, to some extent.  I think the best casting for Watney would have been an unknown, or relative unknown.  Putting an all-purpose American leading man in the role, I suppose it sells tickets, but it makes hard to forget it's a movie.

Secondly, I get the feeling that they played it safe with this adaptation.  Never mind if Matt Damon is right for the part; he never misses.  Got a major nonwhite supporting character?  Get me Chiwetl Ejiofor, he never misses.  (Never mind Kapoor is supposed to be Hindu and Ejiofor is African; we'll just make up a silly back story where his father is Hindu but his mother is a Baptist.  We know we have to have black people in the movie; we even know we have to have a Hispanic or two.  We understand we have to have women in powerful roles.  But a South Asian actor in a major role?  Uh-uh.  We're not there yet.  In 2001, Chandra had to become Chandler; here Kapoor had to be a black guy.  How far we've come.  Not.)
I didn't think Jessica Chastain was right as Commander Lewis, either; too young, not crusty enough.  Id much rather have seen someone like Amelia Bullmore (Gill in Scott and Bailey).  Or Carrie Ann Moss, who has some age on her now.  Just saw her in Jessica Jones, and she'd have been perfect.

 Dont get me wrong, Chastains not right for the part, but she  did a great job being a decisive leader in the latter part of the movie, and swimming through the zero-gravity parts of the ship, I'll give you that, and in fairness, for most of the parts, it hardly matters who plays them; they don't get a chance to develop their characters anyway.  These great actors do as much as they can with the weak script; they're just overqualified, wastedand also, every time you turn around theres another familiar face, so its hard to keep suspending disbelief.

Speaking of playing safe, what is the problem with the F-word?  Watney says it a lot in the book, in numerous variations.  In the movie, he says it once in the beginning, and then it gets sort of bleeped out, paraphrased, somehow hinted at but not shown, through the rest of the film.
If he can say it once, and people can say (two even milder expletives that I couldn't quote for the review; had to rewrite it), why can't Watney say "(f-word) you"?  Or when he says what the f-word is wrong with you, tell them I'm alive!  and Houston says "watch your language, the whole world is reading everything you type we don't get to see what he says, which in the book is "Look, a pair of boobs---> (.)(.)"
Evidently too risque for the movie.  What are they so afraid of?

Now, about the adaptation-ness of this adaptation.  As I mentioned, they follow the book very closely, use a lot of the dialog.  The whole book just won't fit in a movie, so they had to leave out some stuff, I understand that, but then they slavishly checked as many of the boxes as they possibly could, without setting them up, and usually pulling the punch line.
Some examples:
-When Sean Bean's character tells Jeff Daniels he's a (religously-based expletive) coward, and stalks out, first of all, the foundation hasn't been properly laid.  Also, btw, if you haven't read the book, you really don't know what Sean Bean's character even does for a living; you don't get that he's the one in charge of the crew, and thinks that he and they should be making the decisions that affect them, and you really don't get how much he's against not telling them when Watney is found alive.  So when we calls his boss a (religously-based expletive) liar, its not really motivated, not believable but then, where they really blow it, is in the book, the big boss guy turns to the PR  lady, Annie, and tries to apologize for the Sean Bean character, but she cuts him off, saying I was hoping hed kick your ass.  You ARE a coward.  (I hope its OK to say ass in the review). That nails it down, but its omitted from the movie.  (Why??) So the skin and bones of that scene are there, but the vital organs are all cut out of it.  I know the film is too long as it is, but a few extra lines of dialog would have made that scene work, and it would have been great.

-Same thing with the scene where the Chinese leaders decide to lend the Americans their booster.  They say no one would know we could have helped, but I don't think you really get the point of that if you haven't read the book.  You could have, with another few lines of dialog, but they're not there.  Then the head Chinese guy says it will have to be done scientist to scientist, but I don't think you can understand what thats about either.  What its about is that the Central Committee will never approve the deal, so well arrange it scientist to scientist and both governments will have to accept it.  (Sort of; its more complex than that, might not actually make sense if I poke at it too much, but something like that).

Another key point in that scene is that China helps the US to make themselves look good and score points on the US, and also their price is a Chinese astronaut on a forthcoming Mars mission.  At the very end of the movie, for about 1/6th of a second you see a Chinese astronaut, but if you even catch that, you don't know the reference.  btw, how do we even know  the Chinese-looking guy isn't from San Francisco?

-Similarly, on Watneys launch day, he eats a meal pack hes saved for the occasion, but you haven't been told that, you don't have time to read what it says on the pack, it means nothing to you if you even see it.  All these things, if they don't go past when you blink, you understand, if youve read the book, but not otherwise.

-Another scene thats totally wasted is where Mindy Park discovers that Watneys still alive.  I know, film already too long, blah blah.  But in the book its really dramatic; in the movie, its just like, Oh, there he is.  They checked the box, they put the scene in, used some of the dialog, but they just totally missed it.  Another airball where there could have been a really powerful scene.

-Throughout, the movie just fails to convey how inventive and resourceful Watney is; he just easily solves one problem after another, and theres no suspense.  Theres no sense of the desperation and fear and loneliness he feels, or what its like to live on potatoes for months.  Its almost like another day at the office.

-In the movie, the 3200 km odyssey to Schiaparelli appears to take a couple of days at most.  In the book, Watney is again out of communication, so he makes this trip in isolation and has scary adventures along the way, which he has to deal with by himself and Earth can only watch with bated breath.  So since, in the movie, hes still in communication, and the trip is uneventful and you get no sense of it being long and difficult, they have him grow a beard and ask to be called Captain Blondbeard so you can see that it took long enough that he could grow the beard, even though it doesnt feel like that.

Captain Beard??  Whats that about?  Well, in the book, theres one paragraph, or maybe two, where hes idly speculating that since Mars is international waters, and hes taking the rover for a ride without anyone giving him permission, that makes him a pirate.  (Actually, come to think of it, he already did that when he went to get Pathfinder).  This is a trivial joke that really has no business being in the movie, except I guess they wanted to tie it in with Captain Blondbeard.  But in the movie the logic doesnt work; hes not out of communication, so he DOES have permission!

-The last thing I want to complain about is two, no three,  unnecessary, trite, Hollywood things at the end.
In the book, Watney jokingly suggests he can fly by poking a hole in his glove and venting air, flying like Ironman.  In the movie, they have him actually do it, which is the only scientifically ridiculous thing in the film, that I know of.  As far as I know, there are none in the book.
They just couldn't stand it..

Commander Lewis, who has already assigned a crewman the job of catching Watney and bringing him in, at the last second insists on doing it herself.  Does that really sound like what a mission commander would do?  Or would she let the designated, specially trained EVA specialist do it? Just has to be melodramatic and schmaltzy because its Hollywood.

And finally, after the end of the movie, there is one more unnecessary scene where Watney is teaching at Starfleet Academy.  Not in the book, totally anticlimactic and unnecessary, just another piece of Hollywood schmaltz they couldn't resist.

Rented the video for $3.99. I'd already bought the eBook at $2.99 so I was curious as to how the two differed. The movie, obviously, focuses more on visual effect than explanation since that's what movies do. I thought they did a great job here. The overall visual impression was survival mode in a backdrop of red dust desolation, day after day after day. This re enforced the daily grind that was essential to the plot. Those interested in more scientific explanations of what was happening will find that in the book. The movie is more about personal relationships. Again, that's what movies are good at. A real treat for me was the music. It was all disco [Happy Days Theme Song, Turn the Beat Around, Hot Stuff, Rock the Boat, Dont Leave Me This Way, Starman, Waterloo, Love Train, I Will Survive], all recovered from the personal effects left behind by commander Lewis when the crew had to abandon the planet immediately due to a violent dust storm. Unexplained in either the book or the movie was why Mark Watney, the guy who was left behind, didn't bring his own music since music was so important to him. He hated disco, or so he said, but he kept playing it and we're left with the impression that it helped get him thru the process. I wonder what the effect would have been if the survival music had been something like Grant Rogers Catskill Mountain Songmaker or Arnold Keith Storm Take the News to Mother or Ed Trickett The Telling Takes Me Home, or perhaps an individual song or two like Turning Toward the Morning or Run, Come See Jerusalem: old time, stuff that I could sing unaccompanied, but probably not if I had only that to listen to it for 549 Sols. [Note: next space trip, bring along some classical just in case, but not opera. I wonder if NASA has signed up for Amazon Music Unlimited?] The video creates a feel-good outcome with everyone working together to save one guy's life, but leaves you with the impression that the goal all along was the working together, not the outcome for any one person. So why only 3 stars? At this point in his life, Mr Weir, author of the book, is a very stable genius more interested in making a living than collecting stars and smiley faces. So for $6.98, the price of the eBook and the movie rental, you will be entertained for a weekend. Not a bad deal for both you and Mr Weir. Working together folks. That's what being a stable genius is really all about.
Good movie.

The Martian managed to take the Sci-Fy genre to new lengths, by telling a tale in the not-so-distant future. This has the movie feel more real, as each threat becomes a threat to you, each laugh becomes a laugh for you, and each emotional moment is taking place within you as well. A problem with this film, however, is that it tended to drag on. As fun as it was to see the Protagonist's resourcefulness firsthand, it became almost a chore to watch him have to deal with each problem when it surfaced. This is partly from the fact this movie is an amazing adaptation on Andy Weir's novel, where each systematic problem has more time to be explained thoroughly. In all, this movie, I am sure, will become a classic of our time.

 I  am a fan of the first half of the film because I live alone on a tiny fixed income, and I have had to solve problems to get by, with no ones help. Personnaly, I have had to care for my aging mother who lived on the other side of the country. Could you guess that Salt Lake City is about the same distance from my home in the DC suburbs, as it was from the HAB to the Scapperelli Creater on Mars?! (3200 km, or 1988 miles. I've been a science person throughout my career.  There was SCIENCE in this movie! "I've got to science the shit out of this", Damon says at one point.  Science, teamwork, smart people solving difficult problems, all of that is celebrated, as was experience and scientific collegiality.  Esoteric concepts such as Hohmann transfer orbits were mentioned, but they didn't try to explain them.  I applaud their decisions on where to spend the viewer's attention.  I love the characters: strong but not pedantic.  Male and female, different ethnicities, all were represented as contributors and leaders.  I love the cast, every single one.  Love the movie!  I loved the humor, Damon's soliloquies as he drives across Mars, the background scenery, the spacecraft, the tough decisions, the team spirit.

The Martian makes an entertaining and funny flick out of the most fear-inducing and grim situation. Astronaut Mark Watney (Matt Damon) gets stranded on Mars in an abandoned mission, left behind by his crewmates as they assume him to be dead. Mark lives, however, and we follow his survival through limited supplies, wits, and tireless help from home. While inspiration is expected from a film like this, and it definitely has that, the comedy is played brilliantly. Marks light-hearted and self-assured attitude towards his dwindling food stash, isolation, and various complications that occur throughout the movie make for some humorous one-liners. None of it thankfully ever takes the gravity of the situation, yet it does make it all the more impactful when Mark finally breaks down. The characters were likable and sympathetic, not to mention perfectly cast. The effects wonderfully realistic, the faux Mars beautiful. And while the heart-warming aspect of this film is predictable, nothing feels better than the satisfaction of the ending.

I enjoyed the movie, and it was well-done.  In particular, I liked the ingenious thinking through which problems were solved.

But I found myself questioning the central theme of the storyline itself, which was based on circumstances arising from the loss of communication between Mars and Earth.  These days, most interested people would know that Mars has severe planet-wide dust storms that can last for days, and thus that missions to Mars, particularly human missions, should make sufficient allowances for likely eventualities.  In fact, system redundancy to take account of just such eventualities is the norm in space-related eneavours.  Thus providing only one meagre antenna to form the Earth-Mars communication system seems a bit too odd -- especially when everything else were well-designed and built.

I'm always a bit apprehensive watching a movie after loving the book.  I consider the book one of the most entertaining reads of my life.  Yet the movie did not disappoint.  I understand that to cram a book that is 11 hours long on Audible to a two hour and forty minute movie involves leaving some plot twists behind.  The screenwriters did this flawlessly.  I found myself saying "Ok, I can understand why they did not include that story line."  Also the book goes into much more detail of the calculations, engineering, and thoughts that the stranded Astronaut goes through to survive.  But that takes time the movie does not have.  I do think that reading the book helped me to love the movie!

How do I know I REALLY like this movie?  Because if I find it on one of our 14 HBO channels, and I have 10 minutes, I'll watch that 10 minutes no matter where it is in the movie.  There are very few movies I can do this with.  Similar recent movies in this vein: Moneyball and Hidden Figures.

Matt Damon does such an amazing job as Astronaut Mark Watney, in this movie that is not just about coming home; but also, about how one chooses to live their life. It is monumental in showing the challenges and major setbacks this Astronaut faces on Mars after mistakenly being left behind by his fellow crew members.

Watching him try to just grow food. Basic potatoes; in soil that is less than favorable; and after counting out his last rations, is a very real example of how it feels for starving people across our world. And the definitive cold answer to his question, does he have enough food to survive? NO.

All the while people at NASA are working furtively to figure out how to bring him home. This is an edge of your seat movie! Impossible to turn away from.

 There are heart sinking scenes. The opening scene where Watney has to perform surgery on himself is very hard to watch. When I thought there is no way this Astronaut can make it. When I saw all of the weight Matt Damon lost for this role, it just shows how hard he worked to become Mark Watney, Mars Astronaut.

And then his champion spirit, that sardonic wit when talking about his disdain for the only music available: Disco. The juxtaposition of the Disco music playing as he is out there on the edge of another planet; is brilliant.

I began to realize this movie is so much more than just a movie about an Astronaut. It is an allegory for those of us who actually live in isolation. On limited means. With very little contact with others. And I do it for my survival but I recognized parts of myself in many scenes. And how the mind has to begin to think differently. Most of all; we all have to learn how to solve a problem. And then another one. I am not so good at that.

I admire Matt Damon as an actor and a humanitarian so much. Good Will Hunting was literally like a break in the Clouds for me. Like a solitary note sent to my soul that said: you are not alone. And, it is not your fault.

This movie, The Martian is a work of art. For a time when our nation could use a lot more young people studying the fields of Botany, Chemistry and Applied Science; this movie is highly inspirational. It fosters learning and shows extraordinary teamwork and problem solving.

I hope so many people buy it and continue to support Matt Damon. He is a good kind human. A stellar bright soul. And he looks you in the eye and says, I am also with you. I just love him.

The visuals are stunning. This cast is so awesome, Jeff Daniels, Michael Pena, Kristen Wiig, Jessica Chastain. Such a timeless Classic with an enduring message.

Best of all, everyone can watch it. Which is far more than I can say for regular tv which has become flooded with garbage and violence. The Martian is exactly the opposite. Then again, I'm just a fan. Fanning out. And Gushing. It's what we do :)

The movie is good. I rented it when it came out and enjoyed it. Good characters, fun dialog, tension, humor, etc. Then I got to listen to the audiobook this last week. Oh. My. Gosh. I *hated* having to pause--stupid work, dumb old sleep, lousy babies... ;) All the great features of the film (go back to the third sentence in this review if you've already forgotten) are dialed to 11 in the audiobook. The extra details, additional disasters and solutions, and the masterful narration are truly gripping. It is worth getting a free Audible trial just to hear this 11-hour masterpiece! The Martian For Pete's sake, I'm evangelizing about the recording in the movie's reviews section. And I bought the ebook. Twice. (One for me & the classroom edition for the kids--foul language removal). Andy Weir deserves your money.

The movie is great at inspiring hope in the most dire of situations: being left behind on a unknown planet that is hostile to human habitation. There are the right moments of humor and a sense of urgency and suspense to get him home. As for the 3D aspect of it: the clarity and depth are excellent. I finally get it now. After watching post-converted 3D movies, I see the differences. Native 3D just comes across much more definitively and there aren't any gimmicky pop-outs. I watched the 3D Under the Sea IMAX film and that's all it does is give you pop-outs. That's not what I'm looking for when I'm watching 3D and if pop-outs are a favorite then that's fine. I know that this argument goes beyond the scope of the product but if you're looking for a 3D movie that makes the case for why we love 3D movies then watch this movie. Also, I have to say that I was one of those people who hated 3D and rarely watched them before watching AVATAR.

It was somewhat fun, but as empty as cotton candy. Every time a problem developed, the script threw an easy solution right in Matt Damon's lap.  "My rover won't go very far without recharging, luckily NASA left a spare battery just a short drive away. The return craft can't come to me, it's a good thing there's a brand new launch vehicle just over there that no one is using." Every astronaut and ground control technician looked a lot more Hollywood than NASA. Also, if the air is so thin on Mars that you can use a tarp as a nose cone during take-off, how was the storm in the beginning of the film strong enough to knock over a huge rocket? Certainly not a serious movie like Apollo 13 or The Right Stuff. In the end, it's a fairly dumb movie, pretending to be smarter than it is. Maybe the book was better. I'll never know.

As long as you go into this film knowing it's fiction, it's not too bad. Of course the plot has been done a hundred times before: human left behind on hostile planet for whatever reason seems good to the author, manages through his/her own ingenuity to stay alive until s/he can be rescued. If you've watched science fiction for the last 50 years--heck, if you watched the Apollo mission--you know the basic plot.

Matt Damon is good, as usual, and his riffs are funny.

 However, if you're going to ignore what we know about the atmosphere of Mars, and just make this look like a day on Earth--sunny, clear air with miles of (southwestern) red soil and rock, then you can't expect kudos. There's one freakin' wind storm at the beginning--necessary to the plot so the hero can be left behind--and then it's clear sailing all the way. Rather like Wall-ee: all the equipment is there, he just has to figure out how to use it. that part was okay, but, since the Martian soil is KNOWN to be too toxic to grow Earth crops--even in greenhouses--I just couldn't buy it. Oh, and he's there for another solar year and NOT ONE WIND STORM. I'm off to read the book; maybe it's more realistic. . .

This is a movie I got lost in. The storyline is about a guy left behind on Mars by his crew who assumes he was dead. If I were that guy, I would be dead. This guy is a biologist of some type (?) and a pretty inventive and plausible character. If you are willing to accept the reality of someone being left behind on Mars, which I found enjoyable, then watching The Martian by Michael Pena, and staring Matt Damon can be an entertaining and a thought provoking time.

The movie brings up the practical issues of survival, most of which I would never have thought about. Then of course, there is a good dose of reality tossed in. Just about the time, when I am congratulating myself, because I am overly identifying with Matt Damon, the unexpected kicks in. There are issues relating to how long it takes for a rescue to be undertaken, how to survive, how to eat, and how to recover from the inevitable numerous disasters.

There is a novel twist on how our main character communicates with earth and the numerous tense moments that would probably cause most of us to give up. Matt Damon comes through strong in The Martian. It took me over a year to remind myself that I wanted to look it up using Amazon. I am glad I did and expect it will be well appreciated when we have guests, where someone asks "Is there anything good to watch on Amazon?".

good movie

Good cast, fine acting.  Not a bad movie, but SERIOUSLY pales in comparison to the book.  I know that's usual, as of course movies have to cut many things; however, I was surprised at the situations (some very nail-biting ones!) that the movie left out.  I actually expected that the movie would OVERDO some of the situations and make it an unrealistic, non-stop action-fest that would be disappointing.  While I'm glad that wasn't the case (well, MOSTLY that wasn't the case--I was NOT AT ALL impressed with the ending, which was just total Hollywood cheese and did not match the rest of the film), it was very strange that the film left out many of the problems that had to be solved (which was the whole big point in that comment fin the final scene)--problems such as the loss of communication, the dust storm, and the "accident" near the end (trying not to give too many book spoilers here).  Because these challenges were left out, it felt like the full sense of Watney's unbelievable ingenuity was missing, and this ingenuity was the most amazing part of the book.  So, it was a weird combination of missing several opportunities for nail-biting, but BELIEVABLE action, and then throwing in some very cheesy, un-realistic thing at the end.  Bummed about that.  Please, please, please, get yourself the BOOK, which is EXCELLENT! (This from an English teacher, of course...)

We watched with movie with our grandsons (13 & 15).  We loved it.  It was so exciting that we HAD to have popcorn to get through the entire movie.  I feel it was a special treat since it seems to be so difficult to find a movie that is suitable and entertaining for all of us.

I can't fault the production and the special effects, which were well made, but all told this film was just staggeringly boring. I guess I can take only so much of an arrogant, profanity-spewing stranded astronaut growing poo potatoes while waiting for the inevitable pickup from his astronaut friends (who were all more than willing to spend an extra year in space for a futile rescue operation. The film gives you the tangible icky feeling of sitting in a pressurized airplane cabin while still in the comfort of your home! Matt Damon seems to radiate smell and desperation as he treks along with dusty Martian/Utah landscape, accomplishing one implausible thing after another. If I cared anything about nerdy science I might do some fact checking for this film, but I can't help but remain skeptical that a rocket can function properly with just a tarp wrapped over the top? There were plenty of other moments like this as well (includign duct tape to fix a broken helmet. Sure, whatever.)

Of course all of the astronauts are young and beautiful, and NASA's command is staffed with aging b-actors like the Dumb and Dumber guy, whatshername from SNL, and the Boramir guy (I will give the credit that they managed to work in a LOTR gag with him in the scene. I found myself saying "One does not simply launch a rescue rocket" whenever he would appear in a scene.)

The fault here might be editing. I was seriously bored through most of the film and waiting for things to pick up. Maybe an actual martian showing up might have spruced things up. This was directed by Ridley Scott, wasn't it?

Have you read Andy Weir's terrific best-seller yet? The back story of his success is almost as good as his first full-length novel. Look it up! A few memorable situations had to be eliminated, or this 2-hour, 20-minute survival story would run for over six hours! I did object to the last exciting action sequence: They needlessly changed the players simply because of star billing. Grrr....

NASA astronaut/flight surgeon Michael Reed Barrett happily introduced this exciting Sci-Fi adventure to our screening audience (it's his favorite movie). Director Ridley Scott ("Prometheus"), with a screenplay by Drew Goddard ("The Cabin in the Woods"), follows Weir's involving and humorous book into space. We open with a NASA exploration team on the red planet, where a freak storm violently interrupts their mission and our story begins.

The cast:
  * Matt Damon ("Beyond the Candelabra") Mark Watney is left for dead as the crew wisely scrambles to evacuate while their ship can still fly. Faced with starvation, this resourceful survivor becomes "the greatest botanist on this planet!" (See the trailer.)
  * Jessica Chastain ("Zero Dark Thirty") Melissa Lewis is captain of the crew that unwittingly abandons our hero; her responsibility is to get her team safely back to Earth.
  * Mackenzie Davis ("That Awkward Moment") Mindy Park's job is surveillance. She is the solitary observer who monitors the mission from a quiet NASA desk. She spots some unexplained activity. Once it is ascertained that Watney is alive, time and distance are the biggest challenges for NASA. How do we get back there to rescue him before he dies? And how do we tell him we're coming?
  * Jeff Daniels ("The Newsroom") Sanders is the head of NASA; short of a mutiny, anything else that happens is on his watch.
  * Kristen Wiig ("The Skeleton Twins") Annie Montrose's job is Public Relations. How do you tell the world that an astronaut has been left behind on Mars to starve?
  * Chewitel Ejiofor ("12 Years a Slave") Venkat Kapoor is the vital link between the face of NASA and the media world. Through him, we witness the bureaucratic scramble that takes place behind the scenes.
  * Donald Glover ("Magic Mike XXL") Rich Purnell seems to have Asperger's, which makes this high-functioning fellow the perfect person to offer an outside-the-box solution for this white-knuckle dilemma.
  Michael Peña ("Ant-Man") Likable mission pilot Rick Martinez is Watney's best buddy. It's just plain fun to hear their chatter.*
This is PG-13, so expect a smattering of profanity, a bit of nudity, and an entire crew of Macgyvers (one astronaut has to build a bomb from their food supply). And you'll never look at duct tape the same way again.

The most outstanding element of this film (AND the book!) is the humor: Watney has a wry sense of himself and his situation that we come to share. He also has a resilience and a persistence that any would-be adventurer would be wise to note; he even comes to appreciate disco music (some tapes had been abandoned by the crew).

You can $kip the 3D, the $tory is the thing! I heartily recommend this one (and the book).

NASA propaganda, but an interesting and well done piece of science fiction nonetheless.  The severe radiation of the Van Allen belt will kill any human venturing out of orbit into deep space.  Look up the science for yourself.  It's an impenetrable barrier.  Astronauts would need to be shielded by at least six feet of solid lead on all sides to have a chance.  There's a reason why dentists put that lead blanket on you when you get dental x-rays.  Multiply that thousands of times, that's the Van Allen belt.  Apollo was filmed at a sound stage in the Nevada desert north of Las Vegas.  NASA is about politics and money; it's a cold war relic.

A big-studio "space" movie with Matt Damon? What's not to love? Well, after several viewings there are certain aspects of this movie that prevent me, for one, from considering it a five-star space classic. I wonder if any of the other reviewers here feel the same. First of all, in my humble opinion, the script could've used a rewrite. The astronaut's banter sounds very Hollywood - a mix of cliche tech speak lifted almost verbatim from past space flicks like Apollo 13 with some flip chatter that doesn't sound at all legit coming from a NASA crew - "In your face, Neil Armstrong"? I don't think so. Then there's the implausibility of the plot - a trained crew flees Mars, abandoning Matt Damon without bothering to walk 50 feet to make certain that he's dead or retrieving his body, then when almost back to Earth, they decide to turn around and pick him up. From what I understand, no NASA crew would ever mutiny or vary so much from a mission profile, even if the extra risk and months in space were possibilities. The '70s disco soundtrack also seems overly cute and inappropriate. Still, you can't really go below four stars as the effects are convincing enough and the acting, mostly that of Matt Damon, make the fictitious world of this Mars journey a nice place to visit, but I wouldn't want to live there.

This movie comes about as close to accurate as it can (according to various interviews on the subject), while taking some liberties with some facts in order to create the narrative. Then again, people need to remember it's about entertainment; it's not a biopic!

That being said, The Martian is fun and entertaining, and yes, even inspirational. Those who feel they "aren't into science fiction" need to realize that ultimately, this movie (and its original book) are a story about (hu)man's desire to live, when it seems like it will be impossible for him to survive even a fraction of the film. Damon handles the heavy lifting of the title character (Mark Watney) with a deft comedic touch that makes one appreciate just how mentally prepared astronauts have to be in order to potentially handle this kind of crazy, horrifying stream of events and its consequences.

Of course, certain circumstances have to play out perfectly (if he wasn't a botanist, would he have figured out how to potentially survive?), while other bad things seem inevitable in order to throw more obstacles into his path. But even non-sci-fi fans will find the storyline engrossing and will be cheering along for his survival.

The Martian is one of Matt Damon's best movies. It is that rare movie where I continue to enjoy after seeing it over and over again. If you like science fiction movies at all, see it.

The basic premise of the movie is Astronaut Mark Watney, believed dead in an accident,  is left behind on Mars when his crew leaves during an emergency. He survives and then begins trying to figure out how to survive out of touch with earth or his crew in space. Meanwhile on earth ground control discovers he is still alive and tried for figure out whether to save him and how that might be done.

The story arc is expertly done with great cast, acting, writing, special effects and music, The Martian is a movie where (for me) everything comes together perfectly.

I did NOT read the book before seeing the movie and I recommend seeing the movie first. It took me years to accept that the no movie made from a book can match the nuance and detail of a good book. I used to read the book first but  eventually learned to read the book after the movie. I just accept how the book is different better than the movie better in that order.

In conclusion, this is one excellent movie. If you read the book first it may not live up to the book. See the movie, then read the book. I have enjoyed many viewings and that makes a 5 star movie experience for me.

So I just saw the movie after reading the book. The movie's good, but there's a few things that don't work:
1. The size of the base on Mars, "The HAB," and the sheer amount of stuff there makes it look like they sent a container ship to Mars. In an era where they're using conventional rockets to send this stuff, it's clearly impossible. The Rovers are way too big, the size of tanks. In the book, they're more like dune buggys. The HAB looks like a luxury suite in a Dubai six-star hotel, not a big tent with six hammocks. And a 36" computer monitor? I suppose they had a hot tub, too.
2. When he's outside, you can see his face through the helmet faceplate. Sometimes the sun is shining on it. No, no, no, that's UV burns, if not blindness. Remember how thin the Martian atmosphere is.
3. With all that dust swirling around, I just don't get the sense that he's on a planet with a very thin atmosphere. And his EVA suit doesn't look warm enough for Mars.
4. Commander Lewis seems mis-cast. Someone with more charisma needed to play that role. She comes across as an uptight corporate exec, not a military commander of a space mission.
5. The heroics at the end, departing from the book, are just too much.

Now for the good stuff. I thought Matt Damon got the part just right. The other crew members were good. So were all the earthbound characters. The outdoor shots showed the beauty of Mars--if indeed it is beautiful--much more than the book. I don't know if the dust devils are real, but they were aesthetic. Altogether, a good show.

Being a enthusiastic fan of "The Martian" written by Andy Weir, I was hesitant to watch this movie. While the movie does not completely represent every single juicy bit of scientific detail that the novel has, it does get enough in there that it is not another Hollywood cash grab.

The Martian is about Mark Whatney, an astronaut who is left on Mars, when his crew evacuates during a catastrophic dust storm. The stranded Whatney confronts the many problems that stand in his way of survival on the red planet.  The Martian is not a movie to glass over details, while the book details every nail biting moment, the movie throws a fair amount in too. Matt Damon gives you a character that you care about.

I own about 30 3D movies now, and this one is at the top of that list. A beautiful movie, if you like 3d and space, then you need this movie.

Matthew Damon as always is an excellent actor. The ending might be somewhat predictable but the journey to the end has enough twists and turns to keep you engrossed and is certainly worth the ride (pun intended). Scenery, acting, plot, science all great. Definitely recommend seeing this movie!

one of the few movies in the past few years that gets the science right (or close to it), has intelligent dialogue, chronicles the lives of the geniuses that makeup our space program, and keeps your attention throughout the movie.  All this without CGI fight scenes, murders, crime, car chases, etc.  With the success of Hidden Figures (about mathematicians working for Nasa in the early 60"s) I hope Hollywood takes note and realizes that science stories make for compelling cinema.  With the dumbing down of America, we need movies like this to show our kids the enormous good that science and technology has brought us and hopefully encourage them to take full advantage of their educational opportunities.  As a former middle school science teacher, I suggest this film be used by teachers as the basis for lesson plans for any number of skills sets that students need to attain proficiency in science and math.  The mathematics of orbits, basic agronomy and botany, chemistry, the electro-magnetic spectrum, gravity, etc. could all be examined in an entertaining way using this film as the anchor.

This isn't a science fiction movie it's a Lifetime for Women Movie set in space. In a nutshell, during a mars expedition a hot astronaut, Matt Damon is accidentally left behind on mars. While left on Mars he survives by growing potatoes in human feces.  Not Joking about this.  He then digs up an old space mars rover and uses it's radio to get help while his buddies who left him on mars try and figure out how to get him back.  It's straight up out the story line from MacGyver complete with duct tape, etc. with a disco sound track backing the whole movie up. Not joking about this.  If you are into science fiction you probably won't like it but your wife or girlfriend will.

The Martian is perhaps my favorite movie of those I have viewed in the last year. The sense of possibility is rekindled. There is very little need to suspend disbelief to enjoy this movie, though at times the string of creative scientific solutions needed to keep the character alive while he waits for rescue seem on the edge of incredible. I have watched this movie several times and it does not fail to entertain each time I watch it. As one who grew up during the heady times of the Apollo program it gives a sense of renewed possibility that has been lost since we gave up that program more than 40 years ago!

In this astronaut disaster adventure, Matt Damon is mostly charming and occasionally inspiring as a scientifically sophisticated MacGyver. The rest of the characters are too cookie-cutter to evoke much emotional response. The soundtrack and other elements transparently pander to boomers thirsty for a fresh taste of America's true-grit, man-on-the-moon halcyon days.

This is "Hard SF" only in the limited sense that it valorizes scientific problem solving, as long as those problems remain purely technical. Any broader application must be inferred. One gets the sense that drawing such inferences is no problem for the target audience. It is simply assumed that to cheer for the science of space flight et al. is to embrace a scientific approach to life in general - one of the great mythologies of the boomer era. No substantive questions are raised regarding the audience's cultural status quo, such as its blind faith in technocracy. The film concerns itself with the ramifications of change in only the narrowest sense - the logistics of rescuing someone marooned on Mars. Thus, it can hardly be classified as science fiction.

Most viewers won't be too concerned about any of that, though. If you're just looking for a good time - and especially if you're a nostalgic, left-leaning boomer looking to be both affirmed and entertained - The Martian is unlikely to disappoint.

A celebration of the innate courage of clear-eyed scientists and problem-solvers. Matt Damon is convincingly scared, angry, ironic, funny, and determined as the only human ever to occupy a planet alone, and the astronauts, scientists, technicians, and politicians who help retrieve him to Earth are quite believable as well. As our country embarks on witch hunts against climate scientists and anyone trying to base policy on their findings or those of other environmental researchers, this movie is quite topical. Like "Apollo 13," it reminds us of what our country can achieve when we pursue truth, invest in ground-breaking exploration, and educate people to be real problem solvers, rather than relying on propaganda, fake news, and pseudo-religious dogma in the public sphere.

I have watched this movie so many times already that I am repeating the script as the movie plays. The scenario of a manned mission to Mars makes some assumptions that the US has already produced the hardware to make manned Mars missions, and as the drama unfolds, that hardware becomes survival critical. One of the six astronauts is struck by debris during a violent Mars sandstorm that forces an emergency mission abort leaving the one astronaut behind, presumed dead. Matt Damon plays Mark Watney, the astronaut left behind, and I thought Damon's portrayal was definitely worthy of an Academy Award. As the story unfolds, memorial services are held on Earth as the surviving crew are on their way back to Earth from Mars while Watney begins to work through the challenges of staying alive long enough to await the next manned mission, some four years in the future. Damon portrays the determination of Watney to survive incredibly well, starting with his self treatment of his injuries from the flying debris. From then on, despite the overwhelmingly impossible odds against him, he starts working the problem and finding solutions to keep himself alive. Eventually, the NASA people on earth discover that Watney is still alive on Mars, initiating a huge effort to find ways to rescue him. Left to his own resources, Watney defies the odds time and again using his training and knowledge to the maximum.
Rarely have I seen a movie that has grasped my attention like this one. Sure, there are some implausible conclusions, but hey, this is a movie. What makes the story so compelling is the way the story moves along to its conclusion. From the credits following the movie, it is apparent this was a big budget international effort, and it was done flawlessly in my opinion. There is no better movie than this for pure entertainment.

Worth a watch, but the action and drama are so manufactured the plot is ultimately predictable. Of course, what did I expect with a big-budget sci-fi blockbuster? What separates a great space epic like Sunshine from The Martian is chemistry between the characters. In the Martian, we are supposed to believe Matt Damon is so tightly bound to his crew that they would sacrifice their own lives to save his and vice-versa. However, the rapport between the crew and main character is never established. When the characters on screen don't connect, it's hard to expect an audience to connect with the characters. I rounded up to three, but this is a 2.5 star movie.

This is a movie to produce drama and action.  It gives the audience everything they want from a movie, and that is all it is.  It is entertaining at best, but life on Mars would be much more life threatening.  Every second Mars would be trying to kill you.  The weather alone would most likely kill you if you lived above ground for any long period of time.  Out of many things that would kill you, just think about the high doses of radiation you would get just from living on the surface.  Water reclaimers do NOT last forever even if they operated forever.  Also, it must be nice living in a Hilton Hotel on Mars.  Living quarters would not be nearly as luxurious and comfortable and spacious.  Anyhow, like I said, it is entertaining at best, but not realistic.

Matt Damon's understated performance was just right for the role. The main character's solutions to the various problems and setbacks posed by the Red Planet's harsh environment were a nice counterpoint to NASA Ground Control's effort to retrieve the marooned astronaut. These elements, combined with NASA's political and public relations hassles made for a very realistic and engaging plot line. Character development was relatively strong where it needed to be. Nice action-packed plot resolution, too. This film is a fine example of speculative science fiction, a relatively under represented genre in recent years.

This is of the few times a movie lived up to the lofty standards set by the book.  My only complaint?  A bit too much 70's music.  Yeah, we heard about how the protagonist griped about the music, but why use that as an excuse to bombard the audience with so much of it as well.  At least when I was reading about it, I didn't also have to listen to it.  And yeah, it's a minor nit, but otherwise I'd have nothing to complain about.

Naturally, there were a few missing scenes that I wish we could have seen, but this is not unexpected due to the movie's time constraints.  I felt they kept the most germane scenes intact and presented them well.

Overall, highly, highly recommended for almost anyone.  And I think anyone will appreciate it, even if you don't necessarily care about all the "sciency" stuff, because the focus on the show is really about human courage, tenacity, and ingenuity in the face of overwhelming adversity.

Oh, and if you actually *love* 70's music, you're in for a treat.

The Martian, in my opinion, is nothing less than brilliant. This is a thinking person's sci-fi flick - a story built on smarts instead of fast-action violence. Matt Damon is totally in the lead in this film - an astronaut left behind on a Mars mission. Now he has to find a way to survive until the next Mars mission arrives (due to land in four years). Damon's portrayal is authentic,not over dramatized, not marginalized. His actions and behavior are what I might expect from a trained astronaut, a professional botanist, a human being trying to survive. That makes his performance moving, witty, gritty,and gracious. Other performances in this film were very good, but Damon definitely takes center stage, and should. The screenplay keeps the audience engaged, entertained, trying  right alongside astronaut Mark Watney, the crew that left him behind, and NASA's effort to find a way to rescue him while keeping out of a negative public relations tangle that could endanger further funding for the space program. The film score is unobtrusive until just the right moment. This is a great film for everyone, not just sci-fi buffs.

Id heard lots of good things about The Martian after its release and then during awards season it won in some comedy category and I was like, Whu? That doesnt seem right. Isnt it a sci-fi survival story? Thoughts of Gravity swirled in my head but there was more buzz and talk about this movie that was, like, a comedy in a way. This more than anything intrigued me though my wife was had at the starring Matt Damon moment. So we watched Matt The Martian Damon survive, unaided by his cosmonaut compatriots who had left him thinking him dead, and survive he did using SCIENCE! And his wits, and acumen, and an attitude of dauntless humor. So it was a Robinson Crusoe survival story after all that conveyed a sense of adventure and humor in that the whole being alone and going to die soon thing never got him down; it never really got anyone down and everyone worked hard with a thats the spirit! attitude that never gave up, even in the face of worry and incalculable odds. His fellow Mars explorers learned of his being alive and unanimously chose to go back for him while NASA honchos and personnel scrambled in political and mathematical circles to help figure out how to bring him home and spin the story as a good ol US of A nationalistic tall tale. Damon, ever the likable modest superman who comes across more like an everyman, sells us on himself in every scene and we never feel alone. BTW, this movie is way better than Gravity. 4.5 stars.

Matt Damon's Everyman quality and wry sense of humor makes him the perfect actor to portray Mark Watney, astronaut, in Ridley Scott's "The Martian," written by Drew Goddard, based on the book by Andy Weir. When a violent storm forces the Hermes crew, led by Commander Melissa Lewis (a steely Jessica Chastain), to abort the Ares III mission to Mars, the crew reluctantly leaves without Mark Watney, who was injured and presumed dead. Somehow, Watney survives, and starts keeping a log of his experiences on the Red Planet. He is a realist. It could take years for a rescue team to retrieve him, so he gets down to business: rationing and growing food, making water, repairing damaged equipment, and establishing communication with Mission Control.

In 3-D, the views are spectacular, with flying debris coming at us from various directions; the desolate yet strangely beautiful Martian terrain stretching out to infinity; the Hermes astronauts floating from one pod to another; and the thrilling, acrobatic finale. "The Martin," is not deep, nuanced, or subtle, but it is a certified crowd pleaser. Matt Damon shines as a genius who, in spite of daunting challenges and discouraging setbacks, dusts himself off and comes up with solutions, including multiple uses for duct tape. Watney makes jokes about outdated Disco music, boasts about his skills as a botanist, and makes comments laced with profanity while communicating with earth.

The supporting actors include Jeff Daniels as NASA Director Teddy Sanders, who must make tough decisions that factor in not just the human element, but also his agency's image, political standing, and fiscal constraints. Would Americans ever abandon one of their own? At a time when some nations have lost respect for the United States, this film boosts morale with its can-do spirit. Would it be churlish to point out that, for all its wizardry, special effects, and visual spectacle, "The Martian" has formulaic and clichd elements? Still, for a little over two hours, we sit back, take in the sights, and imagine what it would be like to be stranded on a faraway planet, trying to remain optimistic, and using our scientific know-how, guts, and resourcefulness to stay alive until (we hope) help arrives.

Much easier to follow than the other big space flick of the year Interstellar.

SPOILERS

One. The use of Bowie's Starman, and Abba's Waterloo. This wasn't that kind of a movie. It was a suspense movie. They had no place being there.

And that points to a problem throughout the film-- it was as if Ridley Scott, of all people, didn't know exactly what kind of film he had, how to play up certain elements. The crowd scenes in the world capitals at the end, the rescue imminent. Then the cheering. It was as if he wasn't sure they should even be in the film, so he figured, I'll just put them in a little, when more or nothing was called for. The international rescue angle, too: same problem -- in or out, Ridley?.

This is NOT a horror movie!  Instead it is a very realistic adventure movie that emphasizes that man can succeed and survive with knowledge, ingenuity and a never quit attitude, even if he is stranded for years as the sole human on Mars. This movie could have convinced me that it represents a true event. It is largely a one man show by Matt Damon who is excellent in the film.  I have watched it several times and have come to the conclusion that this is very feasible as presented. As an engineer, I can say that this meets my expectations as a very realistic scenario.  The scenes really do look like the event was filmed on Mars.  My hat is off to director Ridley Scott and Matt Damon who made this seem all so real!

A little geeky, but I appreciate sci-fi movies that at least try to make an attempt at actual sci. Several times, though, I got the impression that the editors or writers or even Ridley Scott let some important details slip. Some were done to move the plot along (like the improbability of a storm strong enough to blow structures over in an atmosphere that's pretty close to a vacuum), and some just seemed sloppy (like hanging a naked plutonium core next to his head to keep warm). I would have changed the tagline, "I'm going to have to science the s*** out of this," to "I'm going to have to duct-tape the s*** out of this."  Is there nothing that miracle adhesive can't do?

Everyone has already told you how incredible this movie is (pardon the grammer). I just felt I needed to add my 2 cents. I have watched the Bluray like 7 times, and at least that on cable. If it is on, I HAVE to watch it again. First the cast. Amazing casting. Matt Damon is the best. Jeff Daniels, Kristen Wiig, Chastain, et al perfect acting. The cinematography, the cg, and costuming is amazing. I FELT like I was on Mars, and space. The poignant use of 1970's music to create `atmosphere' is perfect. The angst, the emotion, the soundtrack...even Damon's scraggly DeCaprio-esque beard....are all...well...perfect. This is without a doubt, one of my fave movies, and will always be so. Evn when I know what will happen (after so many viewings, I am still on the edge of my seat every time. If I could give a ten out of five, I would.

The Martian, based on the novel of the same name written by author Andy Weir, is an eventful movie that serves both as an epic sci-fi adventure, but also provides viewers with some smart laughs. Those are who not that interested in sci-fi will probably end up liking the movie, because it is not unrealistic. Acting wise, Matt Damon puts in an excellent performance as the lead, and supporting actors such as Jessica Chastain, also put in solid performances. Probably one of the best aspects of the film, is that the mood of the movie is quite optimistic, considering that the situation of being stuck on mars, is quite a scary one, that requires a lot of panic. In Conclusion, The martian is a fun, smart movie, that is likely to be enjoyed by most audiences who watch it.

I love most any space related Sci-Fi and I liked this, but was a bit disappointed in this overall. Perhaps the hype about it exceeded the reality for me and though Damon was marooned on Mars, his solo performance was not in the same league as when Tom Hanks was stranded on the island in Cast Away. It seemed like it could have been much more than it ended up being and that's mostly why I was left wanting for something more.

Being the lone character in most of a movie is extremely difficult to pull off successfully. It just wasn't all that I was hoping for, but many others have loved it so it seems to boil down to that age old controversy of which is better, vanilla or chocolate.

Takes the general direction from the book, but the endeavor of problem solving and the costs of solving those problems is really bypassed entirely. The flight crew direction and main character are a little stale. Damon comes off more as a Will Hunting or Borne character than a quirky, failed hero who struggles to survive.

I just watched the DVD for the first time, after reading the book. (IMHO that's generally the best order for these things.) I really like them both.

BTW I have no sympathy for the complaint of the reviewer who found it "dull and dry." Some interesting items in the book were indeed left out; there's just no way to fit it all into a movie--and the plot doesn't lend itself to a miniseries treatment, as some stories do. But name me one essential plot element that got left out, not a detail.

All that notwithstanding, I did cringe at certain things. Actually, the one thing that keeps getting cited as unrealistic--the lack of capability for a 10 mbar atmosphere to do any real damage, even with a 200-kph wind--to me is no big deal. Just imagine it's a volcanic eruption, or maybe a meteor impact. Problem solved. But there were multiple times with large groups of people breaking out in cheers and the like, and that seemed quite silly. 30 seconds after liftoff is no time to be popping champagne corks; it's when you should be wiping sweat! And then there was a time or two with dialogue explaining a situation that you know the participants would have to already know thoroughly, no words needing to be spoken at that time.

There was one part I would have loved to see pushed into the movie, and that where it was decided that if things went too badly wrong, and the supply ship did not get to the crew, the plan was for everyone to take suicide pills and for Johannsen, being the youngest and smallest, to survive by cannabilizing the other crew members. That might have been the hardest thing to handle on screen (and BTW it was only a minor aside in the book), but if handled right it could've been quite memorable, perhaps with the aid of a little projectile vomiting.

I was pleased that the book and movie used metric units; maybe that's partly from lessons learned from the 1999 mission failure that was blamed on confusion between English and metric.

Thank goodness for selectable subtitles on DVDs. It's often the case in modern movies that the dialogue is not that clear; it lends authenticity to the acting, but it really helps to have text to help out. That, and multiple languages, are a big aid, and I care enough about this movie to make use of both of those features.

I'm going to assume the five star reviews are from people who didn't read the book, because a lot of the funniest parts were missing. This was poorly done as a movie and a lot of skipped important bits. I'm glad I read the book first because otherwise this movie would have left me with so many questions and much confusion. The MAV for Ares 4 was thousands of miles away and they just filmed it as a little driving montage and he had constant contact with Nasa the whole time. If you liked this movie at all read the book, the hadships this guy had let me believe he was going to die, but the movie gives you that happy ending feeling from the beginning. I also don't know why they cut off the significance of his team to him and kept everything focused on Captain Lewis. Just so strange. Matt Damon did his best with the script though and I found him a good choice for Marks character, as well as Michael Pena as Martinez, but the other crew almost seemed to be there as filler and hardly memorable in the movie.
I know the books are always better and book nerds always whine about it ;P but this is one that was done really badly in my opinion.

This was my cure for cancer. No joke. After chemo, after radiation, there comes the anxiety of how to live "cancer free." When will it come back? Will my life every be the same? Will I ever be normal? If the Martian can live with all his uncertainty about survival, I sure can too! Didn't expect this movie to be life-changing or a cancer healing message, but maybe if you're struggling with any kind of anxiety, this movie and how its main character faces his problems head on, without worrying about when the next one will come, can be inspirational to you too!

Director Ridley Scott has had middling success returning to the sci-fi genre recently with "Prometheus", a modest hit but with this brilliant film based on a best selling novel, he has struck gold plus an actor whom we have empathy with, Matt Damon.  His humor and compassion is responsible for making this Scott's best film to date.  And of course, a great supporting cast helps with the participation of Jeff Daniels, Sean Bean, Chiwetel Ejiofor, Kristen Wigg, Jessica Chastain, Kate Mara, etc.  Also the 3D is great but even without it, this film still holds our attention.  Along with "The Revenant", this was one of the best films of 2015.

I liked the movie but, I'm the type of person that seeks authenticity of a possible theory or scenario. There were a few things that didn't make sense in the movie. One of them is the gravity on Mars would of been a lot less than here on earth given the very thin atmosphere so the normal walking around and driving plus the sounds heard were not realistic because it would of actually been slower movements and very little sound. Another thing that bothered me were the sand storms which seemed more like the type on Jupiter not on Mars. On mars because the atmosphere is so thin the sand storms would not be strong at all. The worst part was lifting off into space from Mars and not having a shield over the capsule being ejected into space and just a tarp. In reality this would have broke multiple bones and the entire rib cage of a human because the pressure is that intense. Because it wasn't realistic enough I gave three stars. Most science fiction movies out there have realistic theoretical plots that support evidence and possibility. This one did not have enough evidence to support it.

Please understand...I am not rating what I think of the MOVIE, because that is strictly subjective. Frankly, you could care less about if I liked the movie or not, at least I hope that is the case. What I am rating here is the QUALITY of the movie in 4K. You must have a 4K Blu-Ray player to play the 4K version of this movie, which is why I paid the extra cash for the disc. (Someday, I'm sure they will all drop in price when something else takes the place of 4K, at least I hope so!) do not be confused, my player does upscale non-4K discs to "near" 4K quality, but it also plays 4K discs. If you have a regular Blu-Ray player, it will not play this disc, so save yourself the cash and buy a Blu-Ray version. Anyway, I digress. The 4K quality of this movie played on my Samsung UBD-K8500 Ultra HD player is phenomenal. I own a Samsung Ulta HD TV model KS8000 TV, and the resolution is spectacular. You can see even the minutest fragment of details in scenes of intergalactic battles, down to the strands of hair on the character's heads. It is as if you are living the scene, not merely watching it passively. The experience is well worth the money you will pay for the 4K version of his film. In my opinion, it beat the resolution that I saw it in at my local theater, and to be honest, I doubt my local theater has 4K resolution, but my experience has been that theaters make up for picture quality by boosting the sound extremely loudly instead in order to try to make you immerse yourself in the action. I can honestly say that this 4K movie played in its highest definition will immerse you without a doubt! Happy viewing!

The biggest surprise about this movie is its understatement. Ridley Scott is the man who gave us Alien; Matt Damon is the man who created Jason Bourne in the eponymous movie series. Instead of gore and frantic action. Scott gives us a traditional and balanced story about a man marooned on Mars in which he celebrates Damon's heroism and the heroism of the folks back home at NASA.

Much of the movie features Damon alone on Mars, but the combination of Damon and Drew Goddard's script keeps it from getting boring. At Mission Control on planet Earth, Jeff Daniels and a talented group of actors wrestle with politics and money alongside a genuine desire to bring this man home.

The movie features no grandiose acting, no big speeches about anything good or bad. Scott's view of heroism in this movie is an old one. All of these characters have a job to do and they do it to their utmost because they know everyone else is relying on them.

Despite the outer space theme, The Martian features few mind-boggling effects. There are SFX aplenty, but consistent with Scott's tone of understatement, the SFX are always secondary to acting and relationships.

On top of all that, the movie has a happy ending that won't make you puke. What's not to like?

This movie was allright... I am going to school for aerospace engineering, so I guess I get a little critical when I see things in movies that are not physically accurate. Good plot though. I enjoyed it, but would have enjoyed it much more thoroughly if it was more accurate in a physical sense.

The first astronauts on Mars are driven from their research by a massive storm. They flee the planet but leave Matt Damon behind. The film is then about his efforts to survive until  if help can come. There are a surprising number of actors in a film about one man in a sort of future day Robinson Caruso. This works though as the number of people needed to run a space program is pretty extensive. What is interesting is the common will to do the right thing. Its good to see people working together on something so complex. There are some surprises here. Damons story remains central though. Showing him sciencing the hell out of things to give him a chance to live. There are successes and failures. Altogether it is an inspiring (if pretty improbable) effort that keeps your attention. Recommended 3.75 stars.

BOTTOM LINE: If you enjoy speculative science fiction, with an emphasis on the science aspect, then THE MARTIAN is strongly recommended. Yes, some things in the plot & script don't entirely work or completely satisfy, and there are nits to pick, but overall I found this to be an immensely entertaining science fiction film. If you can, watch it as a back-to-back double feature with Criterion's excellent Blu-ray release of 1964's ROBINSON CRUSOE ON MARS. I think you'll easily see and appreciate the similarities & differences that each film has to offer. 5 STARS

THE STORY: An accident during a fierce planetary storm on Mars leaves a member of the ARES 3 manned expedition stranded & left for dead, while the rest of the team evacuates the Red Planet and heads for home. The next morning, the wounded astronaut discovers he's been left behind ...but there's no time for grief, fear or self pity; he has far more immediate concerns. He has to self-administer emergency first aid for his life-threatening injuries, then fix the oxygen scrubbing system. While he's healing up he'll have to repair the damaged base station to make it habitable, then devise a method to contact Earth to let them know he's still alive, AND, most importantly, figure out a way to grow food on the lifeless planet to help supplement the meager rations that were left behind at the abandoned base camp. He'll have to work all these problems out - by himself - if he hopes to stay alive until a rescue mission can reach him... which could be a year or more away.

THOUGHTS: A lot of negative reviews badmouth the pseudoscience involved, and other errors both large & small. But they're missing the point. THE MARTIAN is NOT a filmed recreation of an actual Mars landing, it's merely a clever (if thinly-veiled) re-telling of the classic sci-fi movie ROBINSON CRUSOE ON MARS. Remember folks, THE MARTIAN is a science FICTION movie, nothing more. As such, it's an utterly captivating and thoroughly engrossing motion picture experience. An acting tour de force for Matt Damon, who spends the lion's share of the film's 2hr 20+minute runtime on his own. And while that could be the kiss of death, his plight is so personal & immediate that I couldn't wait to see what happened next. It's so engrossing watching him work things out that you forget it's basically a one-man play. From a technical standpoint, (as with most modern big budget effects-heavy films), the look is slick, real-feeling and in many cases absolutely stunning. The scenery, while all reds & oranges, is still eerily beautiful to behold. Y

THE BLU-RAY: A strong modern hi-def release, with solid, crisp picture and a clean level soundmix. No complaints whatsoever. Extras include two short (9min & 14min) pieces on the making of the film, a short fictitious news magazine show (17min) detailing the story behind the mission, three mock educational mini-films (about 1.5-3mins long) about the missions, a gag reel, production artwork & designs, and finally the film's theatrical trailer.

I thoroughly enjoyed this movie. It's funny. It's a great adventure story. It's just an all around entertaining movie. I liked it FAR more than Gravity, which has a similar "How to survive a space disaster" them. The big difference is that Gravity goes out of it's way at the very beginning to tell the audience about some strict principles of physics then proceeds to spend the next 90 minutes breaking all of them (like sound not traveling in the vacuum of space).

The Martian doesn't make any such assertions. It plays fast and loose with some rules of physics, but it doesn't pontificate about those rules first. So it works as an entertaining movie that doesn't come across as being disjointed. I'm talking about things like purposely putting holes in your space suit while in the vacuum of space, and how despite that being a REALLY bad idea that would have immediate disastrous consequences in real life, it turns into an amazingly fun adventure scene. But The Martian also gets other small details right too like how astronauts wear a pretty fancy heating/cooling suit under a space suit, rather than just underwear. So they get enough details right to make it believable, thus allowing you to suspend disbelief a little easier when they do something that's more far fetched.

Donald Glover practically steals the entire movie, which is kind of surprising considering how relatively small his character is and how little screen time he gets. He plays this hyper scientist who literally sleeps in his office so he is closer to his research. He is focused only on the problem of rescuing Matt Damon. He doesn't care about things like who the head of NASA is or why he should be more polite to him.

I also couldn't get the idea out of my head that this entire movie just takes place in Matt Damon's mind. I kept thinking that he's really his character from Interstellar who was stranded on that ice planet on the other side of the worm hole with no real hope of survival, and now he's just imagining being rescued. (This was not intentional by the film makers....probably. But I found the idea amusing)

I enjoyed the way they showed the various different perspectives of people in the film. There was the "Oh my god how am I going to survive" perspective of Matt Damon on Mars. There was the "Oh my god how did we leave our friend behind" perspective of the other astronauts. There was "How do I keep NASA from losing all its' funding over this" perspective of Jeff Daniels (Head of NASA). There was the "How do we spin this into positive PR" perspective of Kristin Wiig (NASA PR director). Etc etc etc. I thought they did a good job of exploring the perspectives of different people like that. It made the story more robust.

The actin was very good overall. The writing was solid. If you like sci fi adventure stories this is well worth checking out.

This movie does not parallel the book in it's entirety (for example, there is no mention of Whatney being a mechanical engineer as well as being a botanist) but the lack of parallels doesn't detract from the story or at all.  Even the use of the plastic and duct tape to seal the air lock breach is forgivable because of Damon's acting and the emotion incorporated into the scene.  The poetic license exercised in developing the movie produces a gripping screenplay and superb casting and direction produce a very good movie. I would recommend it to any science nerd, with the caveat, "they could not spend major time in the movie repairing the hab, building ramps to get the Pathfinder loaded onto rover, and the "enhanced equipment, hab size, etc. allow the story to work without creating major sections that are boring or that have to be explained, later."

Well made modern version of Robinson Crusoe (or any other castaway survival story). Good acting and writing, excellent production values. As a science nerd I was bothered by the totally unrealistic wind hazard. Mars is a near vacuum, as is shown (and is crucially important to a later plot event) and although it does have high winds and dust storms that can cover most of the planet, the force of the wind is tiny, because the air is only about 0.6% as dense as the air on earth. It reality it could not and would not do the damage that is the stranding event.
