For a year and a half you are stranded on a foreign planet. There is a small fraction of the sunlight from Earth available, there is no water, no plants, and you are surrounded by nothing but dust- both on the ground and in the air. There are little resources you can make to survive, and the most tangible ones will only get you through thirty days. On top of that, you have limited access to NASA headquarters, who aren't even aware that you are still alive on the planet. Sounds captivating? Then you are in for a real treat in The Martian, the latest science-fiction thriller that inspires the world to progress humanity towards the stars.

This Ridley Scott instant classic concerns a botanist named Mark Watney (Matt Damon) who is left abandoned on Mars after assumed dead by his team of astronauts during a storm that forced them to abort their mission. He now has only a matter of days worth of food to keep himself alive on a planet where nothing grows, so he has to learn how to grow plants and create water through his own resources to survive over a total of more than 560 Sol (Mars days). Meanwhile, NASA, after months of assuming him dead, search for plans to get him home safe after uncovering his calls to earth.

First off, Damon (Good Will Hunting, Saving Private Ryan) gives an above exceptional performance as the stranded astronaut. He presents his terror of living all alone on a deserted planet, yet still expresses active willpower to do whatever is necessary to survive. He records his progress through a series of video diaries, and his direct tone of speaking to the monitor charges your desire to watch his journey step-by-step until the end.

The Martian may not be the most suspenseful nor the most dynamic of Ridley Scotts directorial efforts. It doesnt have the unsettling atmosphere of Alien, or the social commentary of Blade Runner, or the thoughtful concepts on life of Thelma & Louise, or the heart-pounding storytelling of Gladiator, but Scott does accomplish what he has always done best: keeping viewers of all tastes fully invested into the experiences urgency from the opening to the closing credits. Say for instance, near the end of the films second act, Mark accidentally cracks a rather large segment of his helmet. He then quickly tapes the glass of the helmet shut as his suit gradually says, 30% of oxygen remaining 20% of oxygen remaining 15% of oxygen remaining It leaves you leaning on edge wanting to see him get out of this seemingly doomed predicament.

The stakes of the story were at first reasonably high: Mark has little means of staying alive on a planet where nobody has lived before, and he has to bring the attention from NASA, which creates a whole different set of challenges. But the problem with the screenplays structure is that Mark did not have enough backstory. Okay, so he is stranded on Mars and needs to get home, but what does he need to get home for? Does he have a son whos dying of cancer? Is the NASA educational program going to collapse without him there? Is he the fulfilled prophecy who will volunteer as tribute to protect middle earth from a Vulcan Sith Lord named Voldemort? There needed to be something urgent pressing on him to get home.

What about NASAs subplot in getting Mark home? Well, it is really nothing to jump on your seat about, as somewhere midway through the films running time, the temptation to snooze off becomes slightly greater, as the supporting cast has as much personality as the dust of Mars itself. Any real urgency to get Mark home is significantly lost, since not enough screen time was spent on developing the other characters.

But thankfully, the way that the NASA terms are talked about, and the ways that Mark explains his methods of survival, are told in scientifically accurate language, but still in a way that is easy and fun to listen to, with appropriate doses of humor sprinkled throughout. That takes an acquired skill that many screenwriters sadly never find in their careers.

I can conceptually see The Martian inspiring many scientists and NASA executives in the next several years, setting our expectations for progress to the next frontier. So Ridley Scott, thanks a million for the inspirational push into a brilliant new tomorrow!

Overall Grade: B+

In 2035, the six-person crew of the Ares III is on a month-long stay on the surface of Mars. Suddenly, a violent dust storm starts that threatens to topple and destroy their ascent vehicle. It is quickly decided to abort the mission and leave Mars. In the ensuing chaos, astronaut Mark Watney (Matt Damon) is struck by debris and presumed dead. However, after the rest of the crew had already left for Earth, Watney is revealed to have survived his ordeal. Now abandoned on Mars with some equipment, he must use his wit and knowledge to survive and hope for a trip home. Meanwhile, back on Earth, NASA discovers that Watney is still alive and starts to scramble for ways to keep him alive and get him home.

This movie can be best described as a love letter written to science, engineering, and NASA. It is an exploration of how a person can use science to overcome problems and does so in a somewhat realistic fashion. This is where the movie is the most entertaining. In addition to that, I thought the cinematography was excellent as it showed the sterile, but active, environment of the Martian surface. The acting was generally good from all the major actors.

One issue I had with the film is that plot seemed rather thin for much of the movie. You watch Watney as he solves problems, but not much else. There is not a lot of tension as Watney goes through the motions to stay alive. It is almost as if the movie is lacking a human element.

This Blu-ray release is rather light on the bonus features for such a technically advanced film. There are two short making-of features. Also included are a series of promos that were done in-universe which are honestly more bizarre to watch than anything else.

I enjoyed this movie. If you like hard science fiction, movies such as Apollo 13 and Gravity instead of Star Wars and Armageddon, then I would recommend this.

Being on a different planet alone.  That's gotta be a scary feeling!  The first to walk around on a whole planet, as Matt Damon even mentions in one scene.  If that isn't one of the craziest moments of freedom you've ever felt, I don't know what is!  None of us will ever get to experience such a true sense of being alone (even though those who live near the top of Alaska come close!)

The Martian is about an astronaut crew assuming Matt Damon dies after debris hits Matt and sends him flying back a pretty good bit so they leave him behind, however a short time later the NASA scientists notice something on the radar- movement!  Yup that's Matt alright, and he's alive and functional.  The good news is that he's alive, but the bad news?  Well the astronauts deserted him and in order to bring him back, technology setbacks and disputes amongst the NASA team means that it would take many months/years to make a rescue mission happen.

So what does Matt Damon do to waste time?  Well at first after he returns to his ship (called the Mars Ascent Vehicle) he has to remove a pole that got jammed into his stomach.  Luckily he has the medical supplies to fix himself up and make himself good as new!  The way he takes care of this problem is pretty science fiction-y in a movie that isn't typically so frequent or noticeable showing such things.  Then again you could argue realistically trying to get someone off Mars before they die is science fiction enough!

The story spends a pretty decent chunk of time showing Matt Damon growing potatoes, listening to disco music (music he dreads but doesn't have a choice but to listen to because his crew mates favorite type of music was disco) and walking or driving a Mars rover across the barren red dirt, rocks and hills of Mars using his astronaut expertise to try and sustain as much of a life for himself as he can.

Of course anything could go wrong at any moment.  Plus he's on limited food and water supply which increases the odds of help not arriving in time and Matt not making it off the planet alive.  He could also puncture his suit and lose oxygen which is a big concern, though it seems he has the means to correct most of the minor things that could go wrong related to his suit (then again the scene where he damages his helmet, loses oxygen and need to tape himself up as quickly as possible was quite alarming for poor Matt!)

Meanwhile an even bigger chunk of the story is that the NASA team back on Earth spends a considerable amount of time trying to contact Matt using limited computer resources, and once that happens it's confirmed Matt's still alive so every rejoices!  That's one aspect of the story anyway- later on when the rescue mission gets underway, coming up with an actual plan to rescue Matt becomes more sophisticated).  I like how Matt realizes later that he can break the law by recognizing he's on a different planet, and the law doesn't say anything about that now does it!  He doesn't do anything crazy that I remember though.  Then again what law is there to break?  It's not like he knocked over his neighbors mailbox with a baseball bat.  There is no neighbor, mailbox or baseball bat on the whole planet!

Anyway the dilemma of figuring out a way to get Matt off Mars remains the theme for most of the movie.  Jeff Daniels is head of NASA (who is certainly showing his age and doesn't feel right playing this serious role given his humorous silly stuff in the Dumb and Dumber movies) so he's the jerk I guess.  Chiwetel Ejiofor, Kate Mara, Michael Pena, the silly Donald Glover (who should have had more of a role and taken more seriously than he was given his accurate description of trying to get Matt off Mars), Kristen Wiig and others do everything they can to make a return mission to Mars possible.  Time is running out for poor Matt though, and attempting to use the most advanced rocket technology to speed up the rescuing process isn't as smooth as everyone was hoping which further complicates matters.

There's a lot of sophisticated writing going on here such as Matt digging up the radioisotope thermoelectric generator, a generator used to convert heat into electric.  Perhaps more of an understanding of rocket science would help make this stuff easier to follow  Luckily the movie's never confusing to understand since the reason behind Matt or the NASA teams actions is always explained afterwards using smaller words, but this does demand that the viewer pay closer attention than usual.  Perhaps more attention should have been given to Matt Damon exploring Mars instead of being isolated to one spot, but then again the movie was trying to go for a realistic (semi-realistic?) means of attempting to rescue somebody on Mars so I guess this is understandable.  In a serious situation you wouldn't want to move around while someone is looking for you.  Then again maybe Matt just wanted to be near his supplies, and particularly worried about losing oxygen.

The acting is really good, the writing is really good too in that it strikes the perfect balance of never being too far fetched nor boring either.  You can pretty much tell Matt's not really on Mars though.  The movie relies on special effects that obviously look too fake (such as the sky).  Then again perhaps not  since I've never been to Mars so I can't say for sure what the sky would look like in person.

It does seem like space adventure movies like to have light hearted comedy elements to them, and this is no exception.  Even the NASA scientists present themselves as clumsy and silly at times, and I didn't care for this.  Donald Glover in particular was too much, as was the scene where the one scientist dumps his coffee in the trashcan and soon after trips over it.  Perhaps telling the story directly without the silly stuff should have been written instead but complaining about such a thing isn't really worth it because the movie never loses sight of the serious mission to bring Matt home.  Plus being too serious would make everyone feel ordinary and bland, so there's that to consider.  Highly recommended!

Fanatic movie about an astronaut left behind on Mars after a severe storm separated him from his team.  Being a botanist, he tries to stretch his food supply to last until someone can come get him.  To avoid any spoilers I will stop there, however I would say it is one of the best movies both me and my wife have enjoyed equally for a long time. Usually one of us really likes movies and the other is okay with it because of our different tastes, so it's rare to find a movie we both really enjoy. Definitely would recommend to anyone looking for a great story about survival and courage in desperate times.

Wow! Kudos to Matt Damon for making Mark Watney warm, friendly and downright real.  After being on Mars "with" him for over 2 hours you leave this movie wanting to give him a hug, a medal and a meal or just give him a call to chat about the experience because he feels like a friend. There is just the right amount of humor and humility peppered throughout the story to lend plenty of credence to every character.  You won't get lost in the tech talk although, as you should expect, there is plenty of it.  I figured this would be something boring to leave playing in the background while I got some work done today.  Wrong indeed.  Instead I just lost 2 hours of work time because I was riveted to the screen and totally invested in the result.  What a treat!

This is a dramatic presentation of the survival of a lone astronaut on Mars. As a space scientist working for NASA all my professional life, I would say the story is more than plausible; the story overstretches some aspects, but on the whole, under the right circumstances, the feat is quite feasible. I am mostly impressed by the Chinese participation in the rescue efforts. NASA has steadfast refused to share space exploration with China out of fear of "leaking" secrets to China. As a scientist, I do not think there are any secrets; the fact that "it can be done" is the biggest secret. Take the nuclear bomb as an example. Despite the common belief that Russians (or the defunct Soviet Union) stole the atomic secrets from the U S, the biggest secret in the nuclear bomb is that "it can be done." Once the feasibility of the bomb is demonstrated, it would take an intelligent physicist only hours to figure out HOW to make it (to make it is another story, it will require extensive engineering and scientific expertise). Likewise, the Chinese developed their space programs without U S help and they are about to land a female astronaut on the Moon (that a female is chosen is to fulfill a long held Chinese legend of Chang-é, a woman who fled to the Moon).

ENDING TO FAST

A review on one site calls this flick "Human Ingenuity: The Movie." Meh. I think "Cast Away" did that much better. I did not read the book on which this movie was based or read any reviews (critical or otherwise) before I watched "The Martian". All I had seen was the trailer, and all I knew was that people seemed to love it and praise it to high heaven. So I eagerly anticipated enjoying the movie myself. Man, was this a letdown!

Thin or nonexistent characterizations, too many superfluous characters (many of them flat), too much talking, too much switching between sets of characters. I think Jeff Daniels must have gotten botox injections before his scenes, because his face barely moved the entire movie. At one point two characters spend at least a minute debating the tone in which Matt Damon's character had written something along the lines of "Are you kidding me?" I'm serious. That conversation actually took place in the movie.

Character A: 'Do you think he meant, "Are you kidding me?" Or was it more like "Are you kidding me?!"'
Character B: 'I think it was the first one.'

I'm not watching this scene as I type this, so I can't be totally sure that's what they said, but it's close. And it didn't end there! They continued to discuss the possible tone of the message! Are YOU kidding me, movie? Stop wasting my time! This asinine conversation does NOT qualify as humor! The movie bored me and had zero emotional punch. I agree with others who have mentioned how predictable this was, too. That means zero tension, zero suspense, which translates to zero enjoyment. It was pretty, with mostly good SFX; that's IT. I might have found the movie more fascinating if the tagline (and outcome) had been "Left to Die" instead of "Bring Him Home" and the movie was about the recovery of Watney's body and cheery, yet resolute video logs (I dislike the non-word "vlogs") and not the rescue of Watney himself. I didn't even like the guy.

If you find profanity distasteful like I do, you'll be annoyed early and often. You get two f-bombs within the first half hour or so of the movie and more f-bombs are implied later. For me, this did nothing to make Matt Damon's character either sympathetic or heroic. On the back end of the movie, you get a gratuitous, yet creepy CGI visual of Matt Damon's naked back and backside as he walks away from a shower. I'm pretty sure I would have been able to tell that the character had lost a lot of weight without seeing "him" naked. And by "him", I mean the CGI body they pasted onto the Matt Damon's head. It looked weird and slimy, probably because of the unnatural way it moved. Yuck.

There were so many things highly implausible. Growing potatoes on Mars? No problem, throw some poop in there and you're good! Never mind that the Martian soil is of an entirely different kind. Considering soil on earth is made of minerals (rock, sand, clay, silt), air, water, and organic material (matter from dead plants and animals), I don't see how the Martian soil could possible contain the necessary nutrients to grow Earth plants. Why couldn't they have Matt Damon grow the food with hydroponics? That at least would be plausible.

I watched this movie with a real NASA astronaut. He told us that many of the science/math points were mistakes, or 'artistic license', but many were correct and accurate, especially the gravity boost from the orbit around the planets. This science fiction movie is much better done than earlier ones. Unlike "Gravity" which used actual imagery from the space station, this movie was filmed in Jordan. But the landscape was quite convincing. "Interstellar" played on some scientific concepts but was a fantasy.

The most convincing part of the movie is the attitude of the main character (portrayed by Matt Damon). He did grieve and did become frustrated, and he did show fear, but he immediately started to record his experience and relentlessly PROBLEM-SOLVE, PROBLEM-SOLVE. He was very creative and diligent -- that shows that his emotional state was OK. Clinically depressed people are not able to think well, and often suffer from inertia. He maintained a positive outlook and accepted his own death long before it might happen. He did not blame his colleagues, NASA, bad luck, or anyone or anything for his situation. These are all traits that NASA selects for in astronauts.

I thought I would be bored, and I was worried and scared, but I watched the movie twice: the first time, straight through on the big screen TV. The second time on the computer which displayed little details and profiles of the actors which I found to be very interesting. The notes told me some of the differences between the movie and the novel on which it was based, and some mistakes such as the positive pressure inside would bulge out the tarp and it won't flap, or in weightlessness, you cannot change direction without a push.

that I don't believe anyone reading this review will ever live to see 3 or more Mars expeditions (we'll always be told "it's too expensive"). The movie follows the book in as faithful an adaptation as I think I've ever seen and even gets most things (the atmosphere is supposed to be too thin to support such a storm as we see in the opening scene) right. The classroom scene at movie's end is the biggest difference between book and screen.
Action and adventure? some, but this is no Star Wars and you'll get no aliens or even a mention of microbes-  you just get a wonderful portrayal of the Red Planet. I'm actually surprised the movie did so well, there must be more "Mars"/"Space" people around than I'd expected because this is just the sort of movie that would appeal to them.

Overrated, and overlong. I guess I should have know I wouldn't like this film since I didn't like the book either. I guess the film is better than the book in my estimation, mainly because we do not have to hear every single obnoxious blog entry from the main character. (Not sure why all the hype for either film or book, though, as they are both underwhelming.) This film is sort of standard Hollywood stuff: non-engaging, predictable, and weak dialogue, people going through motions. When you really could care less about a main character, then it really sort of kills the experience. It is one of those cases where the premise-- a man being stranded on Mars and having to figure out how to survive-- is so much better than the actual experience of the film. Very mediocre film, hard to believe it was one of the nominees for Best Picture. Was 2015 that watered down?

Only Matt Damon has the skill to play a solo role for 90 minutes or so without boring the audience. Instead, we were sitting on the edge of our seats. Even though I had read the book (so I knew how the story ended)  it was so well-done that it was like watching a documentary. One imagines that this is what human travel to Mars will be really like (if they can ever get the Astronauts' union to allow the eating of potatoes for 2 years)

An early part of the film glossed over the situation that caused Damon to be abandoned on Mars. The necessity for the space ship to blast off was unclear. Readers of the book had a better 'picture' of the storm and emergency exit of the space craft than viewers of the film. The term "Sol" meaning a Martian day, was not explained well in the film, nor was the time interval between transmitting a message and receiving it. The way Damon 'developed a visual code' to communicate with NASA was also glossed over in the film.

Nevertheless, I rate this film Five Stars!  .

When Matt Damon was nominated for a Golden Globe award for "The Martian" I was surprised to see him in the "Comedy" category. I had not seen the film at that time, but knowing what I did know about it I couldn't believe it was a comedy. Now that I have seen it, there are certainly a number of laugh out loud moments, but those are in context and the film is most definitely not a comedy.
  I thoroughly enjoyed "The Martian" even though one might think of it as sort of "Gravity" on solid ground. For me it was more like "Robinson Crusoe on Mars" than anything else, although there is no "Friday."
  The cinematography in the film is spectacular. I really felt like I was on Mars. Of course there has to be somewhat of a suspension of disbelief given the idea of someone being stranded on Mars, but that was easy enough to do. I could go on about this film but I'll leave it at this: It is a good movie, well made, and entertaining. One can't ask for much more than that.

I am not a fan of science fiction, or fiction of any sort, sadly, but this book attracted me in the way it is narrated. The author must have excellent communication skills per se, since the tone of narrative was funny, affable, familiar, and uncomplicated. The theme, of course, is amazing and shines for its portrayal of resilience and self-assurance, while not entirely diminishing equally-limiting human traits such as despair, frustration, and hopelessness. The movie, in my opinion, did some justice to the main character in that it was Matt Damon who played it---a very well-taken care of and physically fit, Matt Damon. Yes, please.  Other than that, read the book first and then watch the movie for more visual input.

It took me 3 nights at home to watch it in segments -- excruciatingly tedious and boring techno-geek story, with the dramatic tension of a kindergarten kabuki play. Stock "heroic" characters emoting schmaltz, stale cliche dialogue, Matt Damon's cutesy monologues to his camcorder betray no realistic tension, loneliness, or angst of such a castaway position. Unbelievable, with stupid "feel-good" soundtrack sequences, bottoming out with "Waterloo."

The premise could have worked with the addition of a little HUMAN drama instead of machine malfunctions substituting: have 2 or 3 astronauts abandoned, with some kind of conflict and surprise between them -- the food runs out, one turns into Alferd Packer and cannibalizes his mates. Or a love triangle exploding as their sense of desperation and stress grows but this would have required a real screenwriter/dramatist writing the script, instead of a failed engineer.

My husband has watched this movie at least once a week since it came out on DVD. We saw it four times in theaters, and he told literally everyone we know to go see it. He even bought three copies of the book: one paperback for himself, one for me, and the audiobook for us both. For a quiet, reserved guy like him, that's the equivalent of getting 'THE MARTIAN' tattooed on his chest so nobody will misunderstand his meaning when he strips naked and runs through the streets screaming at everyone to watch it as he pelts them with copies of the book. it's definitely one of his favorite movies of all time. And, you know what? I agree with him. This movie is spectacular. We watched it again last night, as we've done at least once a month since it came out, and I think I'd like to watch it again tonight. The Martian is a wonderful movie. Its a nearly perfect blend of drama, high adventure, suspense, comedy, and realistically futuristic technology. Starring Matt Damon, Jessica Chastain, Jeff Daniels, Chiwetel Ejiofor, and Sean Bean, and directed by Ridley Scott, it tells the story of an American astronaut who must fight for his survival after becoming stranded on Mars.

It is the year 2035. Mark Watney (Damon) is a member of the six-person crew of astronauts on the Ares III mission to Mars. When he is struck by flying debris during a blinding windstorm, he is presumed dead by Commander Melissa Lewis (Chastain) his other five crew mates. They are forced to leave Watney behind on the Red Planet when the mission is scrubbed.

But Watney is not dead but only badly injured. Hes completely alone and stranded 140 million miles from home. The next mission to Mars won't reach him for another four years. Now he must figure out how to survive until someone can come and rescue him.

Meanwhile, back on earth, officials at NASA soon learn that the astronaut they thought was dead is very much alive. They must figure out a way to rescue him before his food and supplies run out. They find their efforts slowed by internal politics and bureaucratic infighting, and a catastrophic event that could leave Watney stranded on Mars forever

There is a whole lot to like about The Martian. The film features Matt Damon in his most engaging role. He portrays Mark Watney as smart, decisive, ingenious, unflappable, and with a keen sense of humor. He allows himself only a few minutes of fear before he decides to buckle down, science the sh! t out of his problem, and find a way to survive long enough to get home. I think Damons scenes on Mars are among the most enjoyable of the film.

The scenes featuring NASAs efforts to rescue Watney are also excellent. NASA Director Teddy Sanders (Daniels) and Mars Mission Director Vincent Kapoor (Ojiofor) find themselves at loggerheads with Crew Director Mitch Henderson (Bean) in making the necessary decisions to rescue Watney.  These scenes are quite realistic in their depiction of the infighting and political wrangling that frequently goes on in a bureaucracy.

The Martian is undoubtedly the best science fiction movie that Ive seen in a long, long time.  Highly recommended.

I watched Gravity, The Martian and Interstellar

Interstellar has probably all of the elements of a "good" captivating film comparing to the others. It's behind the science in comparing to The Martian, but it has a metaphysical angle that some may like (akin to 2001). I did not have any issues with the pacing of the film, though it might be long for non sci fans. There are some conceptual and science plot holes like any sci-fi film, but not in an annoying way (like gravity). Though for the main concept you'd have to suspend disbelief. I would put this in the same category as Kubrick 2001, but not above it. Story is a 5/5, Science is a 5/4.

The Martian is a more of solid "science now" movie. So while great all around it's not as "sci-fi" as some other more "futuristic" films, which is both a positive to some and maybe a negative to others. While I'm pretty good in picking up technical faults, they were not obvious in this film. This is a solid well researched film. If you're technically inclined you might actually predict technical problems before they happen, which was a surprise for me since pretty much any other sci-fi film I had watched before simply made things up. I can't think of many other films to compare it to, except maybe Gravity for what it tried to do and failed at. Story is a 5/4, Science is a 5/5.

Gravity is a film I wanted to like but it just has a number of conceptual problems that I can not look past. I was most disappointed in that while it was depicting "space" they could not stop and let you feel like you're in space. For example, 2001 did this brilliantly with the sound of breathing, in this film they just stick music in when they run out of all of that annoying dialogue. I did not like the Sandra Bullock character at all. Her character came off too much like the female equivalent of "average joe" in space, which I found annoying. Her presence in the film made all of the holes in the film rather glaring. The positive of this film is that it has realistic orbital mechanics (Physics). But not realistic Science. Story is a 5/3, Science is a 5/3.

By far the best real science fiction movie in ages, good hard science, no laser battles, no exploding spaceships, just good hard science fiction.  I've watched it now multiple times and read the book multiple times and neither suffers from repeat exposure.  That's the sign of good writing and good movie making.  The movie made quite a few changes from the book, but they were necessary or it would have had to been done as a mini-series.

One quibble with the movie that did bug me was the EVA  scenes on the Hermes ship.  No NASA astronaut would even EVA without a tether.  The scenes of guy outside the ship pulling himself along, especially across the rotating section (which would have flung him into his own trajectory never to be seen again) were not really necessary.  It could have been done correctly with tethers and been just as dramatic.  Same for the scenes with the astronauts in the open airlocks, no tethers, not wise.  But that's really a minor quibble and the kind of thing to expect from Hollywood when they prefer the dramatic over the practical.

Also, the captain's believability as an in-charge person is not believable. She's forcing her authority instead of owning it. She's too inconsistent emotionally. Jeff Daniels should have been the captain, older, authoritative and believable. He and Chiwetel Ejiofor are the two actor's who created the most dynamic drama in the movie. Ejiofor should have been the astronaut left behind on Mars. Just looking at his facial expressions would have sold emotions we wanted to feel. The other actor who seemed like the real deal was the Chinese actor who was in charge of building the rescue/supply rocket.

This is not my type of movie at all, but my husband was dying to see it so I went to see it anyway. I enjoyed watching this movie it was good and science behind it was accurate. Ridley Scott returns to his brilliant best in this epic tale of survival and morals. Matt Damon, the Martian, provides one of the best performances of his career, capturing the audience from the minute he appears on screen. The fantastic story is aided by great acting all round.

The Martian is about astronaut Mark Watney who is presumed dead after a violent storm and left behind by the crew. He actually lives and must survive on Mars for months with meager supplies and his own ingenuity. he delivers one of his most spectacular movies to date that's capable of making you laugh and putting you on the edge of your seat. The final act of the film is particularly nail-biting, drawing comparisons to some of Gravity's most terrifying scenes. But what makes The Martian such a hit is its heart. Besides its great humor and amazing characters, it emphasizes the value and integrity of the human spirit.

I watched Gravity months prior to this and I had to walk away from that movie from basic drama and the fear it induced on "Scream Tactics". The only meat in it was trying to make me startled all the time. I had read this book and loved the read but wondered if it would translate well or if they'd do the same thing.

They didn't try that and it really translated well. They cut down on the verbal cursing (which I didn't mind as an adult) but they did it so subtlety so that it's really still there and winks at the writing in the book and is fine around the kids (unless they read lips). You still get the idea that he IS a space pirate in his position and is having very frustrating moments up there on his own.

I don't do movie reviews and wax about this or that. As a viewer they did capture the book well. What Gravity did throughout their entire movie, this one did where it was needed and not abused for hours on end. It was just great fun to see our beloved character work through problems and perhaps what we'd go through ourselves. "Am I doomed?" Yes, but I won't give up trying all the things.

I compare it to Gravity only because it made you think about how scary space really is, then underlined it. This one has someone not grabbing for straws and hoping for the best and bumping around space, he's left on Mars and doing everything he knows to do in order to maybe survive. Make it in the end or not, there's some real scientific method being used in The Martian and we get to see every win and many losses in the system of space travel.

I wanted to be a police officer growing up. When that became too risky, I wanted to be an astronaut because everything is perfect with them. Nope...this movie moves you emotionally.

If you have or haven't read the book, it's hilarious either way. No funny is lost and to even the non-readers we laughed and cried. No spoilers!
Excellent - It was a worthwhile movie to watch and it kept my interest.

The actual package is your typical blu-ray case. The movie itself is okay... Matt Damon does a great job but as a film it skips many important scenes in the book. Especially toward the end of it. If you haven't read the book I'm sure you'd enjoy the movie even more.
Super entertaining film with amazing 4K picture and sound, couldn't recommend any better way to kick off ones 4K viewing experience!!!

The Martian (2015). 20th Century Fox. Rated PG-13. Running Time: 2 hours, 21 mins.
Directed by Ridley Scott.

Mark Watney (Matt Damon), Nick Martinez (Michael Pena), Melissa Lewis (Jessica Chastain) and Alex Vogel (Aksel Hennie)  are astronauts of the Ares 3 taking soil samples of Mars. Dr. Beth Johanssen (Kate Mara) in the HAB is getting tired of them chatting with each other outside. She finds it annoying. The astronauts are in a good mood.  Suddenly, the doctor gets a Mission Command on the computer. There is a severe storm coming and it does not look good. The astronauts go back into the HAB. Watney wants to wait out the storm, but Commander Lewis decides to go with the emergency procedure and scrub the mission. They go out into the storm and try to get to the Mars Ascent Vehicle Ship. Watney gets hit by flying debris and is carried by the wind. Martinez is already in the ship as the pilot and is given orders to prepare to leave. Lewis is looking for Watney, but it is too hard to see anything. Martinez doesn't want to leave yet. Beck (Sebastian Stan) thinks Watney is dead. he wants to leave. Lewis calls out to Watney one last time before going into the ship. The winds are so strong. The ship almost tipped. Martinez fires the propulsion and they blast off without Watney.
  Later, we see Watney come to and he is alive. He passed out with part of an antenna stabbed into his skin at his belly. He makes it back to the HAB and fixes his injury. He can not reach NASA, so he sends a video message. They never get it. He knows it will take 4 years for a manned mission to reach him. The HAB will only last for 31 days. Eventually, he will run out of food and water. They believe he has died.
  How will he survive and can he be rescued?

Also in the cast: Jeff Daniels, Kristen Wiig, Mackenzie Davis, Sean Bean, Chiwetel Ejiofor, Benedict Wong, Donald Glover, Frederik Pleitgen.

Filmed on Wadi Rum, Jordan as "Mars". Korda Studios (Etyek), Budaurs Airport, Budapest Whale, Budapest, Hungary. Johnson Space Center, Houston, Texas. Jet Propulsion laboratory, Pasadena, California.

Option of language: English Dolby Digital 5.1, English Descriptive Audio 5.1, Spanish Surround Dolby Digital 2.0, French Surround Dolby Digital 2.0.

Option of subtitles: English, Spanish, French.

Extras: Gag Reel, Ares III: Farewell, The Right Stuff, Ares: Our Greatest Adventure, Leave Your Mark, Bring Him Home, Theatrical Trailer.

Won Golden Globe for Best Picture, Best Actor - Matt Damon. Nominated for Best Director.
Only nominated for Academy Awards for Best Picture, Best Actor, Best Writing-Adapted Screenplay, Best Sound Mixing, Sound Editing, Visual Effects, Production Design.

NASA's long-term program, Orion, is developing human space flight to Mars anticipated in about 2035.

A very flawed sci-fi flick.  I gave it 2.5 stars rounded to 3.  Granted, the premise is interesting, but the technical details are really poorly done.  I wanted to like this film, but just couldn't, though I generally like Matt Damon films, (but not all).

First of all, dust storms on Mars are just that - composed of very tenuous dust.  The atmospheric pressure (troposphere) is less than 1% of that on earth, incapable of supporting large shale-like fragments even in high winds.  The dust is more like cement or cornstarch - like lunar dust.  Also, "soil" on Mars is not like plant friendly earth dirt which incorporates humus and trace minerals necessary for growing healthy plants.  Why would a space craft have real potatoes aboard for food?  (Even for a more real Thanksgiving, as in the book.)  More likely dried potatoes.  For planting, certified seed potatoes (no larger than jawbreakers) would be more reliable and disease free.  Also, a botanist is not a horticulturist.  One studies existing plant life, the other knows how to grow plants.  Why send a botanist to a dead planet that may once have had living organisms when a microbiologist or paleontologist might be more useful?

Next, the physics, rocket science and onboard life are also very thin - fantasy.  Who doesn't know about gravitational sling shot effects and orbital efficiency, as if it had to be rediscovered.  Using meters instead of kilometers to designate altitude above the Martian surface?  Yea, 1000 meters is a low orbit - still well within the atmosphere!  What's with Happy Days as onboard entertainment?  Why not Big Bang Theory or some more contemporary sit-com ?  And why, "In your face, Neil Armstrong" ?  Take a slap at the pioneering astronauts?  Really a disappointing film.

I could go on, but what's the use.  (I may update this review later.)  I could have written a better screenplay.  I did really want to like the film.

Update:  I've read Weir's book now.  The book is tedious too, bogged down with technobabble.  Skipped or scanned large portions of it that distracted from the story.  And why so often from the Martian do we get, "I tried it.  You know what.  It worked!"  I guess that's why it's science FICTION!  And Annie and her mouthy insults?  She would have been fired in an instant for snooping into 'classified' or 'proprietary' image files, regardless of gender preference.  Her job was email dispatcher, not data or image analyst!  Can we even begin to guess how many times she was laid in high school?  (The character brings it up in the book!)  I doubt Weir ever worked in a manned or unmanned spaceflight support environment.  I have - you don't insult supervisors, certainly not Mission Directors, or you'll end up fired, transferred or distributing emails, regardless of education or gender preference.  (Unless you're sleeping with one or more of them.)

First off, you can literally NOT compare a book in all its wonderful amazing glory to film.  I listened to the Audible book first and let me say - WOW!  There is always going to be wonder and imagination lost when translating to film and you just can't fit almost 11 hours of a book into a 2 hour movie.  Things that were lost in translation - Mark Watney was HILARIOUS in the book and it only came out a little on film.  Obviously for times sake they had to cut A LOT of the suspense/drama of the book down.  Hell, a man left on Mars is drama enough!  Great job Matt Damon - as always you are a class A actor!  I can't say the same for whoever made the decision to cast Jessica Chastain in the movie OR give her a big part in the ending - WTF, why not just let it play out like it did in the book??  But no, they had to give it some extra drama.  That's ok - it worked, but ugh, please people no more Jessica Chastain - like ever.  MY OPINION, obviously.  I loved the supporting cast - Kristen Wiig as Annie was awesome - but she was a badass in the book.  They deflated her A LOT in the movie and it would have been awesome to have kept her with all her sass and badassness that she had in the book.  I did love the additional ending of the movie.  This is something you do not get in the book.  It was very cute to see Beck and Johanssen with a baby at the end - I wish they would have built up that a little more with his final letters to the crew where he tells Beck to tell her he's in love with her already...... oh, again - only in my head!  I loved seeing Martinez going up again and Vogel with his huge family... but seriously - the movie did NOT need that sour puss look that Jessica Chastain has on her face at the end .... but whatever.  I enjoyed this movie a lot.  Again, can't even compare this to the book - but on its own it was great.  I would knock this down a star alone for the fact that I had to endure a movie with Jessica Chastain in it - BUT the rest of the cast made up for her.

A movie works on the childish level and constantly fails. Only if I forget all that and watch the movie as if it is an episode of Star Trek then it is watchable. I would expect more some sort of poetic elements, but the movie is just brutal, yet not even nearly brutal as it is on the Mars. You cannot survive on the Mars in any form if you have the situation that is displayed in the movie. Period. From that point, a documentary attempt is a total miss. As most know this is an adaptation of a book by the same name about an Astronaut named Mark Whitney played by Matt Damon, who ends up getting stranded on Mars when the rest of his crew leaves believing that he died. The story basically revolves around his efforts to stay alive and communicate with NASA with the equipment that is left behind, and the concurrent plan to rescue him.

The acting is superb on all fronts. I think the movie was very well cast, and the script was very well done. Apparently they did not change much from the book. For those who are into science or engineering it is enjoyable because they based things in real science, and although they certainly did take liberties with some things, the kept most of those liberties plausible. And for those who are not very science literate, the film did a good job not being so technical that everything would only be understandable to scientists and engineers.

For those who get the actual disc, the movie looks and sounds great on blu ray. As for extras there are probably between an hour and a half to 2 hrs worth. The biggest is a mock documentary telling the story that plays out in the film, mainly from Sean Beam and Jeff Daniel's character's perspectives. But most of the cast is involved. There are also some commercial like vignettes promoting the Mars missions, including one done with Neil Degrasse Tyson. Then there are some behind the scenes and making of features as well. A decent amount for those who like to go through the bonus material.

Most people don't seem to be aware that this was a book first, but it was. The book was also far superior. The problem with squeezing a book into the truncated length of a movie is that important plot points are missing which are important to the story. Mark Watney's journey just doesn't work as well in movie form. If you've never read the book I'm sure the movie would be fantastic, but honestly the novel is a classic and well worth your time.

There's also the random name/race change for Venkat Kapoor, who becomes Vincent and is black now because...reasons? Why did we need to change an Indian into a black guy? Also, Mindy Park (who is very clearly Korean) is now white for...more reasons? Also, the movie feels the need to stick an epilogue in, time which instead could have been spent elaborating on Mark's time on Mars. This entire epilogue felt very disjointed and was completely unnecessary.

Overall, the movie was enjoyable but if you like hard science fiction, read the book and skip the movie.

"The Martian" is one of my favorite science-fiction books -- heck, one of my favorite books of all time.  It was a well-researched novel that managed to be exciting, suspenseful, and even hilarious while still being mostly grounded in reality.  When a movie adaptation was announced, I was both excited and hesitant -- excited because a movie would mean more exposure for the book, hesitant because movie adaptations rarely live up to their source material.  Despite never having seen Ridley Scott's "Alien" movies, I had enough faith in him as a director and in Matt Damon as an actor to give the film a shot.

In the end, the movie was very well done, and stayed faithful to the spirit of the book.  But I still find myself preferring the book, even though I greatly enjoyed the film.

Mark Watney is an astronaut serving in the Ares III mission, a manned mission to Mars that is scuttled just a few days in by a powerful windstorm.  While evacuating the planet, Mark is hit by debris, and his crewmates give him up for dead and leave the planet.  However, through a stroke of fate, Watney survives, only to realize just how screwed he is as he takes stock of what supplies his team left behind.  His mission -- to scrape up some means to survive until the next mission rolls around (which is YEARS in the future), find a way to contact NASA, and brace himself for the unforgiving environment of the red planet.  And as NASA and the people of Earth scramble to find a way to bring him home, Mark must find a way to grow his own food in the barren Martian soil, keep his equipment up and running... and not be driven nuts by the disco music his crewmates left behind.

Technically this film is very well-done, with CGI that's seamlessly integrated into the film and doesn't break one out of their suspension of disbelief.  The barren Martian landscape (in reality filmed in Jordon) is both strangely beautiful and eerily desolate, heightening the sense of Mark's isolation all the more.  Said isolation also carries over to the HAB unit that is Mark's shelter -- functional but sterile, and far from homey and comfortable.  One gets the sense that it's not only the harsh and brutal environment that Mark has to struggle against, but the oppressive loneliness that surrounds him every day.

Matt Damon does a fantastic job as Mark Watney -- conveying the seriousness of his situation, but still able to find humor and silliness despite the odds.  The mission-log feel of the book is recreated through video logs, and one gets the feeling that Mark is increasingly struggling against madness as he rants and rambles at the camera.  The supporting cast is strong as well, both in Mark's crewmates as they make their own decisions regarding saving their stranded friend and in the people on Earth trying to bring him home.  It's nice to see Jeff Daniels in a dramatic role -- I'm mostly familiar with him through the live-action "101 Dalmatians" movie and the insipid "Dumb and Dumber" franchise, so to see him able to take on a more restrained, less goofy role is very pleasant.

I confess to not enjoying the movie as much as I did the book, but I blame that on myself and on no fault of the movie.  There's just too much in the book to pack into a film, and some of the best jokes had to be cut for time or simply because they didn't work in the context of the film (it would have been difficult to convey the infamous "boobs" joke onscreen with the same effectiveness).  A few scenes were also changed to make them more exciting or to simply translate to film better, which I can forgive -- some things are just more exciting on a written page than they are onscreen.  All the same, however, I didn't get the same enjoyment out of the film that I did out of the book.  Probably because I knew how everything would go down already, and there weren't many surprises for me.

All the same, "The Martian" is one of the best book-to-movie adaptations I've seen to date, and even if you haven't read the book you will probably enjoy the film.  Even non-sci-fi fans should enjoy this film, which keeps up a steady pace and a clever sense of humor throughout.

Tense and suspenseful but equally uplifting and optimistic, this film is THE antidote for cynicism and hopelessness in our world. Matt Damon plays his role so masterfully that even when you're thrust into his quest for survival along with him only minutes into the film you are willing to take that journey. Ultimately, that journey will prove worth it. A must-see, especially for kids with interest in science, this film puts ample focus on problem solving and scientific analysis and shows astronauts as not just rock stars, but intelligent and capable scientists too.

"Once you solve enough problems, you get to come home".

A powerful yet daunting quote. It does not give the audience any false hope of "if your work for it, you'll definitely succeed in some way". Instead, it tells you the reality of life: a fighting spirit doesn't guarantee you a win, but if you don't have it, you'll never survive. Matt Damon's performance as an astronaut who constantly cracks jokes even in the face of death is absolutely brilliant writing. I've seen those who criticize this, saying that it is unrealistic, yet they fail to understand that it is those who behave contrary to normal people in the face of extreme danger who gets to survive. It shows how strong mentally the astronaut is, and he is properly rewarded in the end because of it. A strong mind will not guarantee you a life full of success, but it will make it much easier.

I was absolutely spellbound while watching THE MARTIAN.  I was on the edge of my seat throughout the entire film and near tears a few times.  I have always followed our space programs.  I lived in Melbourne, Florida for three years - watched them go up on television and ran into the front yard to watch them until they were out of sight.  I was on Merritt Island before the Trans Vertical Assembly building was there - this film just brought all that home to me.  It had everything and more.  It all started with Sputnik, launched by the Soviet Union in the fifties I think.  We got our two girls out of bed early in the morning to watch  Neil Armstrong walk on the moon.  I was watching when the three astronauts never made off the launch pad and when the Challenger exploded during flight.  Apollo 13 was my favorite space film until THE MARTIAN was released.  I plan to watch it many more times;  I believe it is very realistic and would be what is expected.  It made sense to me.....I think it should have won more awards at the Oscars!!!!!

Found the movie to be entertaining on one level, but the  protagonist, a so-called  "botanist" was a poor character choice.  My main question is, why would you take a botanist to a planet where crops could not survive except under artificial conditions?  Personally knowing something about horticulture, I laughed myself silly at some of the things written into this script. He "scienced the hell" out of things, but more than likely he would have been dead before he could have grown crops. The story wasn't as intelligent as it could have been.  The author definitely needed to do more homework not only about horticulture, but about space in general.  The final scenes were uniquely laughable.
The only question we had when we finished the move: "Matt Damon.....were you really that desperate to sign off on this one"?

This is one of the best movies I have ever seen. I usually stay away from science fiction, but this as realistic as it can be. The special effects had me on the edge of my seat, while I watched it. The acting, of course, was superb.

Great film, I was positively surprised that Ridley Scott can still do good science fiction, especially after PROMETHEUS.

If I understood correctly they used real 3D cameras on the studio sets, but went for 3D-conversion of most of the grand and landscape shots - and unfortunately that shows, because there is stereoscopic depth beyond 200 yards which doesn't exist in real life and inevitably makes the Martian mountains and the Mark's rover vehicle look "miniaturized".

Whether it's Ridley Scott or the conversion company Prime Focus to put the blame on I do not know.

But if you want to be impressed by a realistic and majestic view of Martian mountains, then the 3D Blu-ray isn't necessarily your friend. Here, I can already predict that the (4K) Ultra HD Blu-ray will shine.
Though its in 2D only it will show the Martian landscape as you would really see it beyond 200 yards in real life - in 2D.

Nice adaption - book is better/funnier (I know, I know...I'm one of "those" people, who reads the book first). It was nice to hear the pronunciation of all those science-y words! Plus anything starring my boy, Jason Bourne (oops!) I meant Matt Damon, is very much worth a watch. You won't fidget for snacks, the bathroom, your phone etc. You'll become engrossed, and root for this Martian to get the heck off Mars. Enjoy!

Wait...actual science?  This is very fateful to the book in many ways although some liberties were taken and the long solo treks across Mars were cut and that was a shame. I thought they were the best parts of the book.
There is also some BAD science. First, no sandstorm will do anything on Mars but even the author admitted to cheating to get some dramatic tension.  Second, the radiation issue is not even considered on Mars. Without a magnetic field you're toast with severe cancer.  This is not addressed although the book mentions the magical carbon fiber material that works its magic.
However, all in all, this is the best science fiction film I have seen in a long time.

It is a good film, but too long. The story could have been told in 90 min. At nearly 2 1/2 hrs. it gets tedious. I am a bit baffled by all the "acclaim" the film has gotten, it really isn't THAT good. Of course I am a bit older, and I am comparing this to "Star Wars",  "Superman" (Chris Reeves version,) and "Close Encounters" so those are tough competitors.

The Martian fails to deliver the same level of suspense and humor of the novel.  Many of the "I'm going to die" moments are just suddenly and easily solved, as if surviving on Mars is no big deal.

I expect certain points to be cut from the Movie and adjusted for the format.  Using log entries to handle the narrative actually works rather well.  It's the pacing and basic choices in storytelling that don't really work.

My wife actually wanted to watch this movie after it won the Golden Globe for 'Best Motion Picture for a Comedy or Musical'

Comedy ? I was confused because I knew this film was about an Astronaut (Matt Damon) being stranded on Mars, and I couldn't help but think of the Movie Interstellar where Matt Damon also played a Astronaut stranded on a remote planet and in that movie he wasn't funny at all.

What was even more confusing was the movie is directed by Ridley Scott who's best known for Alien, Blade Runner, Gladiator, Hannibal Black Hawk Down and others which are all serious drama's or action flicks not Comedies.

The movie opens up with the astronauts on the surface of Mars doing their routine duties when a sudden storm arises causing them to scrub their mission and evacuate the planet to safety. During the evac, Matt Damon's character Mark Watney is missing, thought to be dead and left behind. As it turns out Watney is alive and begins focusing his efforts on how to stay alive for three years until the next scheduled Mars mission is due to arrive. 'In the face of overwhelming odds' Watey resides he's going to have to figure a way to grow food on a planet where noting grows.

The rest of the movie is basically Matt Damon alone on Mars trying to survive ... so where's the humor in that? Well as it turns out the writers Drew Goddard and Andy Weir do a masterful job of blending hard core science and humor into a screenplay which is not only entertaining and educational and very funny.

Matt Damon is brilliant in his portrayal of Mark Watney a highly intelligent astronaut with the perfect blend of wit and boyish charm which makes your instantly fall in love with his character and route for him to survive.

The Martian is nominated for 7 Academy Awards and has already won a Golden Globe for Best Picture (Comedy) and Matt Damon won the Golden Globe for Best Actor (Comedy).

My wife's not a sci-fi fan but she thoroughly enjoyed this movie and so did I.

Turns our the Golden Globes were right "The Martian" is the Best Motion Picture for a Comedy or Musical ... who knew?

I read the book, and then I read it again, and again.  As a cancer survivor, I could relate to the initial sense of futility, the realization that you are facing death.  And I also could relate to the decision not to die, and the fight to get through all of the horrors of staying alive.  I was "blown up"--not in an airlock, but by my first dose of chemotherapy.  I saw my own struggles and triumphs in the book. And it gave me hope, and a desire to face my fight with a little more humor.

I realize it's difficult to take book that approaches 400 pages and reduce it to a 2-hour film. There are parts of the book that are totally left out of the movie, and parts of the movie are not in the book.  I suppose that is what they call creative license.  I missed the missing parts, and I was not so crazy about the parts that were made up.  Still, I have watch the movie twice.  The uplift is the same.

But, it's still a good story, and Matt Damon is absolutely the right person to play this part.  In fact, as I read the book over and over, the voice I heard in my head could have been him.

If you loved the movie, but haven't read the book, I suggest you do so--not just for the comparison to the movie, but for the joy of reading a more in depth look into this incredible journey.

One of the better SCI FI flicks actually believeable

It is not a masterpiece but it is a good film though. One man abandoned on Mars because he was wounded in a strom and he was thought dead. Then the film is the discovery on Earth and on the spatial mission where the team that left him behind is that he is alive and then the decision to rescue him, on one hand. On the other hand that man, alone on Mars, takes care of his wound and then is playing Robinson Crusoe on the planet, inventing agriculture on Mars and solving all kinds of problems including communication with earth and with his team on their mission.

Of course such an adventure is highly improbable but the educational dimension is important. It wants to show that when death is in front of you, you can just accept it and find your peace with that, or you start working on and solving problems, one after the other, in order to survive as long as possible because there is always a chance that a rescue of some sort might come, or that you would be intelligent enough to survive by yourself with your own creativity and inventiveness.

It is also educational about the absurdity of different countries, here the USA and China, not working together and sure enough the film heavily suggests that they do and they actually do, which could have saved the marooned man and will have positive consequences on the future. Educational again with the position of women. The commander of the mission is a woman and she is not alone on the mission. At NASA it is less clear since all the main characters are men, particularly the director of NASA who appears as a cold, calculating man who does not accept any disobedience.

It is also educational with the team that has left one man on Mars. We are clearly told that no matter what the consequences may be one person as well as one team have to do what is ethically good, here rescue the man, and not obey orders going the other way. Mutiny is necessary when ethics are on your side. And sure enough they are shown as going on the next mission because the rescue is such an international global effort and success that no one can go into reprisals and penalties.

The Martian landscapes are beautiful though they are not Martian at all. The actors, at least the main actors, or even maybe the main actor in the singular, are good and the heroics are spectacular. Apart from that all the details are farfetched but one does not check a gift horse in the mouth. We let ourselves go into the action, the suspense (there is none since we know this poor Robinson Crusoe will be rescued just like Robinson Crusoe was because Robinson Crusoes always are, and that is pure entertainment.

I finished reading the book the same day as I watched this movie on DVD. I did this on purpose, so the story would be fresh in my memory. I totally agree with Kelsey. D (a previous reviewer), that there was just far too much left out in the film. The movie fails to capture the heart and soul of the story. The anguish, the strength, the struggle and the tenacity of the main character in the face of adversity.
The movie made it all look like a walk in the park, whereas the book had you chewing your nails from first page to last. And, yes!! What made them think that changing the ending would improve the story?

I read the book before seeing the movie, which always ruins the movie. But what was a spectacular book should have been a great movie.  The film omitted so much of Watney's witty personality and humor, how he dealt with his frustrations, worked through obstacles, and even the causes of some situations.  Brilliantly developed personalities such as Rich Purnell and Mindy Park were reduced to walk-ons, and events that would have endeared characters to the viewers  (such as the Tolkien reference, and the line "None of you ever got laid in High School, did you?") were not included.  Many really dramatic events from the book were significantly softened or completely left out.  The time Watney got blown up should have been dramatic and horrific, then heroic, then funny.  His electrocution was omitted, as was the rover roll-over accident.  And we rarely heard how much he hates potatoes.

I am more of an action movie guy. On those rare times I watch a movie with a great story line (as in slow but interesting) I might enjoy it but only watch it once. Most movies require stupid human decisions to create the obstacle to be overcome (which really annoys me). This one didnt. Sure, the science was not always right but it was still close enough to be believable if you didn't dwell on it. I don't know why this movie is so appealing to me (given it is the opposite of what I normally like) but my wife and I have already watched it 4 times and plan to view it more in the future. Just love this movie. And Matt Damon was just right for this part (human but not overacting). I think the subtle humor smoothed over the slow parts. Though not obvious at first those overhead long distance shots of the rover driving along really set the mood for how lonely and isolated he would have been.

Here is the deal: 5 starts because the movie is well made when it comes to graphics and for all the scenes, as well as the audio mix. Because I have to say, if you think it is impossible to survive a 12G launch inside a capsule with rocket boosters and just a tarp between your space suit and the elements, this movie isn't for you because that's exactly what Matt Damon did. The stretch of reality is just too much, the science is too flawed. They can get away with it  because they know the public-school attendee audience won't check anything and don't know any better. I think it would have made more sense if he would have been saved by an alien space ship and brought back to earth for the biggest close encounters of the 3rd kind that would make Spielberg blush. If you remove all the impossible things and don't mind that numbers 13 and 33 are brought up often and show up in several scenes, you'll have fun watching this.

The Martian is not the best scifi movie I ever saw, but it is reasonably faithful to the book for a change. Only a little tiresome with the manipulated tears. Funny how the tear ducts respond even when the brain is saying oh, come on now. I still think, as I did with the book, that the author was too much of a NASA and government fanboy. The stranded astroanut being of and being rescued by a private space company would have been much more interesting. There were sequences that demanded some NASA involvement but those could have been finessed. I also came away with less of a sense of the books story of one mans ingenuity in the face of impossible odds. The movie's stranded astronaut always seemed to be plugging in available hardware rather than devising unique ways around his problems. More of the focus, certainly more than in the book, was on NASA and its (in this case) babe or black scientists and their ingenuity in working out a rescue. The group, rather than the individual, was a cause for celebration. Typical of the leftist socialist worldview so prevalent in Hollywood.

This is one of the best movies I've seen in recent years. I've watched it three times and plan to watch it again and again. It is funny and moving and, in this time of turmoil and negativity in this election year, it makes you believe that people are good and decent and care about each other. I also love that it shows how people can use their intellect to better themselves and the world. I loved watching smart people work together for a common goal: saving one of their own.

This is actually one of the worst films I have ever tried to watch. I lasted about fifteen minutes before shutting it off. Here's the plot (I am guessing the ending).

Fabulously chatty people have a huge 'base' on Mars but one day while they're outside doing fabulous things (in their svelt Mars-Suits) a huge dust storm moves in and Matt Damon gets run-through by some thing or whatever. But meanwhile, his friends blast off for Earth without him and so he needs a general surgeon and a rocket real bad. But Matt manages to do his own surgery and soon he's making fabulous videos. But somehow he never manages to actually radio home. Anyway, that's where I left.

Mars' atmosphere is so thin that even the strongest 'wind' would be a puff. Yes, the planet has dust storm but again, their winds would push a daisy over much less a fat man like Matt. This is a movie for three-year-old kids.

One of the greatest Sci-fi directors of all time proves why he is one of the greatest Sci-fi directors of all time with this beautifully filmed and masterfully written tale of hope and survival.  What makes great science fiction is not the tech, story complexities, fantasy, or even the glimpses of unique and astounding possibilities; but an undeniable humanity that connects with the audiences' soul on both a collective and very personal level.  This is great science fiction.  Now, is the science part 100% accurate?  No, of course not; if that were the case, this story wouldn't even be possible.  But the inspired performances of Damon and his supporting cast and a well-crafted script eclipses any anomalies, no matter how glaring.  The subtle humor and genuineness of Matt's space castaway, mixed with stunning cinematography and dynamic action and effects, make this an instant classic in its genre.  I would have preferred a little less Disco, but it was a small price to pay to be thoroughly immersed in this amazing film. How many times are we going to have to rescue this guy...geesh!

A very well-done rendition of the book. Well cast, great locations, fabulous cinematography ... Everything about "The Martian" is excellent. Ahhh, but for one minor nitpicky casting problem ... one of the NASA characters is from one culture in the book and another in the film, while retaining the same name. A minor nit to pick but it is glaring. The transfer to disc is excellent, audio is excellent. Overall I recommend this to anyone who loves sci-fi. If you really want a treat pick up a copy of the audiobook - it's much better than the printed book or the movie because the narrator absolutely nails the character of Mark Watney perfectly and your imagination sets a stage that the movie never could.

The Martian was a film I feared might be quite boring and wondered if I would be kept interested throughout its length, but to its credit it was quite entertaining. Basically it's a remake of countless lone survivor stranded on a desert island movies that have been released over the years, just set this time on Mars. But the visuals are good, although maybe a little too good to be believable, we have the Hollywood style spaceships that are like houses with loungerooms, dining rooms, even a gym with plenty of equipment for just a small crew that is spaced out far apart. Even when he gets stranded he's got a big house sized lab to live in on Mars, not to mention there's tubs full of personal items and well a lot of stuff (if you're going to have a lot of non essential stuff why not have more food, just in case something like this happens? It would have been more plausible if his biggest shelter was the moon buggy truck thing and he had to survive in that.

But this is a work of fiction, and movies don't have to be believable or plausible to be enjoyable. The Martian is enjoyable. Spoilers are talked about in the following. If it was plausible for the original crew to rescue him, why was this not discussed as an option from the beginning when the ship would only have been however many weeks away from Mars before NASA discovered he might be alive. I had assumed there was only so much fuel and that the ship had already journeyed past the point of no return for a rescue which was why they didn't notify them he was still alive. I found it odd that no one in the media or through the media questions the likely trillions of dollars it would cost to rescue him, as surely hospitals, schools and everything else aren't rolling in cash in the future either. People already debate about spending millions looking for the Malaysian Airlines flight that disappeared, and we're talking trillions in this Mars rescue case. I could understand fast tracking the next mission straight away and landing on the same part of Mars instead wherever else they would have but I would think at least someone would debate spending that much money on saving the life of just one human who would have committed to the risk of death going in. They could have then shown his parents, family and friends pleading with the world to spend that money, as we don't even see them at all in the film.

Best Picture nomination?  Best Actor nomination?  Really?  WTF.  This is easily in the top 20 all time worst movies I have ever watched.

Matt Damon portrays Mark Watley, who was inadvertently left behind on Mars by his crew, because they thought he was dead.  The entire movie is about Watley's attempts to keep himself alive, and NASA's retrieval efforts.  This COULD have been a fantastic movie, but I never not once believed any of it, and that is what science fiction movies are about - getting you to believe that they are real and can happen.

Matt Damon probably did as good as he could with the script he had, but I never forgot for a moment that it was Matt Damon.  When an actor cannot get you to see past his star quality, it's a poor acting job.  Damon did a superior job of acting in Good Will Hunting, but was unable to make me believe that this astronaut was in serious trouble or that he was worth saving.  There was just no connection to his character.  The rest of the cast also did the best they could, but most looked very uncomfortable with their roles, i.e., Kristin Wiiig, and the dialogue was stilted and predictable.

The plot had more holes in it than a spaghetti colander.  I won't even go into the lack of science that went into some of their statements.  However, the amount of stuff that goes wrong with this guy is ridiculous.  It flat out would never have happened.  SPOILER AHEAD - Then there is China stepping in and giving up one of their major secrets to our space program to help us get Mark home.  Yeah, right.  I can tell you this - the rescue attempts for this guy were in the billions, and if you think for one moment that NASA and the US government would spend that kind of money on one man's rescue, I have beachfront property for you.  At the end, in Times Square, thousands of people watched CNN instead of watching it at home on their TVs.  The whole thing was ridiculous.  Then there were the awkward and stilted comedy scenes, which just fell flat.

I kept watching this movie because I kept thinking, "It was nominated for awards.  Surely it will get better".  Eh...no.  No, it never did.  In fact, as the movie went along, it went from a promising exciting movie to a dead bore.  There was one bright spot in this movie that I think I should mention.  There was a little known actor named Donald Glover there (no relation to Danny), which stole every scene he was in.  He was humorous and nerdy, and made me believe that he was just that crazy - other than him, I thought every other actor stunk the joint up.

Bottom line - Pass on this one or waste 2-1/2 hours of your life.

Have you ever watched a film that leaves you yearning for more in your life? Well, I know The Martian will do that to you if you decide to watch it. Why should you watch this intricate science fiction adventure film? First, I thought the film adaptation stayed true to the book of the same title authored by Andy Weir. Second, I could see how the entire cast came alive in the film due to their amazing relationships on the movie set and in real life. Third, I naturally gravitate towards film adaptations of novels that teach a life lesson. This film does that. Lastly, I think everyone should watch this epic science fiction film, but especially those who struggle with living from day to day because it will inspire you to change your life.

I'm somewhat divided on the merits of "The Martian".  As entertainment, it's smashing, particularly since it was directed by the master Ridley Scott ("Alien", "Blade Runner", "Gladiator", etc.) with fine acting by Matt Damon playing an American astronaut who survives a disastrous manned mission to Mars and must figure out a way to survive on Mars until he can be rescued.

I'm split on this film because in spite of the film's excellent production, it lacks much that could be considered either depth, ideas to ponder, or even resonance, things Scott's lesser films usually provide.  It actually resembles more of a lightweight pre-Schindler Spielberg film because it seems to settle into merely being a 'crowd pleaser,' much closer to "Rocky" than to "2001: A Space Odyssey", though many might think that preferable.  I also feel "The Martian" has weaknesses as drama: it seems astonishing that our astronaut appears to work things out too easily with little going wrong (until the final rather unlikely 'rescue'), and he never exhibits any emotional or psychological problems, something rather unrealistic as well as dramatically sophomoric. Frankly, it needed a harder edge, even toward the 'darkly realistic', and I can't understand why Scott didn't flesh this out in the script unless its production was, at some point, rushed.  Nevertheless, it is excellently made, a spectacular piece of movie entertainment that I thoroughly enjoyed, even if I didn't carry much away with me afterwards.

If you have been reading or hearing that the new Ultra HD technology is here to stay, you can still get a run from your money with this version. It has a superb audio and video presentation. Finally ..... an intelligent sci-fi movie based on skills and experience with science, technology, engineering and math! No Martians, no horrific aliens - but the very real nightmare of dying alone from hunger and thirst. This movie tells a completely engrossing story of ingenuity, skill and experience, combined with humor and an indomitable refusal to give up. If I were a teenager, this movie would have me thinking about a career in science and technology.

I enjoyed the book but there were passages I skipped because, to be honest, I don't care exactly how many ounces of manure it takes to grow a potato.  There were times when I thought the author was tying to prove the story was possible, but since it was fiction I didn't see the need.

I figured the movie would be better and it is.  The story gets right down to business and while there is talk about doing the math and solving problems, little time is spent on actual calculations.  For example, the "flight plan" for the rescue mission is worked out by plugging a laptop into a super computer and bingo, it's done.

The movie skips other details in the book as well, but it sails along nicely and Matt Damon is prefect for the role.  Great story telling.
