Loved this movie--no excess pyrotechnics, no eternally long scenes in complete darkness where you can't tell what's going on, profanity restricted to only the F word, and even that was used sparingly.  Loved the 'humanity', the humor, the acting and the heroic efforts by NASA, the JPL, and the astronauts to salvage a mission gone bad...with Science.---The cooperation with the Chinese space program was great.  I liked the 'reality' of Sean Bean's character, that even though he did what was 'right' to save the day, he was asked to tender his resignation because he challenged the director of NASA--politics still prevails where there is power, even in the movies.  :  (  Watched it twice back-to-back and still don't understand why Matt Damon, the writers, director and producers weren't nominated for more awards. Can't believe it was classified as a musical or comedy for the Golden Globes?  Really?  Great flic, with enough science and realism to keep us glued to our seats, and still laugh at the punch lines in the midst of peril.  So much more satisfying than Gravity.  Kudos to all involved with this production.

The "man alone" genre continues to fascinate. From Robinson Crusoe to the post- apocalyptic survivor to cast away Tom Hanks, it's all about ingenuity, courage and the struggle between hope and despair. The Martian is Matt Damon's contribution. When he is left behind by his crew, presumed dead, the struggle begins. Performing surgery on himself, rationing his food, using his skill as a botanist to plant potatoes fertilized with. . . Well, let me just say that he is relentlessly inventive. And that, for me, was the joy of this film. Science. It's ALL about the racing imagination of the scientific mind. If this film does not inspire awe for the men and women who build and calculate and  survive, I don't know what will! Damon is appealing, wryly assessing the successes and failures of his days as a Martian. The cinematography and editing are gorgeous. See it!

Almost 10,000 others have reviewed this sensational movie. I can't add too much but to say this....Matt Damon is GOD! this performance was one of his best and there are many that are spectacular. He did this part with pathos, humor and charm. His seems to be only part of the whole, we have his crewmen who accidentally left him behind and are planning a very dangerous way to go back and get him. The ground crews and NASA personnel are losing their minds to figure how to get him back. So all in all, we have three stories running simultaneously. Matt Damon is not the only performance of note either. Here we have one of those movies that has the right people in the right parts and they are all terrific. Amazing scenery and amazing acting and amazing writing and amazing direction all make for a nail biter. Are there slow times, sure but even they are amazing. Be aware though, the jargon and tech speak are just that very technical the very detailed. Matt Damon's humor is awesome.

I love Mars, and this film offers the gorgeous spectacle of the planet from the viewpoint of a man forced to live there---alone. Yet, this film really lifts the spirit. It's not a downer, but offers a positive perspective on survival in a hostile environment, using the STOP (Sit, think, observe, plan) principles of wilderness survival. You don't sit on the edge of your seat throughout. Mars comes to seem marginally hospitable, and certainly beautiful. This is a film about the human knack for making something out of nothing and returning to tell about it.

Where have we seen this before?

Astronaut isolated in perilous situation: check.

Astronaut engages in wisecracks despite peril: check.

Lots of Emmanueal Lubezki outer space scenes: check.

Daring space rescue with lots of spinning around and tethers and stuff: check.

Yes folks, what we have here is Gravity: Mars Edition.

I find it hard to believe that the director who gave us the film Gladiator is responsible for this.

It's a perfect demonstration of everything that's presently being done wrong in modern cinema. The actors all look like they're just pitching up on set to get paid, the emotion is completely and obviously insincere and plastic and the script appears to have been written by a team of sitcom writers.

In fact the script fundamentally compromises the potential seriousness of the story. You go for hardly a minute without a quip, a snark or some other forced humor that absolutely ensures that the film never ever goes beyond the superficial and touches on any genuine human emotions. It is possible to integrate humour into a serious story, but this requires pacing and placing the humour appropriately - if you put a laugh track over a serious scene, that scene won't feel serious.

At this point Matt Damon is also bordering on self parody. I felt like I was watching Matt Damon in a spacesuit, I don't even think I knew the astronaut's name at any point in the movie. This is almost identical to how Gravity presented us with George Clooney in a spacesuit playing every character he has ever played.

Hollywood is starting to get into a habit of churning out third rate, B-movie tier sci-fi and then hyping it up as something special. First Gravity, then Interstellar and now this. And the fact that the latter two were directed by very capable directors just adds insult to injury.

Don't expect anything at all of this movie and you won't be disappointed, but yet again it's just a forgettable piece of cinematic rubbish that panders to all the delusions of the current year.

One of the finest science fiction stories brought to screen. A few problems though. (Spoilers) Kristin Wiig's character claims confusion about the term "Council of Elrond" and seems befuddled by Tolkien references. For a film that prides itself of scientific accuracy, I find this dismaying. I defy you to find any white girl working NASA who does not know The Lord of the Rings backwards and forwards, own all the extended edition box sets, and harbor secret fantasies about one or more of the main characters. I'm not sure what Wiig is doing in this film in any case. Terribly miscast, sticking out like a sore thumb amongst better actors and cursed with a wardrobe seemingly made for another actress two sizes smaller and an ill conceived hairdo.

If you have to be stranded on Mars, it's good if you're a botanist.

Though Matt Damon pretty much holds the movie-goer's attention as the astronaut injured in a storm and mistakenly thought dead and thus left behind, the others in the cast stand out well as the people working to bring him home.  There's the usual concern with NASA's public image when it's discovered they "stranded" a man on Mars, problems with chain-of-command in such cases--and the time factor...the tension and stress of trying to build a ship in the short time frame left and get it there before his supplies run out.

Everything proceeds in a linear fashion and there's little overt danger, other than being on a planet where one has to supply his own breathing material and can freeze at night if he doesn't starve to death.  Ingenuity is the key word here, with the strandee despairing of his predicament then perking up and meeting whatever problem headlong.  Kind of a "Robinson Crusoe on Mars" except that in this case, "Friday" isn't one man but an entire team working in his behalf. Everyone simply sees the problem and gets to solving it. When they fail, it's "back to the drawing board" and they start over, all with the clock ticking ominously.  Some viewers may have an argument with that, wanting roaring monsters to come leaping out of the sand, or bloody confrontations of some kind or other. The dogged way the astronaut and those on the ground meets each challenge with no histrionics may cause a few protests from those who want heavy dramatics. Perhaps this is really the way a trip to Mars would be. A lot of hard, steady work with the victory almost anticlimactic. Who can say?

In any event, the martian scenery created is breathtaking in its sandy, deserted starkness of red and ochre hues,. The space shots are equally awe-inspiring.

Scott has been a great director at times.  He is no where near as bad as Michael Bay or Jar Jar Abrams. In the end it helps me solve my sleeping issues.  "The Martian" is not a horrible movie, it at least tries to entertain.

Really had me on the edge of my seat the whole time.  Matt Damon is great.  The political and administrative wrangling was not as strongly depicted as I'd like, but the cast was in generally good--I liked it that the "nerd" heroes in the story was minorities, too.  But Matt Damon took the crown.  it reminded me a bit of "Castaway", same situation but in a more unforgiving environment; I loved the "I'm not gonna die here" resolution and attitude of the hero, because that attitude is the most important thing in a survival situation---it's not the macho heroics that saves your skin, but the willingness to think your way through, adapt, improvise, and never giving up.  The ending was a bit contrived, I thought, but I guess they thought they needed to add one last element of suspense.  I'd still recommend it to anybody who'll listen.

If you think that this is "Castaway" on Mars, you are incorrect.  That is what I thought going in to it.  This movie is great!  It has humor, sarcasm, intense moments...it has it all.  I would highly recommend this movie.  The whole cast is good and Matt Damon is great!  Enjoy!

No seriously the book was great, and the movie was a pretty faithful adaptation. My biggest gripe was no mention of the lower gravity, but otherwise really good. Matt Damon is excellent, and re-reading the book imagining everything being said in his voice was in no way a bad thing.

The blu-ray is crisp, clean, and really well mastered.

And as with any other Ridley Scott movie, there's a boatload of viral marketing stuff that never makes its way into the movie and is delightful, like "meet the astronauts" videos supposedly produced by NASA, etc.

So I also live in Spain and mostly buy my movies on Blu-Ray. Have been looking at an option to purchase movies online in English without needing a VPN to pretend I am somewhere else. The Apple ecosystem seems like the best, but I hate the closed Apple Ecosystem. I am a Microsoft grunt, in the sense I have a Windows phone, Xbox, Windows 10 PC etc., but the Windows store also has this retarded only in Spanish system where movies are not available in their own original language. I just went to Google Play to check out the Google option and they too have a retarded system. I see what Paolo says about the content owners, but I do not give two hoots about the content owners. At the end of the day, it is Apple, Microsoft, Google or some other company which is licensing me the content. If they cannot be bothered to license me digital content with a plethora of language and subtitle options, well then I cannot be bothered to purchase the content. Either give me something which is a value proposition or shove it, and trust me there are plenty of other options for obtaining the content for free in the languages I want.

The companies involved, content producers and licensing re-sellers need to smarten up and improve their game or they will never attract customers like me. I have no problem paying for the content, but I will not buy or "license" a shoddy product which I cannot even view in its original language. NO NO NO. Wake up and smell the coffee that we live in a multi-language world where people are travelling and interacting with different cultures and languages more so than at any other time. E.g. I am British, living in Spain with a Brazilian girl friend. I want to watch stuff in English , she wants to watch stuff in Portuguese or at least with Portuguese or Spanish subtitles. The online options available from the three major companies are all pretty poor. Stop locking down language options, and make it easier for the customers to get the content they want and are willing to pay for. These language restrictions are dreamt up by retards at the content producers who have a scant understanding of the markets they are selling too.

Aside from that, the content producers currently have an oligopoly in place with the artificial licensing restrictions by country which stop us from playing our content whilst travelling etc., Again, this is a Kafkaesque system drawn up by idiots who have no understanding of what their customers actually want. The EU is slowly coming around to realising what these retards have put in place and there is talk of removing the license restrictions by country and creating a homogeneous EU zone. Bring it on. Then there will actually be proper competition in a more normal marketplace rather than the current artificial monstrosity which as users we currently suffer through.

Sadly, right now, Apple appears to have the "best" system in place for language optionality. Disappoint Google! Google and Android have the most open architecture and I would much rather have bought into the Google ecosystem for movies.

This movie is great and a good watch but personally I didn't "love it" because of the way it was written. It's really good but for me, when I think of Mars, it's done in fantasy and my picture of what/how/where things would go isn't the same as this movie. It actually makes me feel, if this movie is based in any reality what so ever, that we are VASTLY under funded for a trip to space, and we're leaving A LOT of trash where ever we go. Do we want to be know  as "THE LEAVES TRASH EVERYWHERE", civilization? And seriously? Burying radioactive waste on Mars because it's too hot to handle?? That ruined this movie for me. I think that if we are able to travel to other planets, then we should be able to manage our waste. After all, it's completely arrogant to think that there may not be intelligent life. We've slaughtered entire species here on our planet but then figured out that they are intelligent. Remember whales? We, at this time in evolution have only ONE VIEW and it galls me when I hear scientists come to an absolute opinion based on an experiment done on EARTH that supposedly duplicates somewhere else in the Universe. It is good however, on how this character manages to save himself on Mars with what was left over. Oh whatever. Great movie for .... not me.

Amazingly engaging movie. Start to end, you feel like you are actually watching over NASA's shoulder at one of their operations gone bad, that everybody is pitching in to fix. With no extraneous side-story, or any forced romance, it's a different kind of movie.
The only reason I took out a star, is that it doesnt have too much suspense, or sense of foreboding in it, which I (personally) feel is important in making the audience worry about the protagonist. In keeping the 'fat' out of the script, they also cut out some good old fashioned tension.
But trust me, the kids in your family won't agree- they get caught up in all that very fast. Please watch - it might spark an ambition for a tech career!

This film is okay.  I don't think Matt Damon will win an Oscar for best actor but he is someone whom everyone including myself admire, especially
for his Jason Bourne movies which should have won him an award.  This movie becomes quite intense in the last fifteen or twenty minutes during
the rescue attempt and I became edgy and nervous; a real nail-biter of a situation.  Other than that, Mr Damon's character seems little fazed being
stranded on Mars; he copes well enough and is ingenious at surviving.  No tension at all there, no desperation, no great worry, he just keeps calm and carries on.  If it were I, I'd die of fright, loneliness, horror, and despair.  But not, oh no NOT, Matt Damon.  What a guy!

Let me be clear, I ordered this from Amazon, it arrived on time and in perfect condition, so this is NOT an Amazon problem.

The problem is the movie itself. I'm a science fiction fan and I guess they were trying to make a movie based on a factual scenario and  what could really happen, so it's more true to real life than a "science fiction" movie.

But let's keep it real for a moment, there is no way the guy could live on potatoes for a year or more, much less a diet of 1/2 a potato a day. He would be in terrible condition from malnutrition and a host of other complications unless he had a ton of vitamins and other supplements to help him survive.  My opinion, he's be so weak from hunger (if he did last) he would be in no position to do all that work at the end of the movie.

As with lots of book-to-movie flips, many things were left out and / or altered in a way to expedite the storyline's pacing. Unfortunately, this means a lot of plot holes and critical character development flaws.

I urge anyone who hasn't read the book and only watched this movie to consider giving it a whirl. Mark is much more humorous and likeable, and the problems are much more interesting and complex. The film lacks the depth and drama and scope of emotion that the book really captures.

THE MARTIAN (2015) starring Matt Damon as  Mark Watney, a botanist-astronaut stranded alone on Mars, is an enjoyable tale of resourcefulness and survival, largely akin to such recent films as GRAVITY (2013), starring Sandra Bullock, and ALL IS LOST (2013), starring Robert Redford. The roots of THE MARTIAN, of course, go back to Defoe's famous novel ROBINSON CRUSOE (1719) and the nearly forgotten science-fiction film ROBINSON CRUSOE ON MARS (1964), which was also about an astronaut stranded on a lifeless planet who solves where to get oxygen, water, and food.

Many scenes in this film successfully heighten our admiration for Watney, and many others are genuinely touching, such as when Watney's fellow astronauts (who assumed he was dead when they left Mars during a violent hurricane) learn many months later he is still alive and decide unanimously to return to Mars and rescue him.

The two objections I have about the plot are both concerned with the events that set the whole story in motion. First, I'm highly skeptical about the possibility of hurricane-force winds on Mars, including winds strong enough to tip over a rocket ship: the atmosphere of Mars seems to be far too thin for such a thing. Second, during the hurricane Mark Watney is injured by a flying piece of antenna that pierces his space suit. After his companions have left and he becomes conscious, he pulls out two pieces of metal rods from his abdomen and then fishes around inside the hole and removes a bullet-sized piece of metal. If (as appears likely) even one of these three metal objects had penetrated his intestine, peritonitis would certainly have resulted, and without professionally done surgery Watney would have died within four or five days. (I know this from my own similar first-hand experience with peritonitis.)

Fortunately for this film and for the audience, these plot-holes occur early and tend to be forgotten as the much more important meat-&-potatoes (yes, literally potatoes) scenes of the plot unfold.

All in all, this film is much more scientifically credible and psychologically enjoyable than either GRAVITY and ALL IS LOST. If I were giving it a letter grade, this film would receive a solid "B+".

The Martian is a big-budget, near-future sci-fi flick, Matt Damon vehicle, with an easily recognizable supporting cast. Its built for box office, in other words, more than for credibility or contemplation. NASA has sent its third manned mission to Mars, which is expected to be on the Red Planet for 31 days. But the mission is cut short by a dust storm on the surface. Cdr. Lewis (Jessica Chastain) and several of the crew go outside the MAV during the storm, where botanist Mark Watney (Matt Damon) is stuck by broken antenna, lost, and presumed dead. The crew is forced to take off without him, as the MAV is listing from the wind, and they rendezvous with the Hermes in orbit, which will take them back to Earth. Watney wakes after the storm to find that the antenna punctured but sealed the hole  in his suit. He returns to the habitat module (Hab) to tend to his injuries and to figure out how to survive on Mars until the next manned mission arrives, four years down the road.

The beginning of The Martian gives the impression of a man-against-the-elements survival film that will test Matt Damons ability to keep an audience rapt for 2 hours mostly by talking to himself, reminiscent of Tom Hanks in Cast Away (2000) or Sandra Bullock in Gravity (2013). Once the folks back on Earth have figured out that he is alive, it becomes a more conventional race-against-the-clock action flick, hopping between Watney on Mars to NASA officials on Earth to the crew of the Ares III en route from Mars to Earth. Its entertaining but not as interesting as watching Watney adapt to life on Mars. Any number of articles in the press address the accuracy or inaccuracy of the science in The Martian. Its less accurate than Gravity. But the many errors in logic will be more glaring to the average viewer. Its unclear why the crew was outside the MAV during the storm. Dont even try to plot the passage of time by Sols (Mars days) with events, as it will not add up.

The film was adapted from the 2011 science fiction novel of the same name by Andy Weir. Ridley Scott directs. Filmmakers could have paid more attention to continuity errors. Science is always stretched in science fiction, and the closer the fiction is to our own time, the more those liberties strain credibility. But writing a script without obvious inconsistencies is doable, if you try. Delicate-looking, honey-voiced Jessica Chastain is cast as the mission commander in an attempt to feminize that character, as she was in Zero Dark Thirty (2012), but Cdr. Lewis lacks leadership ability and has a weak personality, very unlike a NASA mission commander. Cdr. Lewis and her pilot Maj. Rick Martinez (Michael Pena) are supposed to be military, unlike the rest of the crew, but their behavior and demeanor are anything but. This kind of thing strains credibility and grated on my nerves more than bad science. Mars was interesting, even when inaccurate. The rest was not.

I am not a rocket scientist.
Neither am I an astrophysicist.
I am, however, a storyteller. I spent nearly a half century as a journalist writing stories from across the United States and around the world. I've spent the past five years writing novels.
I note these things about myself because there may be scientists out there who find fault with this movie based upon their knowledge of the arcane. Because I am not one of those people, I can say without reservation that this is an excellent bit of storytelling with appealing characters, a well-constructed plot and a dynamic narrative. The special effects are nicely done without being overdone; there is not a weak link in the cast, and both the cinematography and the direction are flawless - at least to my untrained eye.
By now almost everyone knows that the movie - based upon Andy Weir's novel of the same name - revolves around a lone astronaut stranded upon Mars when his crew mates, believing him to be dead and in great peril themselves, leave the Red Planet without him. His effort to survive in that extremely harsh environment is a study in ingenuity and courage. Matt Damon, as the stranded astronaut, is wonderful in the part. He brings the right amount of wry humor, frustration, and hope to the role. In the parlance of an earlier time, he has the "right stuff" to survive.
But this is not just Matt Damon's movie.
Jeff Daniels, as the head of NASA, is also excellent as the administrator who must balance budgets and public relations with the realities of space travel. Sean Bean, Jessica Chastain and the rest of the cast perform admirably.
This movie is full of action but what makes it special, I think, is the story itself. On the surface, it's an adventure but beneath that surface lies a story that speaks of loyalty, friendship, and the fact that there are people willing to make great sacrifices to do the right thing. I especially like the scene in which the crew that abandoned Damon's character on Mars votes to put themselves and their careers at risk in order to retrieve him.
As I said, scientists may find fault with this movie.
As a storyteller, however, I cannot.

I can't figure out what all the fuss was about this movie.  Movies that interest me are ones that have several story lines running at the same time, lots of conflicts, and characters with flaws.  This was too simple.  Given all the press about this movies I was looking for more.

While this movie was 1000x better than Gravity, it's just another in the line of the dumbing down of the American populace.  Look, there are 4 kinds of sci-fi movies: one which is futuristic/fantasy, and you can give a pass to whatever kind of technologies they come up with, like Star Wars/Star Trek.  The 2nd is just the outrageous kind, who don't take themselves seriously, like Armageddon.  Armageddon laughs at itself, and we're all in on the joke.  It's just a fun movie.  The 3rd is more documentary, such as Apollo 13.  They try to stay really close to the truth.

The Martian is the fourth:  Fiction, but they pretend to be a serious movie.  I lump things such as 2001/2010 into that group.  However, the Martian is just God Awful at doing it.  If you're going to enter this genre, you better have your science down, and the Martian fails at 5th grade science.  While I can certainly give a pass on some things, like the sound of spaceships flying by (2001/2010 did this right) there are some things which cannot be overlooked (possible spoilers ahead):

Damon's character (a botanist, by the way) builds a water collection device, and it flames out in front of him, blowing him back.  Damon surmises that he didn't account for the excess *oxygen* he has exhaled since being there...  Yeah, he said Oxygen.

After the hatch blows out in his garden, he repairs it, with *plastic and duct tape*, even though they keep showing that the internal pressure of his living quarters is around 12 PSI. Oh, and the plastic flaps in the Martian wind.  Let's see, about a 4' wide hatch, at 12 psi.  Let see 1809 sq in.  or about 21 tons of pressure on the plastic.

When he's leaving, he has to get rid of a bunch of extra weight on his ship, including the 400kg nose cone, which he easily unbolts and pushes off.  Apparently Damon is superman.  Then he replaces the nose cone with this SuperPlastic(TM) that he repaired the hatch with.  WTF.

John Carter Oops Mark Watney (Matt Damon) is part of the team of astronauts on Mars. Due to unplanned high winds the mission is scrubbed. Unfortunately on their way back Mark gets what appears to be dispatched by flying debris and does not make it back to the ship.

Is Mark dead or alive?
If alive how could he possibly survives all the perils, including the trials and tribulations? Is it even possible to save them?
This movie will keep you on the edge of your seat.

I could not wait for the movie to hit the rentals so I went ahead and read the book first.

They did an excellent job of following the structure and feel of the book. Each scene was played out well enough that you didn't have to guess what they were doing.

 Including most of the potty mouth; this is not necessary and distracted from the movie with maybe one or two exceptions such as where he broadcasts a negative word throughout the world.

The acting was excellent the seams were spectacular Mars never looked more real. The technology was very close to real; you will not find yourself saying thats impossible.

Naturally being a movie though they dispensed with a few of the disasters; however because this is a disaster after disaster movie you won't notice the missing ones unless youve read the book.

I'm pretty sure my Very Good 4 stars out of 5 rating for the movie "The Martian" is less than it deserves. The problem is that I've read the book (The Martian: A Novel) and like almost every movie made since the beginning of time, there's no way a movie can hold a candle to its source book. Trying to step back from my prior knowledge, I'd say the movie is really well done: the acting and cinematography are all good and it stays very close to the book almost throughout. The big issue is that all that wonderful inner dialog (with the science, math, and humor) from the book is (by necessity) missing from the movie. Still, the movie is well worth watching. I do, however, recommend the book over the movie as there's a lot more depth to it.

Contrived.... that's the word that fits just about every gripe I have with this film in the time I wasted watching it.  The plot - predictable and contrived every step of the way.  Don't wait for a big surprise or mind-twist.  This film isn't about your mind.  It's about special effects and a contrived plot and contrived crises and contrived character interactions to facilitate those really good special effects.  The science is pretty much completely missing.  Every life-saving idea is based on marginal reality.  The final scenes are like a rush to the old-time idea box with new special effects toys to make them plausible.... and still it fails.  There's no way 90% of these crisis moments and solutions could EVER play out. The science is just that flawed.  One Badly strung together film!

Some may argue that it was unrealistic due to the humor Watney exhibited but I think this is exactly what helped him get through the ordeal. No matter what difficult tasks we may face in our lives or how bleak the outcome may seem if we can't maintain some degree of lightheartedness or humor then in our hearts we've already given up and we're as good as lost.  I'd like to believe that I would have reacted as Watney did in his situation.

Its been years since I've written an Amazon review, so this is a first for me in a long time. I'm writing because I honestly don't get what all the hoopla is with this movie.
I found the movie to be very techie in nature, and fast moving to a point that I was confused by who was who what was happening. I'm sure others were acutely tuned to the movie and their adrenaline was moving quickly as they were riding the writer's roller coaster scenes that kept moving so fast, only people keenly interested in that speed would enjoy.

Matt Damon is a very bright man with an exceptionally high IQ, so he pulled off the "Botanist" role convincingly, but I think this was way below his acting abilities. it was nothing like his role in Good Will Hunting with another very bright actor, Robin Williams.

I fell asleep towards the last third of the movie, and had to ask the wife what exactly took place and what was the Chinese role in all this. I confessed to her that while I was watching this movie, I kept wishing I could be watching a nice slow western movie without all the fast moving scenes that confused me with all the techie lingo.

 Finally, my suggestion to this production is, "you better get out of town by sundown pardner"!

An excellent movie, in the hard science tradition of "2001: A Space Odyssey".

Modern techniques made many of the weightless scenes much more convincing.  However, the recurring storms on "Mars" very very difficult to swallow; because of the thinness of the atmosphere, storms will contain very little energy.  Winds require particles actually colliding.  The particles of the Martian atmosphere will be hard put to propagate pressure waves, as required by a storm.  But, if one can suspend belief, it is a wonderful story.  The writing was very good throughout.

I had high hopes that this would be a great movie because of the subject matter. Instead it turned out to be one of the worst movies I ever saw. It actually looks like it was made awful on purpose. This movie, is solid gold as far as Space Adventures go. If your the type of person who like's to see your actors get eaten by aliens and mother nature poop on them, this is not the movie for you. IF you want to see an astronaut M.Watney take a poop on fate itself.. then this movie is for you! Mark Watney gets knocked down hard in this wild ride, but he gets back up and hits just as hard, and keeps a sense of humor the entire time, I secretly think Dead Pool is really Mark Watney. This isn't any fairy tell, but its one good sci-fi movie to watch! Why is it so good? It gives hope about the potential abilities of humanity to reach toward the stars. It shows we will probably get burned in the process. It shows, that we have to be prepared and think on our feet, because the frontier isn't a game. And pussy footing around will get us no where. I read the book first, and by read I mean devoured. The Martian So when the movie was gearing up to come out.. I was both excited and nervous. Because with Hollywood things either go, really good, or really bad. (The movie 'The Last Apprentice' based off these books Night of the Soul Stealer (The Last Apprentice, Book 3)) is horrid but poignant example. It's all down to earth is what I think is the big draw about this movie. The only thing I would say that is really "Out there" is basically the response time of bureaucracy agencies involved... they move way too fast. IF you want another awesome Space movie to watch after this, check out Interstellar The movie is a little bit of a stretch imagination wise.. and it starts off slow, but it really grabs hold of you and doesn't let go until the very end.

Like an after school special.  Only the action, dialogue, tension, are pacing not as good as in an after school special. This was a great opportunity to make an intelligent and compelling science/adventure film, maybe with a twist or two. But this plodding predictable non-spectacle (even the visuals weren't very good) was a huge disappointment. The ending alone was worthy of only the sappiest of directors. But this was made by Ridley Scott!  O, Ridley Scott,  I have loved you for your earlier visually compelling, beautiful, tightly bound, smart work.  I guess you get to fail occasionally too. And this was a notable and unforgiveably uninteresting failure. It could have been light years better.

As a frustrated "astronaut wannabe" it is difficult for me to find a space-themed flick that will make me want to watch it from beginning to end without rolling my eyes, getting antsy and start looking at my watch.  In the last forty years, only a few movies of such genre kept me interested: THE RIGHT STUFF was glorious.  MAROONED was right on the money and so was APOLLO 13.  CAPRICORN ONE'S premise was mind-blowing (regardless of OJ Simpson being in the cast). GRAVITY was pretty good.  ARMAGEDDON was kinda cheesy but fun to watch, so was SPACE CAMP (that one with extra cheese). The obscure STOWAWAY TO THE MOON was beyond cheesy but I loved it (I was 8 years old back then).  APOLLO 18? I walked out of the theater.

THE MARTIAN is a great exception and a very pleasant surprise.  To be honest, the first think I thought when I heard about the movie was "oh, please... not another movie about MY FAVORITE MARTIAN."  Thankfully, it isn't.

The premise is very credible and people can relate to it even if they have no interest in space travel. Think of Cast Away but 33 million miles away and with no food and no oxygen to last the year it would take NASA to get Matt Damon back (if it was Ben Affleck, I would insist they left him there).

The movie is beautifully shot, as could be expected from any Ridley Scott film. The script is smart and even funny in some parts (the movie actually won a Golden Globe as comedy..huh???).  The cast is simply outstanding, particularly Michael Pea (who you might remember from Oliver Stone's World Trade Center as the other cop who dug out from the rubble.  Visual effects were amazing and most importantly, CREDIBLE.

I hope you enjoy it as much as I did.
Great movie and Matt Demon was outstanding.  Definitely worth watching!

I'm sure other reviewers have identified major differences, but I found the lack of in-depth scientific explanations to be what I missed most.

I would recommend this as an entertaining and motivating film about human perseverance, definitely worthy of one or more viewings.  I would also recommend the book for anyone interested in more of the science from this science fiction.

3 stars for bringing a rather whimsical layered story to the screen with not too many cliche changes. Matt Damon's charm brings it one level up. Those cliche changes and inevitable sacrifices to the story keep it from reaching greatness. This is a very watchable and charming movie, well acted, well directed. However, this is a lesser, mainstream take on an original story. A lot of original book's off-beat charm and understated humor is lost, characters aren't as defined and diverse, and complexity of the situation is rather skimmed over. Some sacrifices are inevitable, in my opinion, this book is hard to turn into a movie, but the result is more of a glossy Hollywood mainstream dumbed down flick than a warm, charming, witty story of perseverance, hope and better human nature. Read a book, watch the movie. Both are worth the time, and the book definitely gives you a layer or two to chew through and enjoy it thoroughly.

We advance-ordered this Blu-ray DVD, and had an opportunity to screen it last night while taping the Grammys.  The first 30 to 40 minutes were fine, then the picture broke up with people looking like they were covered in foil and odd things moving across the screen.  After watching for a few minutes, we decided to start and reload the DVD - this cleared up the immediate scenes, and everything was fine for about 15 minutes when it happened again.  Reloaded again and moved on.  The end result was that it took 3 1/2 hours to see about 3/4 of the DVD in a very unsatisfying manner.

This is the first DVD we have ever purchased which is defective, and as a regular customer, I expected to have it replaced by Amazon.  However, we have just passed the 30-day replacement time and are stuck with a totally defective and unusable product.  Next time we purchase a DVD, it won't be from Amazon!!

Finally, a science fiction movie that isn't about violence and conquest, with all the effects devoted to killing and mutilation of one form or another. This is a superb movie: great acting, great script, great directing, and really great cinematography (along with the exceptional special effects). Matt Damon is at his best as a mature actor, and the story is compelling (thank you, Andy Weir).

I enjoy science fiction adventure, and got a few kicks out of the latest in the Star Wars franchise (although Disney's latest addition is more violent than the original ones), but I'd much rather see more stories and films like this one, where there is a hopeful outcome if people just work the problem. And that is the basic "message" of this film: that people can succeed in space in spite of horrendous odds against them, and that they should.

I also think NASA should send copious amounts of duct tape on any future manned mission to space.

Wow! The scope of this film is amazing and Damon does an excellent job journeying through a hero's saga. It's exciting, funny, poignant, thought provoking and deserves the accolades it has received. While it is 'sci-fi', you don't have to be a genre fan to enjoy the against-all-odds survival story. Well worth a watch.

Best movie I have seen in a long time.  This movie is the perfect mixture and balancing of NASA Aerospace mission-ology with a "down to earth" sense of humor that makes the characters approachable, like-able and most importantly doesn't make the movie appear like its' taking itself too seriously.  It is rich with suspense, great acting (particularly Matt Damon), great casting, incredible cinematography, heroics, love, loyalty and a strong, inspiring pitch for the coolness and bad-ass-ness of being really good at applying science.  I will be watching this movie whenever I need a worth while, meaningful movie fix.

Fairly solid and engaging, with excellent effects and acting, but there are two points that hold the movie back.  The first is its relatively simplistic plot.  It turned out nearly as I expected it would, given the commencement, and so I was not surprised by any development.  That said, originality cannot always be expected, granted.  Actually, perhaps I liked the recent "Interstellar" better, or even go back to 1999's "Contact". Nevertheless, this still a very good Sci-Fi.

The second negative is that there was poor use and understanding of the principles of physics, which is always in true science fiction, and to which this movie unquestionably aims.  This becomes increasingly evident as the movie goes on.  For instance, the spaceship Hermes: it had a cylindrical shell which was supposed to impart gravitational effects to the inhabitants thereof.  However, as it was designed, this would have proved impossible.

There was good use of 1970s disco ... !

I really enjoyed this movie BECAUSE I took the time to read the book first.  The book was great; I hated to put it down.  It provided so much detail on the "what, why, and how" of everything he did that knowing that made the movie considerably more meaningful than it would have been if I had not taken the time to read the book.  I definitely recommend the book -- then the movie, in that order.

Do not think twice about watching this movie. Just watch it. Matt Damon is beyond charming and impressive in his solo role. A role he is in for the majority of this movie. The plot line is simple. Survive. Without Damon's performance, that made you pull for the extremely likable botanist with a long sciencey to-do list, this movie would have been a long chore to watch. Similar examples are in other recent space tales Gravity and Interstellar. Both movies I would not rewatch. The Martian, I absolutely would. This movie will bog down in real science on occasion, but always makes it clear what it's discussing. Another impressive portion of this movie is dedicated to a lengthy list of notable actors in supporting roles. I will warn you that there is a decent runt time, but even at home, it will be worth the watch.
You forget you're actually watching a movie... Matt Damon at his best. The entire cast was remarkable! This is a must see!!

I have to say that I didn't think I was going to like this movie at all, because at first it started out so slow and was so boring that I wanted to turn it off.  But once the storm was over and Matt Damon's character (Mark) was left on the planet alone, this movie really took off and became really interesting!  It was full of drama and constantly had me gripping the armrests of my seat when things were happening and I was totally rooting for Mark to make things work and for him to make it off of Mars alive and back to Earth.

There aren't any space battles or aliens in it, and there isn't really any fighting in it other than verbal sparring between characters on Earth.  It really is a story about a man's will to survive and how he used his training and ingenuity to make his environment a place where he can survive in.

I really recommend this film to anyone who likes survival movies and who likes Matt Damon and stories about what the human race can accomplish when we all work together and put aside our petty differences.  Check it out!

Not all, but quite a few of Matt Damons' past roles are of a self aware actor who portrays a narcissistic character, "unlikable" at times, but  also "criminally intelligent". Examples include "The Bourne Legacy" series, Ocean 11 series, The Talented Mr. Ripley, Good Will Hunting, True Grit, Rounders & The Departed. I wonder if his life imitates his career.  I am a huge Sci Fi fan, but the idea of Matt Damon taking up space in this new genre, for him, made me think twice about renting this movie. Of course, The Martian, being a well received book, I decided to take a risk.  Matt Damon portrays an astronaut in Mars, part of a research team, who through a series of mishaps leave Damon stranded alone on Mars. He sets about acclimating to his environment & surroundings. He becomes very resourceful in utilizing sometimes personal and available resources to survive.... MacGyver style. I didn't feel compelled to cheer him on in the midst of his successful endeavors or have my heart strings tugged in moments of failure or despair. It seemed predictable at times as to the outcome  I give it 3 popcorn boxes, sans butter. Should have waited for HBO..

The Red Planet with Val Kilmer is about a group of astronauts who become stranded on Mars. Their only hope is to find an old Russian lander with a sample return rocket on it that just might allow one person to blast-off to their orbiting space craft. But it is miles from their site. During their marathon to get to the Russian rocket before their orbiting spacecraft must return to Earth, all die except Kilmer. And he does successfully blast-off. But Cary Moses has to got out on a long leash to fetch him and reel him back in.

Gee, all those elements are exactly what comprise this blatant copy, right up to the reeling in rescue part by another beautiful spacecraft. commander.

I wish I had more glowing things to say about this movie. I LOVED the book, but the film suffered from serious time management. There was more effort and time poured into altering the ending, and victimizing Mark Watney, than making him the hero he was in the book. I understand that so much internal monologue and science is difficult to portray, but there were so many options and opportunities to do so. Major parts of the book (such as the Pathfinder/drill and the hab airlock scene) are just glazed over. Everything is all too easy, and the depth and wry humor of Watney's character are completely lost. While it is scenic and does have a few really strong moments, the complete alteration of the last 20 minutes, make it a film I wish I never saw, and an insult to Andy Weir's great book.

Rented it last night after arm twisting. Was concerned about the PG13 but then read up that (aside from a naked butt) it was mostly language (an early round of "S--T" worthy of a South Park counter and a few f bombs which my son said went beyond the "13").  I told him if he was stranded on Mars, he could curse too but until then, no. This could've gotten a PG without that so I dinged a star. It's full of problem solving and resilience which were great lessons for my "six going on sixteen" year old who tried to follow along with his own ideas. Highly recommend.

EDITED TO ADD: Also, women and diverse characters in intellectual and pivotal roles (shame that this is still rare enough to have to highlight).

I went into this movie thinking this was a clone of the Sandra Bullock Gravity movie and to a certain extent it does have some similarities but to my surprise this does have an entertaining story that has some unique elements as well.  The story has a nice blend of action and suspense and mixes in some humor to elevate some the tension within the movie.  The humor that is in the movie is light and really doesnt take away from the sci-fi dramatic action that is the movies focus.  The Mars landscape is bleak but beautifully done and looks realistic giving the feeling of loneliness and desolation.  The special effects both on Mars and in space are also nicely done.  The story seems to be based in science which gives it a plausible feel; although at times I am sure the science is bent a bit at times to match the drama of the story and the ending has a been there done that kind of feeling to it.  Matt Damon is one of my favorite actors and he does a good job in the role with both his blend of humor and ability to make the character likeable.  Although the story isn't perfect, this sci-fi movie has a good blend of action, tension, humor that is entertaining and worth watching.

I was very surprised at how much I enjoyed this film! I don't believe in spoilers, yet this movie has been out long enough for anyone reading reviews about it will pretty much figure out the plot and the juicy parts of it. I will, however, say I really hate how film directors re-generate the "generational" bridge as if movie audiences haven't advanced in their expectations of movie soundtracks.

Every song that Matt Damon's character (Mark Watney) listened to while on Mars (heck, he was even watching Happy Days for crying out loud!!!) spawned the time period of the 60's - 70's. I cannot believe that Ridley honestly believes people are supposed to buy that every American or moviegoer is listening to disco or oldies during a time when America should be progressive in terms of entertainment choice, not always reliving the "good ol' days" during space exploration. It's ironic that seems to always occur in films about the future lately. Albeit, this was Commander Lewis' music collection, but movies sure have a way of shoving the iconic fabric down your throat I got mildly irritated at hearing the soundtrack in this film.

With that said, Matt Damon makes this film go!!! I've always liked his movies, though, as of late, he hasn't put out many powerhouses (not his fault, if you ask me) but he redeems himself with this one. It captures the spirit of determination, exploration, science (get your STEM game up people!) and hope as well as some natural human emotion that shows how hard it can be at times to just hold on to hope even when there's little left.

He made you a believer in him and that's why he's my hero!

Movie Review

 If you are into sci-fi movies, dramas, or comedies then the movie The Martian may be for you. This movie has an intense storyline that will make you want to root for Matt Damons character and ensures that youll have laughs along the way. I had seen previews for this movie before buying the DVD thinking that it looked like an alright movie, but it far exceeded those expectations. I am not typically one to love sci-fi movies, but The Martian was so well-done that I couldn't help but love it. This movie is about a man, Mark Watney, who gets accidentally left behind on Mars during a crazy storm and who now has to survive. I don't want to give anything else away about the movie so it is ruined.
 The cast was excellent. The obvious big name actor was Matt Damon who portrayed Mark Watney perfectly by being the kind of guy that everyone enjoys with a good sense of humor. There were a few other actors and actresses that I recognized from other movies I had seen before, but could not remember their names. Overall, the movie had a stellar cast with great acting as well as awesome directing done by Ridley Scott.

Blue-ray DVD Qualities and Features

 Buying the movie on blue-ray DVD couldn't have been a better decision. It gives the option to watch the movie in 3-D. Watching the movie in 3-D was like a whole new experience, which you do not want to miss out on. With explosions and journeys around mars you feel like you are right there with Mark Watney due to the amazing effects and features. The film is fairly long clocking in at 144 minutes in length. Though some people may feel that a movie that is almost two and a half hours long is not what they are looking for, I can assure that it is well worth watching the entire way through and that it will keep your attention. If anything the lengthy movie just means that you are getting more for your buck. Buying the DVD is great because you get to see the special features along with receiving an excellent picture and great sound due to the Blue-Ray DVD enhancements. When ordering The Martian off of Amazon I received it right when the delivery date claimed it would be delivered and it showed up in great condition. I would most definitely recommend ordering a DVD from Amazon and consider it to be well worth the $14.99 price I paid for it.

Only because it was believable, that he would do the stuff that he did to survive while NASA bungled everything and proved over and over that it is any wonder that we have gotten anything up in space.

Great movie! Saw it in the theaters and had to own it!

So perfect, NASA decided to hold information about finding RUNNING WATER ON THE SURFACE OF MARS until 3 days before the movie premiere in order to give it as much of a boost as they possibly could. Director Ridley Scott has gone on record saying that he was aware of the finding a full 2 months before it was revealed to the world, but it was too late to incorporate it into the movie. NASA wanted this movie as much as the studio. Thank goodness it is as good as it needed to be to get people talking about Mars again. Matt Damon is at his best and the visuals are among the best of any Sci Fi movie ever made. 5 stars with an exclamation point.
This was everything you want in a movie.  The plot was thrilling, the acting great, and it might (we can hope!) inspire kids to go into the sciences!

I had heard both the good and bad reviews about this movie, but I'm one of those people that needs to make a personal assessment. I ended up renting this movie before ordering it, as I do with most movies I purchase. I will say this, it will do you wonders if you decide to watch this movie without any expectations and blindly.

I wasn't really sure about the whole story line and decided not to get too many details about the movie prior to watching it. Therefore, I will not reveal anything of the movie, so that you can make up your own mind.

I will say this, I thoroughly enjoyed the movie and I'm a pretty picky guy when it comes to them. I love drama and action along with some comedy and this movie has all of them. Matt Damon does a spectacular job in this film and the storyline, for the most part, is not drawn out or boring. There was only one drawn out scene and if it wasn't so intense, I would've been bored. Instead, it was just a bit hard to watch for a couple of minutes.

Overall, a great movie that will have you laughing. No, this is not the Wedding Ringer or Aliens. However, if you're a fairly smart person, love suspense and not too over the top comedy, then this is the movie for you.
I love this movie!!!!!

This is most definitely a Science Fiction, not Science Fantasy, movie.  A rare thing indeed.  I have this on 3D Blu-ray and with only a few exceptions, the 3D was very good to excellent and the movie itself was outstanding.

For anybody planning on getting the disk, I recommend watching two of the DVD extras *before* the movie itself:

  - "Ares III: Our Greatest Adventure"
  - "Ares III: Farewell"

No spoilers and they both help set some valuable background information about the plot.  These short bits really should have been part of the beginning of the movie, but the director opted for getting into the action as soon as possible.

This is a 3D movie I will definitely watch more than once.

This "feature film", or colossal waste of time and money, is pure nonsense. Everything in this film is a complete and utter fantasy - but that's the point right ? It might shock people to know that everything to do with space, space travel, the solar system and the so-called "ball earth" we live in is a massive deception. One so comprehensively deep that when confronted with the facts (and there are many) one will still go into denial immediately.

This garbage is just further kool-aid for the masses to keep them drunk with stupidity. If they actually used the five senses that god gave them and engaged their brain without being distracted by mindless twitter posts then perhaps they will see a glimpse of the real truth.

Reality is not what we think it is. It's much simpler and more wondrous than anything Mr Riddle-Diddle Scott can produce from his pea-brained mind.

Whether you are a sci-fi fan or not, this movie is well-acted, has a coherent and (mostly) believable plot, and has nice cinematography. This is the only sci-fi movie that I would give 5 stars. The performances are pretty darn good. Very enjoyable movie. Parents be warned: movie contains some vulgar language, a couple of intense scenes, some blood, and 2-3 seconds of backside nudity.

You don't have to be a NASA or JPL junkie to enjoy this movie.  It's a great man vs nature story.  Matt Damon is excellent as always, performing as a solo character for much of the story.  The other cast are stellar as well, led by Jeff Daniels back on Earth keeping control of the team as each development arises.

I've seen it in both 2D and 3D, and I really have to recommend the 3D version.  The rendition of Mars is stunningly beautiful.  You'll watch it more than once.

This movie feels like it was a "What If " type of scenario or task that was given to a bunch of N.A.S.A scientist and a select group of survivalist who were asked to figure out how a group or one Astronaut could survive on Mars or other planets if they were marooned or their Lift Off vehicle failed.
I cannot go into the movie in detail because I do not want to ruin it for those of you who may want to watch it, but I will tell you this,  Matt Damon does a very good job of coming up with solutions on how to survive for 10+ months until help can arrive and pulls some real Inspector Gadget type moves to supplement his food and water supply and ingenious ways to reestablish contact with N.A.S.A back on earth.

Ill be honest, I had not heard much about THE MARTIAN before renting it. I expected it to be another boring Martian mission movie ala RED PLANET. But this movie was nothing like that dud. My first clue was that the film was produced and directed by Ridley Scott, and frankly, I don't believe the man has ever made a bad movie. Second clue should have been that it stared Matt Damon, and frankly, I don't think he has ever stared in a bad movie either. It contains stunning FX, drama, intrigue and suspense, all of which would have made it a good movie. But what makes this a GREAT movie is the element of human perseverance. This almost plays out as a true story, and indeed, it does have elements of the true story of Apollo 13. The movie shows human integrity, intuition, bravery, adaptability, strength, compassion, ingenuity and loyalty. And, like the story of Apollo 13, those human attributes and a whole lot of duct tape can always save the day. Im almost glad that I didn't see it in a theater because Id have embarrassed myself by applauding out loud at the ending. An outstanding film, and an outstanding story. I loved it!

The movie was highly entertaining and had me pulling for the main character. Would have given it 5 stars, but there were spots where the suspension of disbelief were just too much. Overall a feel good movie that felt just right.

Hearing the premise for the Martian, I thought to myself "abandoned on Mars? that sounds so depressing". I was wrong. There are many artful moments of levity. Rescuing Matt Damon again turns out to be a worthwhile endeavor. Great acting by a populous cast (no, you will not be watching poor sad Matt Damon all by his onesies on Mars for 2 hrs), beautiful effects, I guess it'd get the 5th star in my book if it got just a little more bleak sometimes. There is a relentless optimistic outlook, and I'd think there'd at  least be a few times when the main character would mentally collapse and give up. (I realize this would be in opposition of the major theme here, but overcoming an onset of hopelessness would only add to the power of a man determined to survive. Arguably)

The film follows a NASA astronaut and his determined quest for survival while stranded on Mars. Matt Damon does an amazing job bringing his character to life while the film itself makes the viewer believe that this is really the red planet and not a Hollywood soundstage. NASA's efforts to save their stranded man is also believable and gives much deserved credit to the NASA personnel left behind on Earth and their role in NASA's success. The ultimate solution to the problem has some nice surprises and twists and the film's ending leaves the audience satisfied.

The science used in the film is as accurate as a movie can hope to get making this movie not just for popcorn movie audiences but for scientists and NASA supporters alike. 'The Martian' will inspire its audience and will hopefully remind the nation why NASA is worth the investment.
Damon is more than convincing as the stranded botanist on the Red Planet. Real science nuggets in this not so distant in the future treat.

A real fun movie that at times leaves you on the edge of your seat. No alien creatures in this movie, just humans in a movie story of human ingenuity, willpower, and heroism. Matt Damon delivers a very strong performance. You can feel his emotions as they rollercoaster from highs to lows throughout the film. This film is a sci fi drama with some appropriate humor interjected along the way. A good family flick. No overt sexuality or gratuitous foul language. Only one brief shot of rear view full body nudity; used to illustrate the extreme weight loss of the stranded astronaut. Highly recommend this movie if you're looking for a fun, inspirational, and sometimes edge of your seat movie.

I found this book very compelling.  It was difficult to put down.  I was so invested in the story that it actually got my heart pounding with excitement!  I loved this book.  You could tell that the author really did his research to be sure what he wrote was accurate.  That is a huge testament to the author.  He really did a great job on that respect. However, there are a few things that make me give it 4 stars instead of 5.

Reason 1, the characters on Earth, really didn't seem to make much sense.  Their reactions to things seems over the top.  It felt very much like a script, which is probably why the film did so well.  I am sure that the characters on Earth had a connection to the ones in space, but we as readers don't have that mutual compassion so it felt very unnatural.  I often sped read those sections because it just did not seem like a normal human response.

Reason 2, the book just ended.  He gets rescued and then it just ended.  There was nothing afterwards.  We as readers need something to finish on.  Just because the climax is over does not mean that the entire story is over.  We need closure.  This is the main reason why I didn't give the book 5 stars, because the author didn't follow all the laws of writing.

At least he didn't kill the guy. ;)

I wasn't expecting too much when I rented this movie last night, and I was pleasantly surprised at how good of a movie, The Martian, is. First off, it has an excellent cast (Matt Damon, Jeff Daniels, Kristin Wiig, Kate Mara, etc.). Amazing! Not entirely scientifically accurate, but highly enjoyable!
Excellent movie!

The Good:

Matt Damon's character is charming, witty, and funny. His character always managed to pick the movie up in a very light-hearted, and often times humorous way. There was also a great combination of supporting actors that each contributed in their own way into the movie. (So don't worry, you won't be stuck watching only Matt Damon for almost 2.5 hours straight.) You get some solid performances from Jeff Daniels, Chiwetel Ejiofor, Michael Pea (funny yet again), Jessica Chastain and so many others in the supporting cast. It interesting and enjoyable to see how the movie almost seemed like two different movies in one. The first being Matt Damon's experiences on Mars, and the other being the rest of the characters on earth attempting to bring him home. The film also did a good job of bringing a level of science that would appease die hard sci-fi fans, but still make things relatable for the average person.

The Bad:

There are some times when this film can get a little too "sciencey". There were times where I found myself getting lost in the detailed, technical explanations during some of the scenes. (Luckily they had visual demonstrations to help it all make sense.) In a strange way, this movie never really hit any highs or lows. It's not a boring movie at all, but the suspenseful moments weren't going to get you on the edge of your seat, nor were the sad moments going to have you watery-eyed.

The Reason:

The best way to describe this movie is Castaway + Gravity (Click for my previous review). If you were thinking that this movie was just a copy of Interstellar, I can tell you now, it's definitely not that. (However, there is one scene that is ridiculously similar to a scene in Interstellar.) While Interstellar was similar to sitting in on a 3 hour university lecture on quantum physics, The Martian is like your high school science class with that cool teacher who made science fun. Overall, The Martian is a scientific adventure that will give you a warm fuzzy feeling inside. It will be shown in 3D, and there are two scenes in the beginning and the end that I do feel make the 3D worthwhile. I think it's more than worth the watch in theaters.

The Rating: 8.0/10
For more of my reviews, please visit:  EmansMovieReviews .com

Perhaps all of the good reviews came from martians because this movie stunk as badly as the human excrement Damon used to plant his potatoes. The directing was so horribly contrived as though Ridley Scott thought he was playing to an audience of 6 year olds. Clearly Ridley Scott knows nothing about the science of space. And the gym on the space craft? What an absolute joke. Has Ridley Scott watched the YouTube videos of actual astronauts exercising in space? Totally predictable, unrealistic and over done Hollywood rubbish. I wish I could get those 2 hours 24 minutes of my life back. Awful.

If this were a 7 star scale, I'd give it a 6, but alas we only get 5 stars, and it's not so great to get the grand slam. So as a sci-fi fan I'd say the movie does a good job of keeping it real while allowing some wiggle room for suspension-of-disbelief. It really does try to stay within reason, and any of the questionable things are trivial that only folks like Neil Degras Tyson would bother to mention, and even he would probably enjoy the film... because he is able to get past that crap, and so should you.... It's a great film, and it's pretty decent in the 3D version that I ordered. The stereoscopic effect was not too pronounced, actually quite conservative, which is nice. The effects "popped" at the right times, and never did I have to stop and be cognizant that 3D glasses are being worn, so just enjoy the feature film. Matt Damon is of course playing the role quite well, and honestly it would be hard to screw up, but it's nice to have an A actor to watch. Lets be honest here the acting is either not a big deal here for the plot, or the acting was SO good I was tricked into thinking that way. Well, regardless the movie deserves some major respect towards the special effects, this stuff really helped carry the film, along with great writing.  Wold I watch it again, yeah... maybe once or twice in my life time.

As a fan of the book the movie sucks to the point of zero stars.  They gutted the book completely.  I laughed all the  way through the book and love the characters jokes and humor.  Almost all of that is gone from the movie and the few jokes they did try to put in were done in a way that didn't translate well.  There is no humor or laughter in this movie. There are always places in book to movie adaptions that things need to be changed to accommodate the medium but this changes parts of the book included dialogue that just has no reason to be changed.  Their creative editing of the plot introduces so many plot holes and things that just do not make sense.

If space travel fascinates you and you are a huge Matt Damon fan, you may appreciate this movie more than I did.  The premise of the story is very interesting.  Sort of a Cast Away with technology story.  Although Matt Damon's performance is pretty good, it's definitely not one of his best.  So many of the group scenes felt contrived and cliche.  Matt Damon's character is pretty one dimensional although there were some good scenes.  I think I would have enjoyed it more if they would have developed even one character or relationship a little further.  It was just a lot of one liners and scenes of the actors being weightless.  Then back to the corporate NASA conversations where tough business people almost argue.  Kind of like fifth grade show and tell, choppy, and nothing special overall.

Sometimes I gauge a movie by how much I enjoy it and how much my 14 year old son enjoys it as well. This was one of those rare movies that I thoroughly enjoyed and saw my son thoroughly engaged in. He didn't just laugh at the jokes, he was genuinely interested in what was going to happen next, as well as wanting to know why he did something. I was entertained and my teenage son was engrossed. So I find this an excellent movie especially for families to watch together. This is rare these days outside of ridiculous action and comic book movies.

After reading the book by Andy Weir, I knew the movie had some big shoes to fill and didn't have very high expectations, but was ultimately pleasantly surprised. I read the book a year before the movie's release was announced, and can say with 100% confidence that it's the best sci-fi book I've ever read. The movie follows the book VERY closely, but for obvious time constraints, wasn't able to go into the depth of detail that the book has. That was probably my only disappointment with the content.

I enjoyed the fact that the film essentially takes place place in present day, there's not really anything that would be a stretch of the imagination.

One of my only cinematic disappointments was how unrealistic the zero gravity looked on the Hermes.

Martian is a great story and the film is entertaining.  It deserves all the kudos it has received.  Really, I can't point to a specific weakness.  It is an unusually good intersection between studio profit motive and skilled artists. I only hold a star back because of the general sense I felt about the emotional distance between myself and the stranded astronaut Whatney.  The movie had plenty of opportunity to explore and share his personality, fear, pain, loneliness, sense of hopelessness, etc., but "The Martian" generally passed this up.  They should have watched "Castaway" for a few ideas.  Greater insight into the emotional reality for the main character in the screenplay would have really helped. The book is written in diary form, so perhaps this discouraged the filmmakers from going too deep into feelings.  Very good picture despite this.

As far as space movies go - and I've seen a lot of space movies - "The Martian" isn't terrible. It's not blow-the-doors-off fantastic either, but in the final analysis it's entertaining enough. The movie that, to me, this is closest to is "Marooned, which despite its slow pacing gives a very real sense of peril for the three men languishing aboard an Apollo spacecraft in Earth orbit with a balky main engine and a hurricane standing between them and rescue. All the science notwithstanding, one thing stood out to me from the jump. Jeff Daniels's character was referred to as the director of NASA in the caption for his character. In real life, NASA is led by an administrator, not a director. To me, that's an elementary piece of information that shouldn't have been botched. Frankly, no matter what the caption said, I didn't care for Jeff Daniels's character at all. Unlike Gregory Peck, who played the head of the space program in "Marooned" with a maddeningly effective emotional detachment as the program is utmost in his mind, Daniels comes across as a pompous windbag who seems more concerned about his image. I normally like Jeff Daniels, but not here. At least Matt Damon was given something to do in this movie, and he actually does it fairly well. Instead of chewing scenery in an orbiting spacecraft, with absolutely nothing else to do but talk, he does so in making sure he has something to eat and can communicate with Earth. Damon is funny in spots, but there is a sense of serious behind his character. You know he wants to survive and is doing everything he can to make that happen. So it was hard for me not to root for him. Overall, "The Martian" is decent for what it is. Definitely not what I'd consider fodder for major awards, but a decent change of pace for a rainy afternoon.

Since this is generally set in the real-world near future, I found all the Hail Mary, last second decisions that "just might work" unbelievable. There were too many scenarios that had to just right for this rescue to succeed to be plausible. Plus, how many billions of dollars were spent to save this one man? I could not help but wonder how many thousands more people could have been saved from starving or disease on Earth with those kinds of resources. Anyway, it was still an ok space movie, and most people like it more than me, so I think this is a safe bet for an enjoyable movie.

Ok, so I read the book first and then saw the movie.  It was amazing how wonderful the special effects were and how closely they followed the book.  There was only one incident, when Watney (Matt Damon) is on his way to the ascent vehicle and has to change his route because of another dust storm (the Rover overturns), that wasn't included in the film.  Thankfully, however, they also didn't include as much of the scientific hyperbole that almost ruins the book.  There really is so much of it that it's like the author (Andy Weir) is trying to make us believe the story.  I almost put the book down because of it but glad I didn't.  Yes, a really fantastic movie--and A- on the book.

This is an exciting and enjoyable movie which strongly held my attention from start to finish. I couldn't help but get emotionally involved, especially when things went well despite the dangers involved. It even provided some joyful feelings and great laughs at times. It helped, also, to know ahead of time that Matt Damon's character, Mark Watney, would survive despite almost impossible obstacles. The one distraction and, for me, a chief fault with an otherwise really good movie was the unnecessary prevalence of foul language. Why Hollywood writers, directors and producers still seem to feel that filthy language is desirable and tolerable to a decent public is an indication of their blindness, in my opinion, to what customers really want in the quality of movies. Interesting that the previews and trailers designed to draw interest in such movies seem invariably to leave out the foul language later encountered when the full movie is viewed.

Spoiler-less review:

Fun movie!  It stays true to the spirit of the book, with some deviations to allow for the difference in medium.  After all, a lot of the book is Mark's internal dialog, which doesn't make for exciting visuals.  The alterations in the storyline don't really detract from the movie, though if you've read the book you'll notice the differences.  The book is a must-read just for the enjoyment of it, but it is not necessary to read the book to enjoy the movie.  The extras that come on the Blu-Ray are nice though most of them were released as promos on YouTube during the run-up to the movie. The bonus short "Ares III: Refocused" is not one of them, and is probably the best of the bunch.

This movie is awesome, despite not having any actual martians in it. It is the second movie in the Bourne's Eleven Trilogy, coming between Interstellar and Elysium.  I highly recommend this to any fan of Matt Damon, Leonardo Dicaprio, or The Oscars.  The soundtrack also rocks, containing hits from artists like Abba, David Bowie, and Gloria Gaynor.  I'm pretty sure, David Bowie isn't actually dead, and just decided to stay on Mars after he performed "Starman" there.

A well done movie!  The story was believable and filming and action parts were exciting. The science behind the movie was less authentic.  For example, the Martian gravity is 1/3 of that on Earth.  However, no attempt was made to show how this lower gravity would affect walking on Mars, and in lifting heavy objects.  Also, destructive storms on Mars didn't make sense.  We know that the Martian atmosphere is mostly made of carbon dioxide and that the average Martian atmospheric pressure is under 0.09 psi - compared to 14.7 psi on Earth (169 times less pressure).

Aside from the science, the movie was entertaining.  Acting was good - especially by Matt Damon who carried the movie.  There were some humorous moments to keep the movie from becoming boring and monotonous.  Overall, a good job!!
Good plot, good acting.  The drama makes a farce out of the science/believability towars the end, but he, that's what makes it fun to watch.

Great premise for a movie but the story and execution went from good to okay to awful. A few lame "music video" segments put in for filler were partially responsible for the spoilage of this movie. It was like they thought, "This plot is stalled, let's throw in having a guy do mundane chores to music!" Jeez. I'm not a scientist and maybe I'm wrong, but while the initial problems/technical solutions seemed at least in the realm of possibility, the last half hour and particularly the climatic scene, were nothing short of ludicrous. The most wild-eyed science fiction wouldn't come up with that solution to the final problem - because there is no way in the world (or Mars) that it would not result in a dead astronaut. Add in a hackey "world celebrates" scene to end it and you have a movie that went off the tracks about an hour in and never got back on.
Not nearly as in depth as the book when it came to the science but that is understandable.  Very entertaining.

Excellent, but I reserve 5 stars for what I believe is a classic, such as Casablanca.  Good performances all round.  Although much of the time, it's Matt Damon alone on Mars, it still held my attention.  The obvious comparison is Tom Hanks in Castaway.  Although I believe Mr. Hanks gave an equally good performance, because the vast majority of that film concentrated on Mr. Hanks alone on an island, I believe its plot suffered.  One person on an island can only go so far in making an intriguing story.  On the other hand, the Martian periodically cut back to earth for the discovery that Mr. Damon was alive and then to periodically discuss efforts to rescue him.  Consequently, a good pace seemed to be maintained throughout the movie.  Cinematography and special effects were very good and added to the movie rather than seeming to try and take over the movie.  Too many science fiction movies seem to be just vehicles for the special effects.  For "The Martian" this is not the case.  Definitely worth seeing.
