I have to say, right off the bat, that to me, the movie The Martian is the best science fiction movie that I have ever seen. Of course, the lovers of the flashing ray-gun kind of movie would undoubtedly vigorously disagree with me  but hey, thats life!
In my humble opinion, the movie put the SCIENCE into movie science fiction. The only bit of creative license that I saw was the cataclysmic force of the Martian dust storm. While the wind velocities of Martian storms can be quite high, the extremely thin Martian atmosphere (less than 1% of Earths sea-level air pressure) would not be able to transmit much force.
Im OK with that much creative license since, without it, there wouldnt have been a story  at least not the same story.
I liked the realism of the movie. All of the equipment, from the spacesuits to the rover to the Hab to the Hermes cycler spaceship were very well crafted and very credible. The characters were believable, as well. I particular liked the Mark Watney character, who, when he began to realize the magnitude of the fix he was in, says to his video log, Im going to have to science the sh*t out of this. Which he proceeds to do!
*****SPOILER ALERT*****
For me, the most poignant moment, in both the book and the movie, was when Mission Commander Lewis realizes that one of her people has been stranded on Mars.
I left him behind, she says.
The crew tries to make their forced evacuation from the surface of Mars a collective endeavor, saying that, We all left together.
But the commander was having none of it.
You were following orders. I left him behind.
I suppose thats what they mean about the loneliness of command.
See this movie! Then read the book! Or vice versa. Youll be glad you did.

Sometimes an audiobook is just a different path to the same goal as reading: gain information from the medium.  This book is not. The content in and of itself is great, however the audiobook is akin to sitting through a fantastic theatrical performance. Normally, I recommend books I like to people and let them choose their favorite media, not this one! Don't miss this audio performance! As for the movie, it was good, but it's a bit like taking someone to a local carnival and then telling them,  "That's basically what Disneyland is." I feel bad for the people content to just enjoy this movie and skip the book. They miss so much, and they don't even know!

I never give a movie 5 stars because there is always something lacking...plot line, acting, reality of the story...etc., but this missed nothing! The story line was awesome, special affects were really good; however, the rescue was far fetched, unrealistic and ruined the movie.  And what is with directors who seem to pick the youngest actors to portray scientists and astronauts?

Here you have, Mark Watney (Matt Damon), who is a botanist, on a 30 day mission to Mars, with no plans to actually grow anything on Mars and he becomes this no-it-all on everything from electronic repair, survivalist, engineer, etc. And, what supposed to be several years in the rescue process where no one seemed to age except for Mark Watney (Matt Damon), who grew a beard.

I would have preferred the supply ship to have made it to Mars and give Mark Watney a living chance to survive.  Then, when the next mission to Mars happened, Mark Watney would have been found dead or whacked out of his mind.

This had the possibility to be a 5 star movie but I gave it 2 stars.

This is one of the best films I've seen in years.
After a necessary, action-packed set-up that was scientifically impossible, but critical to the plot of the story, the science is practically bullet-proof.
Matt Damon is outstanding as Astronaut, Mark Watney in this 21st Century version of Robinson Crusoe. (Thank you, Mr. Scott, for not making a decision to have him name and be-friend the Sojourner rover (Wilson!).
The supporting cast is equally "stellar" in their performances. (sorry)

I've heard it called a 2-1/2 hour NASA commercial. It sure does a job of flooding them with a positive light. But hey, they deserve the red carpet treatment they received in this film. Ridley Scott worked with them and they helped to keep the science on track. I only wonder how much better "Gravity" could have been if they had asked  real NASA scientists and engineers what actually goes on in space; as Ridley Scott obviously took the time to do in this film.  And while the science is good enough to satisfy us geeks, it is not "in your face". The story rules this film and it is both exciting and emotional.

Many of the praises I could make about this film can't be said here without exposing massive spoilers, so I'll just say it is a must see movie if you have any interest whatsoever in mankind's future in Space, or if you simply want to see a feel-good film about the incredible resilience of the Human spirit.

My only critical point is Jeff Daniels. His smug and arrogant portrayal of the NASA director was in-congruent with the type of man capable of making such thoughtful decisions; or earning the respect of his peers and employees.

The Martian(Released Sept/15)stars,among others,Matt Damon,Jessica Chastain, Kristen Wiig, Jeff Daniels and Sean Bean. Not having seen it during its initial theatrical run I am sure I am not the only one who heard the scuttlebutt on what a "great" movie this was. Not to mention that Damon would be a good candidate for an OSCAR.As has happened so many times in the past,the rumour mill turns out to be just that;thinner than air itself. What a big disappointment this barely a sliver above a turkey was.
The story finds Damon as a botanist,and five other crew,on Mars collecting data on our celestial neigbour. Up whips a huge sandstorm and their spaceship is in danger of toppling. As the crew return to the ship to leave,Damon gets struck by an antenna array and is propelled into the air and out of sight. The on board instruments tell everyone his vital functions are gone. So with danger imminent the order is given to leave poste haste.
Unbeknownst to the crew,Damon is alive,but temporarily not so well. There is a piece of antenna wiring stuck in his stomach,the blood from which most likely saving his life as it sealed the tear in the suit. He hobbles back to base camp,does a little self doctoring and is soon up and around. Now the task begins for him to survive somehow until help arrives. Damon proves resourceful and devises a way to grow potatoes inside the habitat to extend his food supply. One day he comes upon a solution to contact Earth. By this time,however,NASA has already detected him and when they finally connect,the rush is on to get him back home.
The crew of the returning ship,after three months,is finally made aware of the situation. After a supply ship to Mars,which is hastily put together,blows up after launch,NASA devises a plan to slingshot the returning ship around Earth,pick up supplies(from a joint U.S./China project)in orbit,and head back to Mars. This is accomplished, but once in orbit the return ship is still too far away to get to Damon. His ship(a de-constructed supply ship sent to Mars ahead of a future mission)is tumbling over and over far below. The captain of the rescue ship is on an EVA seat stretched as far as the tether will take it. Damon in a desperate move cuts his suit around his wrist and uses the escaping air to propel himself to the captain. Damon is saved.
As the film ends we find Damon is now teaching up and coming astronauts.
Yes the S/FX are very good and director Scott does manage to imbue the film with moments of tension and suspense. But the outcome is telegraphed long before the picture ends,so it is just a matter of wading through over two hours of long,drawn out and quite boring scenes involving either Damon's activities on Mars or the NASA gang on Earth doing their "we're very concerned and worried" routine. The outdoor scenes of Mars itself were totally unconvincing to this reviewer. The were of course just computer enhanced Earth scenery, but it LOOKED like computer enchanced Earth scenery(we're not supposed to think that while watching,as it kinda spoils the believably ya know ).Damons transformation from full weight to a walking skeleton near the end of his rescue was also not believable. What caused this severe weight loss was his having to ration his meager supplies. However when the producers showed an obvious double from behind-only to emphasize his wasted phsyique,they forgot when they showed his face that it too should have looked as gaunt. It looked as full as it did in the beginning of the film. And if he was that emaciated how did he ever have the strength to do the things he did to get rescued. Just asking.
Technically speaking the film is in its original w/s a/r of 2:40:1 and is clear and crisp. Extras include a gag reel,featurettes and the trailer. From what I understand the original cut of this film came in around 2hrs. 45m. I would expect that version to be released sometime in the future.
All in all a darn long and boring film. While it tried to be something grander,all it succeeded in doing was trying my patience. Do not believe the hype folks or you will be sadly disappointed. 2  1/2 stars.

I'm quite sorry to have to say that The Martian was a great disappointment.

I am a long-time fan of director Ridley Scott, both of his science fiction films, Alien being one of best ever made, as well as some of his other films, such as Someone to Watch Over Me and Thelma and Louise.

I looked forward to the release of this film.

The first segment of adjusting to life on Mars is pretty good. Matt Damon is well cast as an astronaut type, and his behavior will remind viewers very much of the old MacGyver television show with a number of ingenious survival tricks and jerry-rigged apparatus.

I like Damon, but his role and performance are not demanding enough to warrant any award. I do very much like the little touches of humor scattered in this segment. Some viewers seem to have objected, but I think the humor was a good choice.

Then the film begins to fall apart. Scenes back at NASA sometimes are just plain tedious with orders being grunted and scads of people running about and grimacing. The casting for the Director of NASA is poor, entirely unsuitable. The dialogue is all second-rate, at best, yet writing has been nominated for an award.

The staged whole worlds interest, eventually, in one man stuck on Mars quickly tires too. It reminds me of some of the cheaper sci-fi films of the 1950s with news reel crowd scenes spliced in. No, these aren't news reels, they're carefully constructed new footage, but what a tedious waste of time they are. It simply fails to capture us in the drama which it claims is going on.

Good God, and then officials in China take an interest and offer a now-secret rocket system of their own to help. This is absolutely unbelievable. Great powers do not behave this way, motivated by sentimentality  certainly the United States never would.

I won't go into details, but the actual escape from Mars is close to ridiculous and highly unsatisfying. Yes, it is all superficially plausible, but it is not truly believable. There is a difference.

Since the tedious portion of the film is at least half its length, I just cannot recommend it, and not by any stretch of the imagination is it a "best film."

By the way, there is a pice de rsistance bit of droning boredom tacked-on at the end. Damon, now famous, goes to speak to a group of aspiring students. The scene is literally silly and reminds me of a sermonette on self-reliance, which, of course, as any reasonable person knows is not something you can teach. You either have the right stuff or you dont, and only real-life challenge will prove it one way or another.

This film definitely does not have the right stuff.

I believe Ridley Scott is now 78 years old.  Quite possibly, he has passed his productive years?

Maybe the award nominations reflect this fact. After all, they gave an Oscar to Elizabeth Taylor for one of worst performances in another, almost unwatchably boring film, "Butterfield 8," years ago because she was very sick at the time and of course was a big money-earner for the studios.

Some smaller points.

First, the escape ship, from Mars orbit, seems to me impossibly large and complex, given the huge engineering efforts always put in to minimize such things by NASA.

Second, in the early scene of the crew leaving Mars in their lander and leaving their comrade behind, the reason is a massive sand storm. Surely, planners would anticipate such storms. We know right now that you couldn't go and stay any time there without adequate preparations.
Predictable.

But it was very entertaining, but most of all he showed what character he can create on screen, as he has done so many times before. I found it refreshing scifi, good script great acting on all their parts. I gave it 5 stars because I was captured from the very beginning until the end, Bravo Matt and Crew.

I'm truly stunned @ this movies popularity. In 2000 Don Cheadle & Val Kilmer overcame far more impossible odds in separate movies, same planet, same obstacles to overcome.  "Sciencing  the Sh! t" out of meager resources @ their disposal allowed Cheadle to grow plants for breathable atmosphere until his crew returned & we learned earth was populated long ago by real Martians.

Kilmer fought off psychotic fellow astronauts, short circuited terminator, flesh-eating simple celled organisms whose upside is... breathable atmosphere. Next on to reprogram a decades old soviet probe w/Cyrillic alphanumeric digits w/lots of liquid fuel left over that hadn't stratified and mechanics, rocket all still working.  Whack Terminator, crawl inside, blast off like a bat of hell, let ship disintegrate around him while getting into orbit and the waiting arms of Carrie-Anne Moss. and a nice long ride home, if you know what I mean...

First of all, I was expecting a lot out of this film. The great rating coupled with the director, had my hopes high. I'd seen Gladiator and Prometheus and knew what Ridley Scott could do. I expected so much more from this film -- directed by one of my favorite directors, Ridley Scott, and starring one of my favorite actors, Matt Damon. But "The Martian" squandered its potential by constantly changing its point of view, introducing a bunch of characters we never really got to know, and bouncing from Mars to earth to space and back around again. It would have been fascinating to stay with Mark on Mars, as we stayed with Tom Hanks in "Castaway," experiencing his solitude, hopelessness and then ingenuity and determination to survive. In "Castaway," Hanks' character was on a remote island on earth. Mark was on Mars and, as the audience, we could have experienced Mars with him, felt its barrenness and gloried in its magnificence. Ridley Scott, along with his team, is a master at creating alien worlds -- "Alien" and "Blade Runner" come immediately to mind. Matt Damon is a talented actor, who could have given us a powerful performance, as Hanks did in "Castaway." Perhaps someday there will be a director's cut that shows us what could have been.

Anyone proposing to buy this movie should first come to grips with astounding hypocrisy inherent within it. As any informed person knows the chief protagonist, Matt Damon, is a huge liberal and big Obama supporter, at least in 2008. Now, first and foremost, this film portrays a NASA filled with young millennial types just over bursting with tech knowhow embracing the challenges of space and interplanetary exploration. As the plot of this film unfolds the entire world becomes enveloped in the drama of interplanetary exploration. However, the truth is, it is funding for this type of manned exploration that President Obama has cut the most.

in 2012, one year after the book on which the film was based was published, President Barack Obama allocated $1.2 billion to NASA's planetary science programs  a 20 percent cut from the current allotment of $1.5 billion, with further reductions expected over the next several years. This shift compels the agency to withdraw from the European-led ExoMars missions, which aim to launch an orbiter and a drill-toting rover to the Red Planet in 2016 and 2018, respectively. According to one news article "NASA's new strategy acknowledges that the agency won't be launching ambitious, expensive "flagship" missions like MSL toward the Red Planet  or any other solar system body  anytime soon. 'A flagship mission in not on the table,' said John Grunsfeld, NASA's associate administrator for science. 'We're looking at building a moderate mission...',

Now this film was released three years after Obama's cuts, so the filmmakers knew all about it, but in the film the only government agency that comes under criticism for spending priorities is Congress (who, as the film was released was controlled by political conservatives).

If you want to see man on Mars, then buy this movie and vote Republican. By the way, it was Republican President Dwight Eisenhower who created NASA in the first place.

My husband and I listened to the audio version of the book on a drive to Florida,  and when it was over,  we both said "This would make a great movie! ". It did. I am not a lover of science fiction,  and I'll admit that some of the scientific stuff was over my head, but both book and movie enthralled me-I was totally engrossed. You will laugh,  be on the edge of your seat,  be infuriated by the political BS going on back on earth,  and cheer (literally!) for the main character. You won't be sorry you watched this movie.

The Martian is both an interesting character study and exciting suspense filled sci-fi film. It is of course science fiction but does not seem that far fetched. This has the feeling of a film that 100 years from now, or less, could be billed as "based on a true story". Almost all popular science fiction requires belief in things that at present seem impossible. Kudos to the writer or writing team for great scientific and tecnological research that produced an entirely plausible story. Matt Damon gives a great performance that ranks among his finest work. This is excellent entertainment.

Basic tale of man stranded on deserted "island" with little hope of rescue done with a modern twist. The movie is a lot of fun with lots of offbeat humor. Many errors on the scientific scale but that can be forgiven because it does provide basic education on planetary injection, relative velocity rendezvous, gravity, atmosphere pressure, and many of the issues involved in interplanetary colonization. I liked the movie enough to buy the book.

The Martian is a great ride.  It starts fast and just keeps rolling.  However, as a child of the space race, there were a few things that bothered me even though I know they were done to achieve more drama.  Once the crew makes their emergency bug-out and they are out of danger, why would they then head back to Earth?  They were only half way through their planned schedule and so they had supplies and a launch window that was months away.  Any scientist is going to want to stay in orbit and conduct science and also observe the impact of the storm on the surface facilities.  I understand that they could not go back down to the surface, but who would just take off for home without checking on anything?  And why would NASA which tries to be precise in the things that it does, just assume him to be dead?  And why would you start running the rover all over the place first thing?  The first thing you do in crash scenario is stay put and let the help come to you.  Nevertheless, I did enjoy the movie a great deal.

This is a survival movie. Great Movie! Our whole family enjoyed it. If you like survival movies then this is for you.  After being abandoned and left for dead on Mars... Michael Pena has to use every common sense and science theory to survive long enough until help can come, which will take almost a year of survival. No water, no food, harsh temperatures and bad weather makes it interesting on how he figures out all these crucial necessities to live.  Incredibly the instinct to live and never give up is what kept him alive. A lesson we all should learn from this movie.

I saw this movie several times and in my opinion the plot was predictable and a bit far fetched.. Come on now...This "Macgyver" astronaut has the answer to every single problem that comes up..He puts a scoop of crap near a potato and puts it into highly radiated martian soil and presto...he has potatoes up to his ears. I know its all for effect and part of the survival story but come on. Next he is a plant guy...a botanist, yet he solves a multitude of problems far exceeding the knowledge of a plant scientist.. Then he tapes plastic to the entrance to seal it up. This is the most unbelievable part.. Total BS!!  Not only would the pressure difference instantly blow it out but it somehow holds up to the storms...must be special space plastic and tape that stick at -150 degrees.  How many rolls of duct tape do astronauts carry?  He must have went thru 20 rolls. but hes not worried a bit, he just goes along his business not worrying if at any moment he could die instantly. I know I couldn't sleep a wink with plastic and tape separating me from the martian atmosphere. The movie overall keeps you going with problem after problem being solved and for me there wasn't enough action and was drawn out way too far. It's entertaining enough if you don't dig into the scientific aspects of Mars. I'm still debating whether to add it to my sci fi collection.
The movie was very enjoyable with some suspense, humor and great problem solving skills.

Space just got a lot more interesting. This is a movie that will leave folks in their senior years with some very interesting feelings about where we are heading with our lives and how much we will miss when we are finally gone. I never imagined Mars as a real destination, but this movie has given me a fresh set of impressions on why that is a great goal, as an avenue to progress on not just a scientific level but to pose moral and ethical questions as well. Can a man who leaves everything he knows behind still be the same person? The "Robinson Crusoe" effect has given this deep philosophical question a through re-vamp here, in an enjoyable future adventure that should be a positive, up-lifting human survival tale with a space-age twist that will keep you glued to the screen until the very end. Matt Damon gives a fine performance as a space botanist in trouble.

I thought this movie suffered from the monotone delivery of most of the characters. (Except Donald Glover, whose rumpled college student vibe was hilarious!) They're all talking very seriously into screens all the time. In thinking about how more emotion could have been worked into the story, I got to wondering where Mark Watney's parents were. He records a message to them while stranded on Mars, but if he's talking to the folks at NASA, couldn't they have brought the parents in to see and talk to him? If it were my son, I would have torn down walls and kicked in doors to get to the control room. There's the emotion that was missing, in my opinion. For me, Apollo 13 was a much more gripping (and true!) story. Lacking any emotional core, the movie is just a standard issue (albeit loaded with cool science) adventure flick.

A very cool movie about a stranded astronaut. I really like the scripting. However, there were a few inaccuracies, as usual with Hollywood writers,
For one, an airlock would not be made of what was shown in the movie, and would have been more properly secured to it's habitat module. Oh well, it made for a bit of excitement, I suppose. There also would not have been noticeable flapping of plastic sheeting, as the pressure on Mars is one two hundredth that of Earth. Yeh, you would see the dust blowing about, but it would not be as dramatic as seen here.

Also, a returning space craft would not have enough fuel, or food to turn around, and go all the way back to Mars to make a rescue. In reality, an unmanned ship built for one would have been the best logical choice to be sent for a rescue.

I was fortunate to have had the chance to read the book this movie is based on very early on.  It was dicey as to whether I would be able to finish it as the language was periodically quite coarse and totally in your face.  Fortunately the screenplay toned that down a bit, enough to make it watchable and enjoyable.

The book to movie transition and faithfulness is great.  The story line, the intensity, and experience is fantastic.

Matt Damon nails the lead role as a botanist stranded on Mars, where he has to try to find a way to stay alive in the hopes that a rescue mission might take place, even though it is much more likely that it will not.

The science is solid, the storyline is engaging, and the acting is top-notch.

I highly recommend the book (but be ready for periodic heavy coarse language) and the movie.  I am happy to add this to my movie library.

All in all, topnotch entertainment.

Full Disclosure: I tend to really love sci-fi and tech oriented entertainment, so I naturally loved "the Martian". So please keep this in mind when making your viewing choice. Damon really pulled it off as a person stuck in a bad situation who must "work the problem" to save his life. The screenplay has enough action to keep most people interested through the story. I liked that, set in the near future, the writers never resorted to "magical" technology to force the story to work. It also makes some salient points on our collective humanity without trying to hammer them into the viewers mind.

You don't really need to suspend belief when starting to watch The Martian, which opens with a sudden storm overtaking a small manned space base on the Red Planet. In the confusion astronaut Mark Watney (played by Matt Damon) is left behind and has to work out how to stay alive over the course of the 18 months it will take for NASA to rescue him. He rigs up a greenhouse and grows potatoes, all the while trying to work out how to make it across the planet to the spot where the next mission is due to arrive. The time zips by as he shows his ability to improvise but sadly, the movie bogs down when it comes to the rescue. We are then treated to a Gravity-style space junk movie with far too many wild improbabilities and laughable plot lines, which sadly wrecks the end of the show.

The Martian is a well written and well acted suspense film that is set on Mars. The plot is well constructed and intelligent. Still, I prefer the earlier film Apollo 13. The films share the theme of a mishap in space with the problem of bringing astronauts home alive with crippled equipment, but Apollo 13 succeeded in developing much more suspense and drama. I suspect the fact that Apollo 13 is based on actual events has a great deal to do with that. Also, I thought the end of The Martian was a bit anticlimactic. I hoped for some greater message or epiphany than I was given. Still, it's a very entertaining film.

A credible job of summarizing Andy Weir's novel. It would take a mini-series to do it justice, but this was a fun watch, even though some might think it shallow and inaccurate from a scientific perspective. I've been reading science fiction for over 60 years, and have to say that "The Martian" ranks right up there at the top. If you haven't read it, you're missing a real page-turner, even when you know the outcome. Mark Watney's faith in his ability to solve life-challenging problems, one at a time, is inspirational - something a relatively short movie can convey. Matt Damon was an excellent choice to play the lead, and I found the supporting cast equally well chosen and believable. Larger than life? Yeah, but fun, and close enough for me.

This is a great movie! The science is dense and excellent, the physical site of the Jordanian desert works perfectly for Mars (with a touch of CGI), the narrative is believable and the acting is wonderful. The realism is heightened by the humorous Band -of- Brothers- and- Sisters camaraderie among the crew members, joking in the face of really unimaginable tragedy. In particular is Matt Damon's video log comments as he clearly struggles to fend off despair and isolation with a sense of adventure.. as he is shown telling the class of new astronauts at the end of the film, just take it a step at a time, and each step of problem solving leads to another step. I think that this movie more than makes up for Ridley Scott's previous science fiction movie Prometheus and returns his audience to the gritty believable science of the original Alien and, of course, the touchstone science fiction movie of all time (up there with 2001 and Apollo !3), Blade Runner. Highly, highly recommended!

The Martian had some really funny moments and some really touching moments. And for a story as crazy and (seemingly) implausible as this one is, the moments were I went "yeah right" were so few and so minor. The movie was good; this is a horrible review (sorry).

Total side note: Not sure how Michael Peña and Jessica Chastain are getting top billing. Not a big deal at all. It's just Matt Damon's face is right on the poster! (Not an actual complaint. Just a weird detail that made me smile).

As far as the 3D goes, this film looks positively flawless. Not only do the scenes in space look amazing, but even shots of press conferences and mission control are all framed and shot so expertly to take full advantage of the format.

Visually stunning movie, easily one of the best looking 3D movies I've ever seen - but the movie as a whole was your typical by-the-numbers space movie mixed with your generic survival story, nothing new here. I liked Gravity more, but it was a fun watch. Certainly not Best Picture material, we've seen a million movies like this before - and while I'm happy they didn't try and pull at your heartstrings too much, they didn't give the main character ANY backstory at all. A quick mention of his parents and that's it - your less excited to see how things play out because the filmmakers don't give you much purpose for him to survive outside of the fact that it would be a PR issue for NASA.

So I say pick this up if you have a 3D setup at home, but if you just want to see it in 2D - rent it, borrow it or be patient for it to hit Netflix.

I enjoyed this movie in the theater, so I wanted to share it with my wife at home. As can be expected, the home experience isn't as breathtaking as the big screen, but it is still impressive. To me, a science fiction film story needs to have aliens, replicants, murderous computers, etc. This film is more real, more near-future, and more believable. That is important to me. As an engineer, I see a number of scientific flaws, but we are not talking a documentary here, it's a saga and good entertainment. If you want the facts on going to Mars, check out the seminal book from Zubrin: The Case for Mars: The Plan to Settle the Red Planet and Why We Must. Lets get going!

I was really looking forward to seeing the Martian since I heard so much about the movie. But by movies end, I was left very disappointed asking myself why was this movie even made. The Martian did not create any tension in the audience the way Apollo 13 did. When those astronauts were stranded in space, I was really worried about the crew and their problems and I was completely engaged in what the ground crew was actively working on towards solving Apollo's problems. Not so in the Martian. While communication between ground and Mars required excellent thinking to figure out how to communicate, the script and actors never included let you feel the fear of not communicating, never let you feel the fear of what if this doesn't work...none of that. The Martian was inventive - he did figure out how to make water but the movie presented the resourceful solution very blandly. The Martian was no MacGyver - but, the Martian did use duct tape a lot. The sling-shot around earth by the returning ship happened so fast, I thought I missed it! Remember Spock, McCoy, and Shatner coming home with two whales - there's a sling-shot with banter, humor, and worry. Because of strong storms that threaten to topple their rocket scientists on the surface of Mars have to cut short their research mission and make an emergency escape leaving behind one crewmember they think is dead.  Of course he isn't.  He survived, barely but the rest of the crew are on their way home and can't turn around.  Even if they could he has no way of contacting them.  His only hope is to wait for the next scheduled mission to Mars which will land 2,000 kilometers away.  He has a battery powered vehicle that can't travel anywhere near that far.  He has equipment for oxygen and water but the only food is what was left behind by the others which can't be stretched that long.  The movie is about how he overcomes one seemingly insurmountable problem after another and things don't always go smoothly.

One should read the book first in this case, for there are one or two scenes and bits of dialogue that seem to be out of sync with everything else.  For instance, why was Watney (and the technicians back on Earth) drilling holes in the second rover to remove the roof?  It was somewhat entertaining to see both the Earth technician and Watney fall through the roof of the rover after enough holes were drilled, but why remove the roof in the first place?  The book lets us know that Watney used the second rover for a trailer, not the spindly affair shown in the movie.  That being said, the movie did a good job of presenting the substance of the novel and the various technical and emotional dilemmas faced both by Watney on Mars, NASA on Earth, and the Hermes crew traveling both from and then back to Mars.  What's it like to suppose you've lost a crewmate on Mars and then, months into your flight back to Earth, to find out he is still alive you have left him behind?  Although the exchange between Watney and the Hermes crew is greatly condensed in the movie, the viewer is able to get the gist of the gritty decisions that had to be made by all involved.  The special effects alone were worth seeing, not the least of which were the scenes of a vast and empty Martian landscape in the middle of which were a single battered habitat, a moving rover trailing a plume of dust, or Watney alone in his EVA suit, sitting on a Martian rock and contemplating his fate.  Recommended!

The characters were toned down cardboard cutouts, the actors had nothing left to work with and practically phoned in their performances.  Quite a few details were changed from the book, in such a way that they didn't work as well, or in some cases didn't make any sense at all. I understand the need for such changes for reasons such as pacing or explainability, but these seemed to have no purpose just added to my overall disappointment in the movie.  The audio book was fantastic, and much better performed than the movie.  Mark was ten times more likeable, and even the other characters had a lot more life in them.

Best Picture 2015, hands down -- or should be.  The best sci-fi film ever made, even compared to the classic "2001: A Space Odyssey".  Took the best sci-fi novel in years, and greatly improved it with wonderful acting, directing and screenwriting, not to mention magnificent special effects with breathtaking Martian vistas.  Calling this a "comedy" was the biggest gaffe in entertainment history.

Laughs do not a comedy make.  Star Wars: A New Hope - Comedy? Of course not, but you chuckle when the Falcon won't make its jump and Han Solo insists, "it's not my fault. It's not my fault!" Just because a movie might have some comedic moments, or comments that make you laugh, that does not mean the movie is a comedy. Comedies have entirely different story arcs with pratfalls and reckonings for characters from unexpected sources and suchlike. This movie might be considered a comedy because of the approach to every dilemma that the chief protagonist chooses to take, which is to treat it as a challenge that has a solution as opposed to anything damning. As a book it almost certainly reads funnier than it comes across on the screen. I don't think I can write anything else without a spoiler disclaimer so I will leave this review with one comment that is not a spoiler but is about the movie. If you go to a planet, or moon, and plan to be there for 21 days, then everything is prepped for however many people will be there for that period of time, in terms of basic Maslow Hierarchy terms, which is to say food and shelter. There are other mission specific things, where the technology aspect of the trip is concerned, but food and shelter are the first concerns to be addressed. That said, if you ever wake up to find yourself stranded anywhere while you were sleeping in a tent, or in the case of the movie a glorified Yurt, and the one thing you can count on is extremely harsh and unpredictable weather patterns, please harden off the structure you are depending on for sustaining your life. At the very least, stack up some rocks and don't rely solely upon visqueen and duct tape.

3.5 Acclaimed director Ridley Scott once again takes to the stars with a semi-humorous movie based on a book by the same name. While on a manned mission to Mars, a vicious storm hits a small group of astronauts. As they try to escape, one of their crew, Mark Watney (Matt Damon), is hit by debris and presumed dead. The rest of the crew leave Mars for Earth. Back on Earth, NASA reports his death, but soon Mark turns up alive. NASA scrambles to save him, by sending him more supplies and figuring out a rescue mission. Mark, alone on the hostile planet with meager supplies, cultivates Mars and grows potatoes to survive. Of course more disaster hits both Mark and NASA. While the movie has a stellar cast [Jessica Chastain, Kristen Wiig, Jeff Daniels, Michael Pena, Sean Bean, Kate Mara, and Donald Glover], the movie was boring and lacked some character elements. The script was sarcastically funny, as Mark talked to the cameras to record his experience, but it lacked the pain and depression that Mark must have been feeling. It showed it at times, but spent a lot of time on Earth and NASAs rescue attempts. It was also a simple story that dragged on for 2 and half hours, where one knew the plot going into it. Being very visual with the Martian landscapes and space ships, this would have been a one for the theater, but I found that there was nothing exciting that makes it stand out. Its worth checking out on a lazy weekend afternoon, which is how I watched it.

Just some general notes.  Great concept and outstanding CGI. Reminded me a bit of Castaway but without the pathos.  A little over the top in MacGyver like ingenuity.  Fun to see but implausible.  Many science flaws (despite comments to the contrary).  For example, the wind storm that flung Watney away could not exist on Mars (because of thin atmosphere) so the entire scientific premise of the movie is flawed.  Over exposure to radiation would have normally crippled the crew both on Mars and the long journey between Earth and Mars.  This movie touted realism but it wasn't forthcoming here.  A bit hokey with the disco music.  I never really connected to the main character.  However, the scene with Watney giving himself medical attention was extremely well done and acted.  I enjoyed it, but it could have been a lot better!

And then there was Kristin Wiig, whom I generally like, cast in a completely superfluous role as some senior NASA rep. or PR person. I could not figure out why her character  was in the movie at all. Her performance consisted of being on screen in a tight "professional office couture" and heels while her facial expressions were limited to a wide eyed "OMG" or smirkly "don't even." Stupid.

Man's desire to survive, even against all realistic hope, is displayed in "The Martian". This movie falls between several classifications. It's adventure. It's suspense. It's comedy!  (Yes, I said comedy, but not because of the plot. It is the sense of humore of the main character, even in the most hopeless of situations.)

 Matt Damon portrayed NASA Astronaut/Engineer/Botonist Mark Watney, quite well, even though the editing in the screenplay took much to much of his personality away from the character. Mark WatneyThen again, comparing a movie to the book is always going to find the movie lacking! In this case, I believe they found several of the best parts of a 14 hour read and put them into a 2 hour movie.  I recommend that you see the movie. It will not disappoint. But READ THE BOOK! Watney had such an amazing sense of humor and the math and science he has to use to survive are spell-binding and legit!

Rarely do I enjoy a Matt Damon movie as much as I did with this film. Matt Damon is brilliant as an abandoned astronaut on Mars who luckily, happens to be botanist. With limited supplies, Damon convincingly "colonizes" the planet, creates a viable living space for himself and finds a way to stay alive until a rescue mission can be formed. The brilliance of this film is Ridley Scott's balance of suspense, heavy scientific-jargon, and sharp-witted humor. The films humor never detracts from the situation; if anything it alleviates the tension the audience feels as Damon tries to adapt to each new, spirit-crushing problem he encounters. The Martian if far from perfect, with some far-fetched sequences in the end that are a bit more movie-magic than applied science, but if you overlook that, you've got an intelligent, thriller with style and heart.

Finally, the plot is one of the typical  seven or so the the industry seems to be stuck in as they continuously cycle through the actors, situations and the like only to end up back where some other 300 movies have been. Maybe I am getting old and my memory is shorter, or the movie industry  is,  and they lack the level of imagination  required  to end a movie with a real twist. Otherwise, I would have given it 4 stars.

This is not the most memorable job by any of the major figures connected to this project, but it is nonetheless a fun a 2+ hours of popular entertainment that will be fun if you don't push and ask many questions. I don't mean to imply that this is like another popular SF film INDEPENDENCE DAY, which had a few dozen major - and I really do mean major - plot holes that makes it impossible for many viewers to accept the film on any level. It is all in all tremendously predictable, even formulaic, but the film is populated by a host of very talented professionals, both behind and in front of the camera, so any holes, like high grade spackle, is easily covered over.

The film raises some interesting meta-narrative questions. Is this SF? If so, why is it? If it isn't SF, why isn't it? It is set a few decades into the future, with space travel being taken for granted and apart from the logistical problems of going to Mars the only major hindrance. In fact, this really is nothing but a film about the logistical problems of going to Mars. The film is at its best when facing these complex considerations face on. Unlike in STAR TREK or STAR WARS, where somehow people can communicate across vast stretches of space in real time (which will never happen given to the nature of the very fabric of the stuff of the universe), there is a substantial time delay between messages sent to and from Mars. My favorite part of the film consisted of those on Mars trying to communicate to those on Earth using decades-old technology. Playing both sides of the "Is this SF?" question, one could say that this film follows firmly in the tradition of hard SF, in which scientific considerations play a major role in the story. And in fact, there are a lot of stories along these lines in the Golden Age of SF over which John Campbell reigned. Campbell wanted stories rooted in science, and deployed strong characters or even a strong literary subtext, as these detracted from the science. Thus, in what is widely considered the most famous and certainly the most anthologized SF short story ever written, "The Cold Equations" by Tom Godwin, the entire story involves figuring out if it is possible for a space ship carrying vital cargo for a distant planet to fulfill its mission after a woman stowaways on the ship. The captain (and in keeping with Campbell's aesthetic, both of the story's characters are cardboardish in the extreme - it was the very rare individual, such as Robert Heinlein, who was able to create memorable characters or great dialogue during the time Campbell held sway) spends most of the story "working the problem," concluding that there is no way to reach the planet if he spares the stowaway, though virtually everyone who has ever read the story questions the story's central assumptions, asserting that it is hard to really believe that the equations are so cold as to allow no wiggle room at all. But one of the marks of hard SF is "working the problem." The other side would be that in the wake of Philip K. Dick supplanting Asimov, Heinlein, and Clarke as the model of what SF is trying to achieve (although Dick wrote in the fifties, sixties, and seventies, his books really only took off in a huge way in the eighties, partly as a result of BLADE RUNNER and partly as a result of Vintage bringing most of his novels into a standard, in print edition (I remember spending hours raking through SF bins in the seventies trying to find PKD novels - I even read drek like COUNTER CLOCK WORLD in my search for ANYTHING by him). Also important was the production of a five volume edition of his complete short stories. There are many ways in which we want more in our SF these days. THE MARTIAN is definitely an old style, hard SF story, and those who have come to love more nunanced stories and complex characters in the tradition of BLADE RUNNER (by the same director as THE MARTIAN) and BATTLESTAR GALACTICA may not find it to their taste. My opinion? I'm still trying to sort out how I feel, but I believe that this is SF, but not SF as interesting as most other good SF films of recent decades. I should also reveal that I passionately agree with Orson Scott Card that the STAR WARS films are not SF; they are fantasy adventures films in SF costumes. Even as space opera they fail to fall into either hard SF or Dickisian SF. The real source is the old thirties and forties low budget serials, which have never really been considered SF by most SF fans, even when considering FLASH GORDON. I believe issues of what constitutes a SF narrative an important one for understanding the genre as a whole.

But it is hard to fault this film too much. It is not in any way a memorable film - I have seen it once, and I doubt that I will ever want to see it again. As I said above, the film is stuffed to the brim with talented individuals, from stars like Matt Damon and Chiwetel Ejiofor to screen writer Drew Goddard (they guy who has emerged as one of the go-to screen writers of his generation simply couldn't overcome the limited nature of the story) and veteran director Ridley Scott. Speaking of the latter, even though he has directed some of my all time favorite films (ALIEN and BLADE RUNNER above all) and more recently created THE GOOD WIFE, a TV series I have thoroughly enjoyed, most of his films seem like projects for his enormous abilities in creating great visuals. Scott started off as an Art Director, and in a way he has never become more than this as a film director. All of his films look great, but they have not consistently been interesting in terms of character or story.

So, if you are looking for a fun time for two or so hours, this should do the trick. But I do not think that this will be remembered as a particularly fine film, whether SF or otherwise.

There is a philosophical thread that runs throughout recorded history regarding a group never (or at least almost never), leaving one of their own behind. In war it means soldiers going back to rescue one of their own who may have been lost or wounded. In any circumstances they strive to rescue their comrade(s). The Martian builds on that philosophy and does an excellent job of describing how both the one left behind and the rescuers go about affecting the rescue and returning their lost comrade home. So, the story and screenplay does very well in describing the complex activities necessary to rescue Matt Damon's character from certain death following the Martian storm that led to the separation from his colleagues. Moreover, the "real" science behind how Damon's character survives and ensures that he can get to the physical place on Mars where he can influence his own rescue is well woven into the story.

Looking at the acting and directing I would say that Damon did an excellent job of stepping through the story in the portrayal of the hero's overcoming one adversity after another. Additionally, the director did a masterful job in weaving the activities on earth and those going on on Mars so that the viewer can identify closely with the various characters - a not so easy feat considering how time and "space" would normally delay everything. So, the story unfolds at an acceptable rate so as to not lose the viewers. Well done!

The production values of the film were great with nearly seamless crossing between real and CGI. It was interesting to see how such vast spaces and time periods were deftly handled throughout. Another well done!

Overall, the story stayed believable (as opposed to other stories about Mars where preachiness can get in the way), and even with all the cards stacked against him, Matt comes home (in one piece)! Yea!!

Great movie but it did drag on abit with all the solution seeking here on earth . Similar to the Apollo 13 story however, engineers and scientists are put to the test to determine answers.

Good science. Some great scenes, especially towards the beginning of the film, where a solid performance by Matt Damon, makes watching the first man to live on Mars worth while.

As the film progresses, the story starts to feel muddled.  As new characters back on earth emerge, and old characters re-enter the frame, the moments in which the film beguiles, become rarer and rarer.

These moments become interupted by clunky edits, as the two parts of the story, Matt Damon colonization of Mars, and Nasa's rescue mission for his character jockey for attention.

A blockbuster cast (I'm guessing Ridley Scott really liked Interstellar, since he casted two of its alum), great and great cgi environmen's cannot save this film.

The music underwhelmed, the cinematography felt average for the scale of the film, and the clunky editing left me wanting for more.

A survival movie, taken to the max! It doesn't get much more extreme than being left behind on Mars, and fighting to live long enough to get back home!
And this movie has it all. Exactly what us lovers of survival stories love. A hero in an impossible position, getting down to what needs to be done, no feeling sorry for himself, hard work, creative thinking, quick wit and even faster humor. Oh...and endless uses for Duck Tape. What more can a person want?
Add a wonderful cast of people doing the impossible to save another person in trouble...and this movie is a fun, moving, breathtaking drama for anyone who loves a good story!

Nine Things About "The Martian"

1. This is probably the science fiction film with the most actual science that I've ever seen.

2. Based on a book by the same name, it's about a crew exploring Mars. When a huge dust storm hits, one of the crew members, Mark, is punched in the gut by piece of equipment and the crew leaves him for dead. Of course, he's not dead.

3. The movie goes back and forth between Mark's efforts to survive on Mars, and NASA's efforts to save him - and everybody can only use science and math. That's it. That's the whole plot. There's no violence, or aliens, or space battles (although technically there is one space pirate).

4. NASA consulted closely on this film to make it as accurate as possible, including the surface of Mars. So it's also kind of a commercial for NASA. But that's OK. Anything that encourages scientific education is fine with me.

5. There are two big scientific inaccuracies in the film - a storm on Mars couldn't be that strong, and the lack of atmosphere means Mark would have died of cancer. Additionally, I'm personally really suspicious of the "Iron Man maneuver". However, I think these are acceptable fudges, because they make the movie possible, and it is worth being made. The really cool things Mark does are basically real, even the way he makes water.

6. It's nice to see an accurate portrayal of a mission like this that relies on the delicate interplay of many different specialties, such as physics, chemistry, botany, and math. Nobody gets to be a superhero, but anybody can cause a mission to fail.

7. The cast is not only talented, but diverse. It's really great to see males and females of various races all being smart together. It's a subtle message that subjects in science, math, and engineering are for anyone who wants to study them (by the way, am I the only person that thinks Donald Glover is a really good actor and deserves much bigger roles than what he gets?).

8. Director Ridley Scott said he thinks the theme of the movie is that nobody is really alone. Which is funny, because I saw the exact opposite theme.

9. This movie is a rarity in Hollywood - it's entertainment mixed with actual learning. If you need action, or flashy special effects and interstellar drama, you're going to be disappointed. But with a story this compelling and realistic, I wouldn't be surprised to see a boost in science and math majors as a result of this movie.

I read the book before the movie came out. I absolutely loved it. Geeks rule!  I recommended it to my teacher friends as a tool to combine reading, math and science in their classrooms.  Then I saw it in the theatre, with the 3-d glasses, and I loved it. At lot of the math and science detail from the book was left out. That's understandable because the movie would have had to be 10 hours long to include it all. Then, last night to celebrate the snow we watched it on our 42 inch TV. Once again, I loved it. The picture quality was outstanding, even though Amazon warned me that it might not be. I actually enjoyed the TV version more than the big screen because I was able to take in all the visual experiences at once. This movie was great for all ages. It has one four letter word in it. Watch it with your kids to show them as an inspiration for what science and cooperation can accomplish.

Fantastic. Well-written, engaging screenplay. Acting was superb: Damon was cast perfectly for this role. I don't find the science distracting (which I so often do, because it's so often just bad and wrong). The tone was well-balanced, managing both serious dramatic suspense and light comedy. The special effects were high-quality, though not over-used so as to become a distraction. This is my current favorite recent movie.

Wildly contrived.  It should be a cartoon.  This movie so badly wants the colonization of Mars to be probable it overcomes problems with outlandish solutions, done with silly humor.  I didn't find anything humorous or cute at all.  Especially when the lead character is munching away and drinking down liquids while talking about rationing.  Is Matt Damon supposed to be cute or something?  The interaction and negotiations between the administration and scientists were hokey and fake.  The Martian, a.ka. Matt Damon, a.k.a. Mark Whatney survives explosions, one of which throws him flying in a spherical container and would have broken bones at least.  And the script for the lead character is terrible.  One would think he'd be more articulate being a scientist.  "I'm going to science the s**t out of this."  Oh, ha ha.  "Fortunately, I'm a botanist.  Mars will come to fear my botany powers!"  What?  Did this guy get into botanic super heroes?  And there was some epic realization how he has colonized mars because he grew some potatoes.  Horrible horrible acting when Whatney is in a rover freezing.  One does not talk and take deep breaths in sub zero temps.  They lock up and shiver.  Lot's of overacting really, and lots of "We have Matt Damon so we can really make this character cute."  SPOILER SPOILER SPOILER:  The sling shot concept to rescue the stranded astronaut is interesting, but are we really to believe Whatney and launch himself in orbit and the space station's precise calculations will put them in the same spot at the same time.  Especially when the station is coming to fast.  The hook up between the spaceship commander in a jet seat and astronaut in nothing but a space suit was absurdly contrived.  To refine velocity and direction on approach, the space station sets off an explosion to slow down and Whatney cuts a slit in his glove to jettison himself, and opening and closing his hand serves has a valve.  And it all went off with...well, there was a slight hitch of course, there at least had to be that.  The commander sat in a jet seat while Whatney tumbled toward her with his uncontrollable jet glove.  Of course, their hands pass through each other but Whatney gets tangled jet seat strap that is connected to the station.  Each have a hold of the strap from the jet seat and are winding closer together.  The commander sits in the jet seat desperately trying to maintain a grip on the strap while Whatney winds up around her.  Not sure why she had to struggle so much since Whatney would have been weightless in space.  Another annoying factor was all "no gravity" movement throughout the space station was flagrantly fake...they were all obviously flying and floating on cables.  This is one of those movies where you have a popular lead man mixed in plenty of female authority figures and market the thing like it's epic.  And why do the directors think Matt Damon can come off as so cute and profound?  Whatman is not a well known instructor/professor and he apparently has something profoundly epic to depart to his new students- SPOILER SPOILER SPOILER CONTINUED -----  "Welcome to the Astronaut Candidate Program.  Now pay attention, cuz this could save your life.  Trust me I know what I'm talking about. All right let me get a few things out of the way right off the bat, yes, I did in fact survive on a deserted planet by farming in my own s**t.  Yes, it's actually worse than it sounds, so let's not talk about that ever again.  Uhh, the other question I get most frequently is, when I was up there stranded by myself, did I think I was gonna die?  Yes, absolutely. And that's what you need to know going in because it's going to happen to you.  This is space, it does not cooperate. At some point, everything's gonna go south on you, everything gonna go south and you're gonna say this is it, this is how I end. Now you can either accept that, or get to work. That's all it is, you just begin.  You do the math and you solve one problem, and you solve the next one, and the next one. If you solve enough problems you get to come home.  All right, questions..."  All hands raise.  The End.  Egad!

I absolutely adore this movie. I will say, the book, written by Andy Weir, is much better. I will also say there are some things in this movie that one would not fully understand had they not read the book, which would be the fault of the screen writer, Drew Goddard. That being said, I still love the movie by itself. Matt Damon did an absolutely wonderful job playing the ever intelligent and sarcastic Mark Watney. This movie was cast very well, except for Kristen Wiig. I don't believe she exactly fit the part that she was given. Jessica Chastain did wonderfully as Commander Lewis and so did her crew. Jeff Daniels was a very believable director of NASA. I would also like to give credit to Chiwetel Ejiofor and Sean Bean for being passionate as always. This movie is cinematically beautiful. The cast and crew worked hard and they did a wonderful job. If you don't enjoy science, I will admit that some parts may be boring to you. This is a very science heavy film. The main character, Mark Watney, has to survive in a place that nothing has survived in before. This is something that no average human could do. Through mass amounts of science, Mark cultivates Mars on the inside on his sort of house, called the HAB. And through lots of money, NASA eventually finds a way to bring him home. Overall, I would definitely recommend but this is one of those movies that you need to be in the correct mood for.

This was one of my favorites of 2015! An intriguing take on the Robinson Crusoe story features Matt Damon as a lone astronaut stranded on Mars and the attempt by NASA to rescue him. Ridley Scott does a masterful job directing this story and Matt Damon delivers a teriffic performance as the astronaut in peril but who cracks jokes instead of falling to despair. The ending tugs at the heartstrings but it gives you a good feeling. You don't have to like sci-fi to like this.

The Martian, the film and the audible book, are just plain fun. I listened to the book first and loved the way it picked up speed right to its breathless ending. The author's imagery proves beautifully vivid. It was easy to place myself in the action and go for a ride in the rover. The visual effects in the film version stayed true to the story. A majestic mars, coupled with an expansive score,  provide the perfect backdrop for a hapless human with "in-the-nick-of-time" survival brilliance to manage the impossible while retaining a wry sense of humor. And the disco songs? You never know when disco can save a life.

I was initially dragged to this movie but it turned out to be one of the best movies ever.  It was great in terms of all the innovative problem-solving as well as demonstrating the power of possibilities.  I was pleasantly surprised by humor that the film offered as well.  Highly recommend.

I rarely give movies five stars. But I really enjoyed this movie. The story is straight forward and based on the eponymous popular novel by Andy Weir. And even though the film is 2 hours and 20 minutes long, it didn't feel that way at all. At no point did I think, man, I want this to hurry up. I was along the ride the whole way for sure. It had some nice moments of dry humor, lots of cool science moments, tons of exposition (but delivered in a way that made total sense for it to be spoken), was dramatic and entertaining all at once. I'd say this deserved a nomination for Best Directing, because it's so masterfully crafted by Ridley Scott, a man who isn't on my favorite director's list. In fact, I'm not usually in love with his movies like this (though I really like Thelma and Louise). I highly recommend this movie to families. It's good, clean, educational (of course some of the science doesn't check out, but hey, it's a movie first), inspiring and feel good.

It's rated Pg-13 for two spoken F-words (though their might be one or two others that are mouthed and unheard), one shot of a naked man from behind to show how much weight he has lost over time, some mild innuendos children won't understand, and a scene of injury and self-surgery. Also there is a lot of peril in the film.

I waited with great interest for the DVD to come out because I rarely go to the theaters anymore.  Too expensive and you have to put up with these
low lives that have to play with their cell phones rather than watch the movie.  When I got it I almost immediately watched it.  I have varied feelings
about this movie for the following reasons.  First, it is splendidly produced with excellent sets, realistic Mars scenes  (even with dust devils!) and
well conceived spaceship sets.  I did think the film was a bit long, with too much going back to NASA; I would rather spent more time with the
Astronaut on Mars.  I know something about space sciences and I did feel the Mothership was MUCH too large and spacious; It would have been
extremely difficult to heat and keep a  good atmosphere in such a huge ship; perhaps in the distant future such  a vessel would be considered.
Though the revolving living quarters should be thought about on any future Mars mission, because astronauts (NO COSMONAUTS!) could not
be locked up in space for 9 months in "capsule" like environments.  Something like the DISCOVERY from 2001 or the Ship in MISSION TO MARS
would be more likely to be considered.  It would have to be built in orbit, not launched from Earth.  Still, the Mothership was very well designed, and
believable as all the sets in this move is.  I gave this four stars instead of Five because I thought the rescue sequence was not well thought out; since the Mothership returned to Mars, why didn't a ship of that size have small shuttle ships?  This is Mars we are talking about which is only
a third of the size of earth with only 1/3 the gravity.  The need to leave the planet in an emergency and then return should have be a consideration
considering the length of the voyage to get there.  And Mars has a very thin atmosphere;  I could not believe the storms that do arise on the surface
would be strong enough to damage or topple the return vehicle.  The winds are said to rise to 300 mph but the air is so thin that a cracked visor
could cause the astronauts to "explode"!  Perhaps I am wrong, but that is my opinion. But overall, the cast was excellent and I give an overall
"thumbs up" to this film.  Ridley Scott made this and did a much better job than he did with that dopey EXODUS!!  To a certain extent this movie
reminded me a but of  ROBINSON CARUSO ON MARS, where an astronaut had to learn to survive untll a rescue ship would arrive.  It was good
for its time, but this film is much more up to  date and accurate.  The way this Astro found a way to communicate with earth was astounding.
So, Four Stars Plus for this well made, imaginative visually brilliant  movie.  I wish someone would make a keyboard that a good typist like me
(on REAL  typewriters!) could type on!!  OH well, this one will do.  I got my DVD from Amazon like all my others,  Enjoy!

I read the book first, and some very interesting, tense, suspensful parts of the book were left completely out of the movie.  But the movie is good -- a faster, simpler story that I think nearly anyone would enjoy.  The book has more detail and that detail makes things much more suspensful. Both are great.  I worked 38 years at a NASA Center, and I am familiar with the technologies seen in the movie and talked about in the book.  That is a very interesting and realistic aspect to this story.

I recently read the book and loved it, so of course I preordered the movie, especially with Matt Damon in the starring role.  I was skeptical that the movie would do the book justice, as so often happens...you just can't pack all the detail included in a book into two hours!  I was pleasantly surprised.  The movie managed to relay the relevant details into the plot without bogging down and while still conveying the emotions Watley, the main character, expressed in the book.  The cinamarography was just gorgeous in HD on my 60 inch television.  Highly recommend!

Okay, I'm chapped that this was entered as a comedy in the golden globes this year.  So I'm deducting a star for that.  If you don't care that a punk marketing team at Fox didn't want to compete against it's self (see the Revenant) then by all means consider this a four star review.

It's an awful lot of suspension of reality, but it's fun, and you do root for the main character (Damon), while still feeling sorry for the decisions and circumstances that lead to yet another Matt Damon rescue plot.  How much money have we spent rescuing this guy from peril in all of his films?  Still I do find some criticism to be made here.

First:  How about if we had Matt Damon play the Chastain character and Damon play Chastain's role? Then we have a movie!  Chastain should be playing the badass.  We've seen Damon do this time and time again.  Mc Guyermon has been done, and done.  Where is the girl power?  Chastains character isn't nearly pivitol enough for this movie for the quality actress that she is.

I can's suspent reality enough to not roll my eyes while watching.  I feel like more could have been done to suspend reality successfully if they'd spent more time building a 'fifty years in the future feeling'.  Instead we are just sort of just dumped is right into the mission.  However, this movie is LONG enough at 2 hours and 21 minutes.  For a movie that long there isn't enough character immersion.  We learn a little about Jessica Chastain character's family, but nothing that I detected about Damon's.  Where is the back story about what it would be like to have a husband or father stranded on Mars? Answer: Probably on the cutting room floor.  Other movies of similar length do a much better job of character development.  It felt like the purpose of the entire film was to show off the truly amazing special effects splashed through the film than any emotion building.
Great movie. I love movies that promote the sciences, critical thinking and best of humor. Great movie

Enjoyed this movie.  The science was off when the space suit was used as a transport device.  The writer forgot about inertia.  That scene would have  looked ok if the air was let out of a balloon instead of a space suit.

Ridley Scott is a great director, my favorite of all time being the original Alien movie. Most of his others are long, drawn out, and kind of boring actually. I was/am actually a fan of his (now deceased) brother's Tony Scott's work, as his directing eye imo is much more modern, exciting and diverse. He'll be missed. With the Martian you get one of those "I'm stuck here, alone, how will I survive, no one knows I'm here etc." kind of films. Which are so predictable. Much like better films like Castaway, Moon and Hours (Paul Walker). In this case some things are obvious, others aren't, which makes it work in some ways, and fail in others. The little twists are pretty good, but not enough to make it watchable another time around. Matt Damon is always good, but I like when he "interacts" with people a lot better. This film is far from Oscar worthy, and neither is The Revenant. I think they are/were pretty desperate for nominees this year.

The special effects are great, as Scott is very good at doing this. But the slow pace and overall lack of energy make this a one time viewing movie. Actually some of the best films are ones you've never heard of, watch the movie 99 Houses with Michael Shannon, about the housing market crash in 2010. No THAT's a great film, and his performance, along with the other young guy (who's name I don't know) is just superb. Along with a few other films I can't really rattle off right now. I hope Bridge Of Spies wins, that movie is leagues ahead of this one, in story and acting as well. Also Speilberg is still the master of the film industry. So this is OKAY, but really nothing special. Especially for any awards. I could think of many others I'd choose.

Note-One thing that I found clever and funny, was the secret meeting of Elron they had. Around a table, with Sean Bean from Lord Of The Rings actually there. As he is the flight director in the film. And for those who don't know, that's when they called the meeting to see the "One Ring" and argued about what to do with it, and Sean Bean wanted to use the Ring as a weapon, or a gift against the enemy. I thought he should have had more dialogue during that scene. But oh well, a great add in parody, I thought.

We sat down to watch half of this before bed but found our backs pressed to the couch for the duration of the mission (the movie's actually about ten minutes shorter than the stated run time of 2:24.) The diary-style narrative at first made me uncomfortable but towards the end I was thinking Matt Damon clearly deserves his recent best actor Oscar nomination.

This movie delivers what is expected, but nothing more. About the deepest message here is geeks are cool. Matt Damon is lacking in color in this role. This is like watching what would happen if your average high school quarterback/science nerd were to be stranded on Mars. The actors playing the crew are not convincing in their concern for the guy- that interplay is weak. All in all it had about the emotional depth of Deep Impact, and the same tinges of All-American nationalism. It's a feel good commercial for NASA. I gave it three stars because it is realistic and production value is excellent. It just leaves a lot on the table in terms of what could be explored here- they need to go read some Phillip K. Dick.

Like most of the rest of the reviewers I really liked the movie and knew I would buy the blu-ray when it came out.  Many people have done a much better job than I can telling about the movie.  This is a review about the Blu-ray/DVD/ HD Digital.

The movie was just as good as I remembered it. Picture quality and sound were excellent.

EXTRAS:
1. There is a short film, about ten minutes long that is supposed to be taking place seven years after Ares III returned home.  It is done as a news interview between Teddy, Mitch, and Vincent.  They argue both sides of the Rick Purcell maneuver and why Mitch sent it and why Teddy refused to. It was interesting and fun to watch.
2. Gag reel
3. Movie trailer
4. Two other trailers that I think were outtakes.  The one with some of the crew talking with the NASA psychiatrist after two weeks in an isolation chamber. The other one was were Mark talks to school children before Hemes leaves orbit.
5. One about casting
6. One about costumes
7. HD Digital - worked like a charm with my iTunes and Apple TV

Although an obvious remake of "Red Planet" and not as elegant, this is a great movie.  Nice tight writing and good acting all around including (surprisingly) Matt Daemon.  Excellent scenery and reasonable technology, though with the same flaws as the original.  Casting. would have been even better with Val Kilmer.  Great cameos by ...  well you will have to go see the movie :}

Finally, a science-fiction film that's both entertaining and intelligent!  It made you believe that a human being could survive in such a hostile environment, if he (or she) had the right knowledge and resources.  A welcome alternative to the Star Wars-type fantasy films.

I wasn't expecting much for some reason (maybe Ricky Gervais' Golden Globe ribbing influenced me) but I found myself really enjoying this movie.  It reminded me that there's a reason people like Matt Damon are movie stars, it's because they draw you in and make you interested in and concerned about what they're feeling, what they're experiencing and suffering through - while simultaneously making you forget that you're watching an actor in a movie.  I found the story compelling, albeit a bit unbelievable at times - its just barely good enough to allow you to suspend disbelief in favor of buying into its universe.  One critical side note: the casting of Kristin Wiig was a lousy idea - she spent years on SNL convincing us that every minute movement of her face was a comical affect. Now she and the producers of this movie expect us to be compelled by those same affects in a dramatic context - I personally found the idea absurd and it almost ruined the movie for me except for the fact that her role is relatively small.

Matt Damon puts on a great performance but there's something about movies that revolve around a stranded main character.  Just like Tom Hanks in Castaway, they wind up talking to themselves for most of the movie.  The dialog between the crew that left him behind is so weak that I preferred to watch Matt Damon talk to himself.  Seems like its targeted for a younger immature audience that might not notice the  characters that are supposed to be Astrophysicists and spaceship commanders are dopes---or at least their lines and acting portrays them as such.
I didn't find Jessica Chastain convincing as a Commander in this movie and come to think of it, didn't like her as a CIA agent in Zero Dark Thirty.  Formulaic, far-fetched, and it all works out in the end, hollywood style.  Good to watch with kids(I don't think there was any vulgarity--PG-13) if you need that least common denominator family movie with spoon fed drama they can grasp.

Fantastic movie and a welcome departure from the dystopian genre. The science and remaining close to plausible makes this film truly engaging.  Matt Damon was outstanding and the subtle humor made his character likeable and complex. The film is timely as the U.S. Government and many citizens have seemingly abandoned the value of science in understanding our world and making new discoveries. Seeing the people of the world rally to bring back one astronaut was moving. Maybe we should redirect our interest in reality tv and political posturing and find common ground in some sort of 21st century version of the once unifying nasa program thAt took us to the moon. Can you imagine a race to find alternative fuels that make fossil fuels obsolete and rid our planet of a fossil fuel economy? New jobs and less pollution, just imagine.

Wonderful movie, very well done. It's not an easy thing to do, acting (almost entirely) alone even for great actors and actresses, but it's very believable here. Even if he's 'only' out of contact for a certain number of days the isolation is still very much there: absent only at a few points: obviously at the start when he's not alone, when he first makes contact (sort of), and at the poignant 'ending' with the whole world watching. The story, the characters, the acting, it all fits together in a gripping movie that holds onto you all the way through.

One of the more overrated films I've seen in years. I enjoyed the first half hour  and computer-generated images of the Mars landscape were quite enchanting and  beautiful.  But this film bogged down in an overly long rescue mission that seemed dull in comparison with the one in Apollo 13 ( a truly great movie). The rescue was as implausible as it was boring and the characters at Houston control seemed to be phoning in their perfomances. Also all  the cheering down on Earth at venues from Times Square to China seemed like scenes from a dozen other space movies -- quite banal.  Also, it strained credulity to see the Chinese cheering on this U.S. rescue effort of an American astronaut with the same intensity as die-hard Mets fans cheering on their team during the playoffs.

As an aside, the foreign Hollywood journalists behind the Golden Globes should be deported for putting this film in the comedy category so it could get more awards. There was nothing funny about a film that took itself way too seriously, unless you liked that stale overused running joke related to Matt Damon's character being captive to disco music. In short, this overhyped film had me seeing red (planet.)

The movie was also overly looooong, I think like 155 mins? All of the times that Matt had to explain to the audience what he was doing ("science the s*** out of this", etc) became annoying and silly, but I guess constant explanation is sort of mandatory for today's ADHD populace...

Lastly, none of the characters are likable, and after about 60 mins you literally don't care if Damon's character survives or not and just want the whole thing to be over with.
