Things get crazy fast in this space movie. Or so you think by the first 3 minutes or so. Not quite. This is a 2+ hour movie, 1.5 of which seem to be a montage of Matt Damon growing potatoes and/or vlogging about growing potatoes. A lot of the plot devices and terminology seem watered down for a broader audience, which I can't say is good or bad, but I typically roll my eyes to. I rolled my eyes so much I got a headache. Childish Gambino is in this movie for some reason. Matt Damon looks ridiculous with a beard. He also signs his name as he communicates with earth, just to be sure there are no miscommunications. Moving on...

I was ready to give this about a 2 star rating, when suddenly, the climax came. All of a sudden, the pacing was frenetic, the odds were slim to none of this elaborate plan working, and all of the pieces came together. I was glued. I was invested. Things got pretty crazy out there. Then, there was a really awkwardly misplaced scene at the end to wrap it all up. "Any questions?"

There was really no filler as the story moved along very well and kept you in suspense for the entire movie. If you liked movies like Armageddon, Gravity and similar then you will really like The Martian. I won't say how the movie ends but I liked the entire movie, beginning, middle and end. If you are a stickler for accurate science then you might take issue with some parts of the movie.

Matt Damon did a great acting job, but this was one of the schlockiest movies I've seen in a long time--kind of a throwback to the "glory days" movies of the USA, over the top portrayal of good old American ingenuity to confront any problem and solve it--and all incredibly unbelievable, with a HORRIBLE DISCO/ABBA SOUNDTRACK. It's reactionary.
What the heck was Ridley Scott thinking? I am embarrassed by the film's inauthenticity (No one has real potatoes in outer space: all food is packaged, and the rescue was just plain silly and utterly unbelievable).
But if Scott was looking to make a film which would whip folks into a frenzy of teary patriotism, this is a good film to achieve that end.  I'm sorry, but I hate movies with such blatant and almost jingoistic manipulation of the public's emotions. I know people will hate this review because they want to stay in the warm, fuzzy glow of "everything's great" which the movie produces.

I would have given this movie 4 or 5 stars if they didn't resort to intentionally getting the science and physics wrong in parts of the movie in order to create reason for the story to have an unforeseen possible disaster so that Mark would have to be left behind. The NASA character that said they can remove the windows in the space capsule and just cover that area with a plastic tarp even pointed out that the atmosphere  was so thin that it wouldn't matter. What I am pointing out is that due to the very thin CO2 atmosphere the high winds on Mars will stir up dust but would not have enough force to tip over the spacecraft the crew was taking off in or blow a antenna off it's ground anchoring.  There are other examples of this in the movie thats just put in to create some excitement. This sound like writer's block or Hollywood meddling. Another glaring mistake was Mark making fertilizer out of the other crew members feces without first sterilizing it. That's a good way to get very sick or dead. My point is that this movie was promoted as being one that gets the science right and I think with a little more effort on the writer's part that could have been true.

The movie is great. 5 stars. The rest of this review is about the special features, for those interested.

The special features were underwhelming. Here they are:

Gag Reel - 7m 34s of typical gag reel.
Ares III: Farewell - 3m 36s of "Mark Watney" interviewing the "crew" prior to their departure to Mars.
The Right Stuff - 3m 21s of a "psychologist" interviewing the "crew" prior to departure.
Ares: Our Greatest Adventure - 3m 39s of Neil deGrasse Tyson doing a "Cosmos" bit in 2035 about the Ares mission.
Leave Your Mark - 1m 04s Under Armour commercial staring Mark Watney.
Bring Him Home - 1m 36s of people rooting for Watney's successful return all over the world.

The first 4 are entertaining enough. The last 2 are worthless. All but the first can currently be found on "ARES: live" youtube channel.

No behind the scenes or making of. No interviews with cast, director, screenwriter, author, or anybody at all. No commentary. :(

I would rank it as my top choice in fictional space films, even exceeding that of "Gravity".

Riveting and heart warming all rolled into one well written script. Bravery, ingenuity, and the need to explore, are all human traits that have made it possible for humans to reach out beyond the known for the unknown. The dangers that exist in these endeavors are why NASA has for so long avoided manned missions beyond low Earth orbit and instead have used robot's. This movie stitches all of these opposing views of operations into one workable story line that is sure to keep you on the edge of your seat.

This, in my opinion, was the best movie to come out in recent memory. Of course, with Ridley Scott at the helm, I had no doubts really. Matt Damon really shined in what was mostly a solo performance. However, some of the other actors were exceptional as well. Jeff Daniels for example was perfectly cast. Visually, this movie was stunning. Sort of combined the sleek modern day film making with the old school Alien vibe. I found the story to be completely engaging and immersive, and I hardly noticed that 2 1/2 hours had passed watching this. Also, they get the little things right regarding the science behind what they portray in this movie. That attention to even the most minute of details really pushed this movie over the top.
Definitely a must watch movie if there ever was one.

This movie was pretty good! I love sci-fi, space movies, thrillers and the works. It's about a man who accidently gets left on Mars after an emergency evacuation and how he manages to stay alive despite his limited resources. But using his brain and basic physics he's able to find away. Matt Damon did an excellent job acting in the movie as he usually does. I loved his characters funny sense of humor and good attitude during the grim situation he was in. It keeps you on your toes during some of the suspenseful scenes. The only thing that disappointed me was some of the special effects could have been done a little better. But regardless of that is was still a must see. I would recommend this movie if you like sci-fi, space movies, or suspenseful movies. Its a good watch!

5 Stars.  I don't know the last time I've given a 5 star rating to anything, especially a movie.  I haven't watched a movie this great in at least 10 years, least to say I was pretty impressed!  Not only is the storyline great, and the filming is pretty good, but they're also actual science to this which makes it even better.  My wife actually told me to pause the film in the middle of it so she could ask me if The Martian was based on a true story!  She said that she was pretty sure that she would have heard if we sent a manned mission to Mars, but the story is so believable that it seems likely that it had already happened.  I have to admit she's right.  While I know the entire story is science fiction, there's a lot more science than fiction to it.  It all seems so real, that I found myself thinking about the movie for days after I saw it.  So like I said, this is a great movie, and will go down in history as one of the classics.  WATCH IT!!

The setup on this is just plain stupid.  With a massive storm coming, they go outside for no apparent reason.  One of them gets killed.  The whole mission is jeopardized.  The commander would face a court-martial for doing this.  I was so disgusted by this that I called Amazon and had them cancel the order.  In a theater they have a captive audience but the stupidity of this opening would still register.
4/9 My wife ordered this from Netflix without being aware of my disgust at the opening.  After that it's not too bad, but now we're at the point where the airlock blows off.  The reason it blows off is because in a nearby previous scene someone says "if nothing goes wrong."  There is no real-world reason why it would blow off, so this is another black mark.  If the Yakuza reviewed this picture someone would be missing a finger.  The only reason why someone would float this out into the world like this is arrogance and contempt for the audience.

"The Martian" has its moments, but it is unrealistic at key points, and ultimately overrated.  The film (as well as the book) missed an opportunity to effectively explore the range of human emotions that would no doubt confront someone left behind on a desolate planet, and the result is a one-dimensional character that is difficult to care about.  This was perhaps the most disappointing aspect of the story.  Since all the other characters are also one-dimensional, however, this was easy to overlook.  It's time for science fiction to dispense with the hackneyed young, eccentric genius character, and offer audiences something more substantial (to give just one example among many, the millennial from the JPL who is too brilliant to know he is pitching his (utterly obvious) "slingshot" idea to the Administrator of NASA is a scene sequence that is nothing short of  ridiculous).

If you can suspend disbelief for almost 2-1/2 hours, and can lower your expectations far enough, then you'll like "The Martian".  If, however, you ask a bit more from science fiction (or just films/books more generally), then the experience is a mediocre one.  You're not asked to think too much in this film, and as long as you can accept that, the film is fine.

I was interested in the movie primarily because I loved the book by Andy Weir.  Often when a book I like is made into a film I am disappointed in the corresponding film as it either veers to far away from the original story line of the book or changes or eliminates key characters.  In the case of The Martian, I was pleasantly surprised how closely the movie followed the book.  Obviously the film makers did make changes, especially with regard to the roles of the Hermes crew during the rescue scene at the end of the film.  On balance, they kept it close enough that I  just sat back and enjoyed the film without wondering why they changed so many things from the book I enjoyed.  The other thing I think the film got right was the casting, especially Matt Damon as Mark Watney.  He exactly captured the humorous stoicism of the Watney character from the book.  If you loved the book you'll enjoy this movie.

I saw the film in the cinema when it came out, and I recall subtitles then, but they left them off the DVD copy.  It did result in my family momentarily believing that I had become fluent in another language when I "translated" that portion of the film for them based on what I remembered from seeing it the first time which was kind of fun.  However, I think maybe the production company was in too much of a  rush to get the DVDs to market and overlooked this detail.

The Martian is a rousing-good SF adventure/survival story, Cast Away on a desert planet instead of deserted island. I give it high marks for scientific accuracy and general credibility, although a couple of details need to be overlooked, and a couple of willing suspensions of disbelief are called for, if the film is to be fully enjoyed. (Regarding my use of the term "SF" rather than "sci-fi": If you don't understand the difference, watch "The Martian", "Gravity", "Avatar", or "Interstellar" and then any of the "Star Wars" films and you'll understand.)

First, the most implausible conceit regards the central crisis of the story: That a Martian storm ever generates wind speeds such that the thin atmospheres momentum would be enough to topple the Mars missions upright return ship and require an unplanned termination of the mission on literally a few minutes' noticeor, more directly, that NASA would ever make the crews ascent rocket vulnerable to a storm whose intensity is such that it has more than a vanishingly small chance of occurring in that spot within a length of time equal to the missions ground stay. (No reveals hereyouve all seen the trailers, and the event occurs very early in the film, too early, in factsee below.) Or am I wrong, and did NASA areologists check off on this point?

Second, the Ares mission base is downright magnificent, as are the ground vehicles and the Hermes spaceship that transfers the crew from Earth to Mars and back. The cost of the base and the mission, in current dollars, would be in the hundreds of billions, and as we learn, this mission, Ares III, is what appears to be the third in a series of at least six planned missions. That one nation, even the U.S., could devote this kind of money to Mars missions in any plausible 21st-Century geopolitical and global economic scenario is beyond belief. Its something that we SF fans and science supporters can only fantasize about.

Third, as we soon learn, the planned mission length on the surface is a mere 31 days! A mission costing a good chunk of a trillion dollars, and lasting a couple of years overall, for a single month at destination? A manned Mars landing mission involving one or two astronauts in a basic shelter might plausibly last for this short a period, perhaps even less. But for the magnitude of effort, and the cost, of the relatively huge installation that is Ares III, a single month seems ridiculously short. Worse, it would appear (since the unmanned preparatory landings of the Ares IV mission have already been made thousands of km away) that the Ares III installation was only intended to be used once. So, hundreds of billions, perhaps a trillion, dollars for a mission with a robust base and big surface vehicles, all of which were meant to be used just once and only for a month. That definitely does not add up, nor even resonate with the fantasies of fans of human planetary exploration. For us, its a gratingly unconscionable, and improbable, waste of money, resources, effort, and opportunityand completely lacking in credibility. Just for starters, if a single astronaut can science the s*** outta this and cobble together a potato garden that will sustain him, NASA could certainly have provided a mission with the capability of sustaining a crew for a year or two. (Leave aside the amusing thought that NASA would have sent bins of fresh spuds, rather than dehydrated powder or freeze-dried slices. This is what dramatic license is for!)

But besides the survival story, the saga of the rescue mission (which may or may not be successfulno spoilers hereor involve the tragedy of the sort that desperate rescue missions often seem to require) makes for great tech-oriented SF as well as grippingly tense high adventure, especially since its a given that that sort of thing never goes smoothly. The intellectual flowering of the rescue plan(s) and their multinational implementation are superbly well done, though the idea that verifying the practicality of one idea required a lone wolf to poach time on NASA's lovely Pleiades supercomputer cluster (an actual thing) is a bit more dramatic licensethe calculations could have been done on a laptop.

The production values are lush, and the sets and props breathtaking. NASA personnel must be drooling with envy at the thought of having such technologically munificent apparatus. Id like to know where the inspiration for just the appearance and the phenomenal detail of the equipment, the low-pressure suits, and the interiors and equipment of the Ares base and the Hermes came from; its utterly convincing. The photography, and/or CGI, of the surface of Marsfrom a foot or two away to stunning landscapes spanning milesare jawdropping and totally acceptable as the real thing. I imagine they were constructed at least in part from NASA data and images from Mars, although the credits reveal a large second-unit operation in Jordan, perhaps at the Wadi Ramm of "Lawrence of Arabia". Im going to reveal myself as a dinosaur, but I only have to think back to my adolescence to remember how laughably primitive, even then, spacecraft and alien landscapes looked in SF movies and TV shows.

If theres one non-technical complaint, or objection to something other than implausible scenarios, its in the development of the characters. Its disappointing that this SF tale is so predictably shallow in this respect. The Martian bears striking parallels to Cast Awayan accident stranding an individual who must rely on his wits and his scarce resources to stay alive in a spare and unforgiving environment while hoping for a rescue that comes to look less and less likely, then a desperate, do-or-die leap into the unknown. They both even have a coda following the resolution (however that may occur) of the crisis, and are almost exactly the same length at about 2h 23 min. But Cast Away devoted a significant length of screen time at the beginning to establish the personality and backstory of the principal character, and gave him depth and humanity. Not that Matt Damon didn't do an excellent job of putting spirit and character into the persona of Mark Watney, especially through the device of a video diary that the marooned astronaut keeps from Day 1 (or Sol 1) of his ordeal, but Id have appreciated having 20 minutes or so cannibalized from other sequences and devoted to developing some foundation for Watney and at least one of the other principals, specifically the mission commander (whom, being played by the luminous Jessica Chastain, I wanted to know EVERYTHING about, and see way more of!)

There are interesting complexities and subtleties that I haven't hinted at, things that give extra dimensions to the story than mere technological crises and inventiveness, creations of talented writers and an inspired director as well as many fine performances on the part of an outstanding cast (Sean Bean kind of does a Ned Stark with stolid heroism while more powerful people of lesser character remain unscathed), and many more reasons to see it than to find fault with it. Do so, and then contemplate what NASA could accomplish as a partner with ESA, Russia, China, Japan, and India in a non-confrontational world where half of the economic activity didn't go to the military and welfare.

I read the book so I always have a bit of trouble when the screenplay writr chooses not to follow the book.  I didn't think that they needed to change the ethnicities of the characters since it was already very multicultural.  While I understand the desire to complete the circle of the commander"losing her man" and then "reclaiming her man", that's not the commander's job.  The book appropriately addressed this, so it seem contrived to have the commander risk her entire crew to go get Mark herself.  That being said, the acting was great and the visuals were very nice and the story flowed well.  Read the book for the full effect of a first person narrative.  It was brilliant.

Typical Hollywood production. Short on character development, long on flash. Line delivery seemed very rehearsed and plastic, casting was stereotypical and uninteresting.
  Directing was cookie cutter right down to the cutaway's of people smiling and nodding yes. The Ares III Hermes crew seemed more like a bunch of corporate yuppies then real astronauts and scientists (not like the book). Very flat and weak character interaction at NASA ground control (again not like the book). The Mars imagery was verygood but Mark Watney's story line and resourcefulness was nothing compared to the original story.  Poor editing as the film was hard to follow and important informational content was distilled down into a flashy, meaningless short montage with incredibly predictable music.  However, good way to spend a rainy afternoon if you have nothing better to do. Hard to understand from guy who did Blade Runner, Black Hawk Down and Alien. Don't read the book first, you'll be very disappointed when you see the movie.

We rented this last night on the recommendation of a friend who told us that it was a "great story" and "action packed." Unfortunately I didn't find the story to be anything special and, to me, much of it was the opposite of action packed. While there were some interesting and innovative sequences in the film, too much of it was predictable, dragged along a snail's pace with few surprises and didn't have enough substance to hold my undivided attention. I made it through to the end, which I had been looking forward to well before it actually came - they could have left twenty minutes to half-hour on the cutting room floor without adversely affecting the story - but I doubt I'll be recommending it to friends or watching it again

I rarely give a movie 5 stars. Even if I enjoy it, it is usually rated a 4 star move. The difference here is that it is very engaging from beginning to end. I have a short attention span and didn't expect to watch it all because of the length. I mainly rented it for my husband. I watched every minute and it was suspenseful and never boring. What put it over the top was that it had no raunchy sex or raunchy language. It disappoints me to spend money on a movie and have to turn it off after a few minutes because it has unnecessary foul language and content. A truly good movie doesn't need that and that is what puts this movie at a five star level for me.

Overall it was entertaining look at how Mark Watney was left behind on Mars and found a way to survive for nearly a year and a half waiting to be rescued.  Worth the rent!!

Awesome movie!  Very well performed.  Well-balanced cast with outstanding leading role by Matt Damon. He truly showed his intelligence and talent in this film.  As I watched it, I thought, "Obviously this is the same guy from 'Good Will Hunting.'" The Blu-ray imaging was superb.  We regretted not seeing this in theater, but we still thoroughly enjoyed it at home.

I recently read an article that calculated how much money it would have cost (in today's dollars) to rescue Matt Damon from his movies if they were in real life.  Apparently the government would have had to spend upwards of $900,000,000 to rescue him from his movies to date.  It's a good thing Matt's worth it, because a lesser actor would have had his *ss left on Mars.  To give the word of mouth summary of the Cliff's Notes, this movie was fantastic.  At one point I was worried that Matt might become a bit unhinged and start talking to a piece of sporting equipment, but no, he kept it together and put in a great performance.  I do have to say, however, that the visuals of the red Mars are almost enough to upstage him, because they are exactly what a layman like myself imagines the barren deserts to look like.  All in all, The Martian is a fun and surprisingly uplifting movie, following in the tradition of other fun space movies that include The Right Stuff and even Space Cowboys.  And once again, Matt Damon put in a performance that reminds the viewer just why we keep rescuing him.

A very good movie with minor scientific inaccuracies such as the wind storm (Mars has 1 % the atmosphere as earth), no protection from solar and cosmic radiation (Mars's magnetic field is dead), and water production (the soil is frozen, no need for rocket fuel production).  Of course, all movies are based on some form of drama, such as man against man, or man against nature.  Of course, this is really about man using science to stay alive, while battling one of the most inhospitable places for humans - space. The pressure on Mars is 150 that of earth (14.7 psi), and the pressure on Mars would kill a human in approximately one minute, when fully exposed.  It was interesting to see the pressure, temperature, and oxygen icons displayed on his instruments.  Very spaceadelic, indeed. I also noticed how China helped the NASA in this film, but this is inaccurate, due to obvious security concerns, and from a personal nature, their technology is horrible, and they still produce junk, and I think it would hamper our rescue efforts if indeed this was the case. Another aspect of the movie that was right on, was the structure of government, with bureaucrats running the show, like the Alpha Male, (Jeff Daniels - excellent performance) bowing to his superiors and so on down the line.  I also liked the young astrodynamics student, with no social skills, trying to explain his theory for the rescue attempt. Overall, a definite go see, and it will keep you on the edge of your seat the entire time you are viewing it.

Small spoiler alert ('cause it's so early in the movie):

I mean, you already know Matt Damon is going to be stranded on Mars. Damon is impaled by a piece of antenna in the stomach area. (Not too thick.  Think automobile antenna.)  He pulls it out, does surgery on himself, and staples himself closed.  One might expect some damage due to having his stomach punctured, but its strictly comic book stuff.  Next scene it's like he was never injured.  No infection, no nothin'.

All the scenes are like that.

The ONLY reason I did not award one star is that he was  NOT stranded from doing something (like grab some scientific equipment) while everyone else is urging him to get back to the ship.

Ridley Scott is a very creative director .He has a boat load of wonderful ,bankable films in his resume which I have enjoyed immensely. The primary and secondary cast members are proven actors ,also with great resumes to flash. The writing staff has created a very exciting,thrilling script. Just like most of the critics have expressed The Martian is 2 plus hours of thrills and great entertainment. It has the whole gambit of human emotions. Lets start with the obvious emotions. Survival instinct, guilt, self sacriface, desire not to give up on life where there is breath, and the need for cooperation among competing groups. There is also and a dab of political intrigue.
HOWEVER, I don't see this in the world that I am living in. NOW let me do something I like to do when watching a film. I like to see if there is anything in the film I just watched that I can relate to. In the last week I have watched 2 massive stock markets representing 100's of millions of peoples quality of life drop like stones. Where is the cooperation among these two great countries. Yes The Martian is a movie which isn't reality but If you ask people about what this film projects we are back to the issues of sacriface, survival and Cooperation. This is art not immitating life. As this film is a feel good movie in that the human spirit can endure almost anything and overcome the implausible. It would be wonderful if this is an accurate or even a hopeful representation of how it is. It is true that there are individuals that have overcome extreme adversity in spite of obstacles placed before them. That is similar to this exciting film. In reality for most of us the obstacles that are presented to which we must overcome many times are insurmountable.  Not because the desire isn't there but the cooperation among the outside forces just are not there. Apolla 13 with Tom Hanks also showed what can be down when we work together to accomplish what seems to be the impossible. WE NEED FILMS LIKE THESE TO REMIND US OF WHAT CAN BE DONE WHEN WE REACH DOWN AND FIND THAT EXTRA MEASURE THAT WILL GET US THROUGH. IN EACH CASE THERE IS STILL THE NEED FOR THE OUTSIDE INFLUENCES TO GET US THERE BY COOPERATION,COMPASSION, AND THE WILLINGNESS TO EXTEND OURSELVES . KEEPING THE GOAL IN THE FOREFRONT WITHOUT REGARD TO POLITICS OR WHO WILL FINANCIAL BENEFIT AND WHO WILL SUFFER AS A RESULT OF THESE ACTIONS. IN The Martian everyone is focused upon one goal. Save the stranded botanist without regard to the consequences of their actions. If life was only like this film.
It is a film of great entertainment and if you care to look deeper a film that can challenge you to see what really controls the survival of other human beings. I allowed Scott and Goddard to let me see beyond the story on the screen and make the transfer to real survival issues. I could have just taken the film for a feel good ride. But there is so much more in our lives that seems to be out of our control. Just because we want to survive does't mean that we will. Our protanganist decides "I will make it no matter what it takes " But we would be very naive to believe that will alone is enough. Even with his skills and determination he is doomed unless outside forces come into play. As stated earlier these forces are from first those nearest him. This spreads to outside agencies and then to other nations. The world awaits his rescue. And we the watcher are cheering and hopeful too. We are not on Mars but we also are stranded with either disease , financial burdens that are not of our making or severe family issues. Can these be worked out with just desire and a willingness to fight on. Of course not. We run into obstacles that cannot be overcome. The sum of our lives has come down to the willingness of medical centers. insurance companies ,legislation or just horrible diseases which we find ourselves no matter how we fight on we cannot overcome without help. So it comes down to THE MARTIAN is a fairy tale with few exceptions. Maybe that is what we need. So I root along and try to stay hopeful for all of us.(I know this was a little heavy review/comment but some films just bring us there as this did for me).

I found "The Martian" to be thoroughly enjoyable.  I didn't get to see it in the theater but did watch the Blu-ray version as soon as it came out two days ago; and it exceeded all my expectations.  The fundamental plot was reminiscent of the classic "Robinson Crusoe on Mars," where an astronaut has survive alone on Mars until rescue comes, although of course the older film predated a lot of scientific knowledge we have now and didn't have nearly the budget or CGI technology.  Of course there are a few technical nits such as the saturation of color and force of wind on Mars, but nothing that threw me out of the story.  (For me, that's saying a lot.  I spent more than three decades as an engineer in manned space flight at the Johnson Space Center in fight crew training, crew systems, and EVA development.  The technical accuracy of this film knocked my socks off.)

All the cast delivered great performances with a minimal amount of the inevitable poplib politics that could easily have spoiled the film.  Computer-generated imagery was integrated seamlessly; I really couldn't see where the practical sets ended and CGI started, though of course I'm sure there was a lot of CGI through the film.  Cinematography and editing were really outstanding work; I didn't even think about them until the story was over.

Sadly, the portrayal of internal NASA meetings where you see risk-averse bureaucrats making decisions that the crew and engineers disagree with was all too representative of my own real-life work experience.  The notion of a new space race was more of a stretch from current reality than my mind could cope with, but I was willing to accept it for the sake of a great story.  This is science fiction, after all.

On a personal note, Sean Bean's appearance, character, and demeanor in this film kept reminding me of my old boss, Bob Overmyer, who flew on STS-5 and STS-51B.  The resemblance was uncanny.  If anyone ever makes a film about Overmyer's life and career (which could be great cinema), and if Bean can do an American jarhead pilot's accent, he'd be a perfect choice for the role.

Odd that everyone is raving about the acting in this film. Yes, it is a good idea to watch the survival of a lone man on another planet, but the acting and the dialogue are so flat line and the actors seem so uninvolved with this read-through of a script that after a while all the fancy special effects even get more interesting than the story. Some are remarking how far better Andy Weirs book is in comparison, but even Ridley Scott has slow moments in trying to keep this space venture airborne.

The story (brief as it is)  During a manned mission to Mars, Astronaut Mark Watney (Matt Damon) is presumed dead after a fierce storm and left behind by his crew. But Watney has survived and finds himself stranded and alone on the hostile planet. With only meager supplies, he must draw upon his ingenuity, wit and spirit to subsist and find a way to signal to Earth that he is alive. Millions of miles away, NASA and a team of international scientists work tirelessly to bring "the Martian" home, while his crewmates concurrently plot a daring, if not impossible, rescue mission. As these stories of incredible bravery unfold, the world comes together to root for Watney's safe return.

The cast includes such winning actors as Michael Pea, Chiwetel Ejiofor, Jeff Daniels, Jessica Chastain, Kate Mara, Kristen Wiig, Sean Bean and others but there is little to no development of their characters until the very end. Jump on if you must see every movie that is nominated for best film/actor but be aware this tale goes on for well past 2 hours in length. Grady Harp, January 16

"The Martian" is brilliant! This is how the story goes: During a manned mission to Mars, Astronaut Mark Watney is presumed dead after a fierce storm and left behind by his crew. But Watney has survived and finds himself stranded and alone on the hostile planet. With only meager supplies, he must draw upon his ingenuity, wit and spirit to subsist and find a way to signal to Earth that he is alive. Millions of miles away, NASA and a team of international scientists work tirelessly to bring "the Martian" home, while his crewmates concurrently plot a daring, if not impossible, rescue mission. As these stories of incredible bravery unfold, the world comes together to root for Watney's safe return.

The cast led by Matt Damon (in a superb performance as Mark Watney) is brilliant. The directing by Ridley Scott (who also produced) is brilliant. The screenplay (based on Andy Weir's novel) by Drew Goddard (who also executive produced) is brilliant.

The music by Harry Gregson-Williams is brilliant. The cinematography by Dariusz Wolski is brilliant. The film editing by Pietro Scalia is brilliant. The casting by Carmen Cuba & Nina Gold is brilliant. The production design by Arthur Max is brilliant. The costume design by Janty Yates is brilliant. The art direction by Jonathan Houlding, Mark Swain, Huw Arthur, Robert Cowper, Monika Esztan, Marc Homes, Samy Keilani, Jason Knox-Johnston, Laszlo Rajk, Phil Sims, Stefan Speth & Matt Wynne is brilliant. The set decoration by Celia Bobak & Zoltan Horvath, set dressings by Pal Csicsman, Tamas Gal, Tibor Gaal, Zsolt Kovacs, Csaba Mitku, Imre Sandor, Tamas Simon, Viktor Bakos & Gabor Papp is brilliant. The stunts coordinated by Rob Inch is brilliant. The special effects supervised by Neil Corbould & Steven Warner is brilliant. The visual effects supervised by Sara Bennett, Justin Cornish, James D. Fleming, Anders Langlands, Chris Lawrence, Tim Ledbury, Mohen Leo, Brooke Lyndon-Stanford, Adam McInnes and Richard Stammers & coordinated by Tom Barber, Jack Daniels, Stanislas de Lesquen, Deeps Hargunani, Peter Hartless, Geraint Hixson, Terez Koncz, Miranda Middlewood, Will Newis, Sherin Padayatty, Soujanya Pentyala, Ingrid Pons, Diana Roldan, Jane Simons, Kath Smith, Mariangela Suma, Timothy Trimmings, Nadia Volodina, Toby White & Alysia Wildman is brilliant.

This is a brilliant, well-crafted and entertaining film that is well-done. Matt Damon gives one of his best performances as Mark Watney and his supporting cast led by Jessica Chastain (as Melissa Lewis) is brilliant. Ridley Scott has made one of his best films to date. This is one of the best films of the last year and one of the best films of the recently done fall season. This is also an awards contender and rightfully so, too.

I read the book a few months ago and really liked it. I was a bit hesitant about the movie because the book has so much detail, I knew the movie just could not have it all. It'd take a 4-6 hour movie for that, but folks with short attention spans kind of messes it up for those of us who want to wallow in every little detail.

Nevertheless, Ridley Scott managed to pull in enough of the information to make an excellent movie. In the vein of 2001: Space Odyssey rather than Star Wars, this isn't a kid film. Take the young 'uns to something else. However, if you're a serious SF loving adult, this is just right.

And anybody bad-mouthing Matt Damon can go F**k themselves, as Mark Watney would say.

Many recent UHD Bluray titles will be unconverted from 2k masters and won't actually be 4k. This is simply because many recent films shot digitally were not shot at 4k or above resolution but only 2k. Even many films that have been shot on true 4k or even film, only had visual effects and post production done at 2k. Fox Home Entertainment has already admitted that The Martian 4k release is being made from 2k assets.

https://twitter.com/FinnJ/status/686724096059559937

The Martian does not currently exist in 4k, stick with the 1080p version for now.

Please do your homework before purchasing "4k" Blurays.

I gave it 3 stars because it was entertaining in a PG, feel good sort of way. It was reminiscent of Armageddon and Independence Day in that the solutions to many of their rescue plans were a bit too unbelievable and it was just ripe with cliches. Some of which being the cold government official concerned only with his career, the overly attractive astronauts, the world powers that put aside their differences and expose government secrets to one another to save a life (complete with the handshake of friendship at the end), and the oversimplification of math and physics despite countless variables. It was hard to take this movie seriously. Maybe I wasn't intended to? If you are a fan of the "stranded in space" story line I would recommend checking out "Moon" (2009) or "Love" (2011)

Strangely, some parts had futuristic tech and some parts had very low tech. HECK, even Nikita and iPhone have voice recognition/dictation for texting. Instead, we watch these guys typing messages and reading them aloud. Come...on... And then there was the constant Red Planet. I should have known better. Ridley Scott has not been creating interesting stuff. Case in point: PROMETHEUS: BORING. Nothing to really like here. All very predictable, especially if you see the trailer first. This is the soonest any science fiction movie has been blown out of the noisy vacuum by Science.  Many such movies were only trashed for their scientific mistakes decades after they appeared.  NASA just announced that water is in the soil, and just heat to extract.  Super windstorms do not happen on Mars with its thin atmosphere--certainly not ones of 1000 mph hurricane speed.  Read almost any encyclopedia of sci-fi and you will find pseudo-learned critiques of such 1950's classics as RXM.  Most of those critics had not seen the movie-in-question in years and so got many plot points horribly wrong.  But now we have a new movie-- I just watched the 2-D Blu-ray-- whose director and star DARE US to disagree that THE MARTIAN is a Great ORIGINAL Story.  Well, apparently those Hollywood insiders never saw ROBINSON CRUSOE ON MARS or RED PLANET or any of a dozen or so other Mars invasion movies.  Okay, maybe they just did not know of written science fiction, such as FIRST ON MARS whose original cover art shows an astronaut riding a self-made bicycle across the Martian surface.  Yes, things break, but here we have Hollywood puffery taken to new heights with Matt Damon in the EXTRAS and the script tagged with I'M GONNA SCIENCE THE SH*T OUT OF THIS PLANET.  Sorry guys, all 10,000 workers in several different countries, but the real Mars is a lot less bright and colorful.  It took years for NASA to admit that they too faked the Red Planet to look a lot redder in the first photos from Viking so that The Public would not be disappointed.  (I worked on the Viking landing radar.)  But that is okay.  RXM put a red filter in front of the projector during the Mars sequences.  (The clouds looked gorgeous.)  I have no gripe with the incredible CGI and wirework and cameras--GoPro is fantastic, I find as a user--and appreciate the tropes and memes too.  Every Mars movie has to have Comic Relief in the form of a joking sidekick.  Must have one or more beautiful women, smart and now in the Commander rank.  (RXM was way ahead of its time with its female chemist onboard who was better at math than the Captain.)  Finally, this is a movie whose main shock is NOT that Murphy's Law still works in space, but that bragging from The Star and The Director are so in-your-face.  Maybe Murphy's Law is in effect there too:  if anything CAN go wrong, it WILL go wrong, and at the WORST POSSIBLE TIME.  This is no 2001 A SPACE ODYSSEY:  the sound effects of rockets in space really go back to the ancient-movie scientific error of LOUD ROARING SOUNDS TRAVEL IN VACUUM.  No, not an OOPS, just homage to STAR WARS to let the audience know what to think.  But at least there is no giggling unseen aliens and/or discovered lost civilizations.  2001 went against the author's wishes about having an evil computer on board.  Here the author of the book is pleased-as-punch at what Hollywood has done.  Admittedly, it would be hell to go back, as was done with CLOSE ENCOUNTERS, and NOT fix things that are bad science but just tack on a new ending.  But maybe the Studio could edit the B.S. about Science and the Great Original Story.  Another possibility is that THE MARTIAN might be sued.  It happened to ALIEN and K-PAX years ago.  Settle out of court, anyone?

Most disappointing is that there are no deleted scenes. I know a lot of footage ended up on the cutting room floor with this film, and that is was cut short for commercial reasons. I'd really like to see some of what we missed (beyond the obligatory gag reel). Maybe Scott is defending the integrity of his cut, or didn't want to include footage with missing or incomplete effects, and I understand that. But still sad. I hope we'll get a director's cut or deluxe edition down the line. But don't let that stop you buying this version. Brilliant movie! Although I thought the previews for this movie looked interesting, I really had no desire to go out of my way to see it in the theater. It had pretty good reviews so we decided to give it a shot. We were both super impressed by how good it was! It wasn't a slow starter, it definitely pulls you in quick! Read the book too, but maybe do it after watching the movie; part of me thinks I'd have enjoyed the movie a little more if I didn't know what was missing while watching it.

This film is Ridley Scott's ode to science, a romance between man and science and what the duo can achieve when great minds work together to solve human problems. Mark Watney isn't just an astronaut he is the combination of everything the human mind and spirit has ever conquered. This is a smart, at times funny, harrowing and always awe inspired. The film is clear that it is not god or religion that will save us but our collective knowledge, applied sciences and human cooperation, this is highlighted in a scene where our man Watney is examining a wooden crucifix, left by a fellow crew member, not because he was thinking of god, or praying for god to get him out of his dire situation but because the object turns out to be useful for one of his life saving projects.  The characters are rich and nuanced and the actors are perfectly cast. Matt Damon put on one of his best performances since Bourne Identity.  The film is hopeful and optimistic in time when many films dealing with humanity point to apocalypse.

Deceptive packaging when it comes to describing the digital copy.  With all my other movie purchases where you get UltraViolet and iTunes options, I have been able to redeem the code in the packaging for both formats (future proofing the purchase). This packages shows that you claim your code for iTunes and UltraViolet, but what it doesn't say on the packaging is that you can only redeem it for one. Once you put that code in, it looks like you can select your preferred providers like iTunes and Vudu, but in reality, it only activates one of those (look like mutliselect on the mobile site, but it is more like radio button options) and you are out of luck for the other format.  Even their terms and conditions are vague about it, saying you can redeem the code once.  I redeem the code once for the other studio's movies and apply those streaming rights to my accounts.  Here, once means pick one format and live with that forever.

I just finished watching this film and it is like a breath of fresh air after all the Science Fiction films I have watched lately. Science Fiction asks the question "What if ?" and proceeds to show what happens then. We have had few films that really explore the reality of space travel based on what we currently know scientifically. "Red Planet"  and "Mission to Mars" provide elements that are used in this film to good effect. The escape from Mars via a spacecraft that was there from a previous mission and the rendezvous and capture of the same by a passing space craft. The cinematography is excellent.

I take a moment to salute "David Bowie" whose song "Star man" is one of the non-disco tracks used in the movie. It is prophetic that he just passed away yesterday and here his music is in the first DVD I watch after seeing his obituary in the paper.

I don't want to spoil the viewers experience by revealing the plot so I'll just say this is a very good and entertaining film which shows what we could still achieve in space if we decided to devote the resources necessary.

Someone has called this a "love letter to science" - and I'd agree. Many books and films of this sort lose themselves in attempting existential contemplation of the vastness of the universe when compared to puny human concerns, while others fall back on luck and pluck. THE MARTIAN goes an entirely different route. The protagonist uses specific and very human skills and scientific knowledge to make the best he can of a seemingly impossible situation. He's backed up by a sizable contingent of other smart and dedicated people who think that space exploration is important but who retain their sense of proportion. Somewhat surprisingly, there's a fair amount of situational humor. In the film, Matt Damon proves once again that he's the go-to actor of his generation when the ability to combine intelligence with action is needed.

Star Wars is more believable.  And, while this movie is funny in spots, this is not a comedy... not even a dramedy... it is a straight up sci fi drama. Great computer generated effects! "The Martian" is a movie to watch if you like predictions of what the future of Space exploration and interplanetary exploration on mars will possibly look like and what Astronauts be challenged with.

As for the plot, "The Martian" appears like a realistic, original, and very smart movie, but the audience knows the whole time someone was left left for dead, and more importantly completely left behind because of a accident in a sand storm. From the first introduction of the characters and plot, there is this lost crew member. Considering the highly technical space program presented, it seems somewhat superficial someone just gets left for dead within minutes of the crew also leaving Mars to return to planet Earth.

That accident greatly clouded how smart the crew and NASA appear in the movie from the audiences point of view. As a result it is possible NASA and the crew never really appear that smart again. The result of just simply leaving their own dead crew member, even though they create an elaborate solution to communicate with the survivor, and a very elaborate space search and rescue, does not really seem forgiveable in the real world or even in fictional movie.

But, the left for dead scenario can add to the survivor's story, and if anyone likes survivor genre movies this is exactly that. Being a survivor creates that needed challenge for the hero to overcome communication problems, and overcome the lack of supplies. So as being a survivor seems like a staged hardship for the plot to develop seeming fake, it also presents the questons of how would someone communicate and replentish their supplies.

NASA and the crew do finally rescue their stranded crew member, but literally years later. The survivor is reduced physically and mentally to the reality of the environment on Mars, but he does survive.

Overall, it is rated 5 stars. It is a good movie for its entertainment, while showing the more basic issues of surviving on another planet. The complications on Mars are presented to be nothing like survival on Earth. People on Earth can call on a phone for a ride to  be picked up almost anywhere in the world, or use another form to signal for help if a phone is not available. Hopefully, someone will respond a lot faster to a call for help on Earth than years later in needing help on Mars.

But, Earth has its weather disasters and man made disasters as well, and when neglected have been causing long lasting delays in basic humanitarian relief. Sadly, disasters on Earth still have not been managed as well as they could. Please consider the downed communication lines, which have been furthering continuos preventable damage from becomming under control in advance. That is also possibly a reason for including the Mars sand storm in "The Martian", as a possible example of an unpredictable challenge for future Astronauts on an interplanatary exploration. Interplanetary weather forecasting is the next great science experiment along with the privatized race into Space.

Finally, its a great movie bringing up many discussions about interplanetary space exploration, and the issue of the need for search and rescues in Space. Search and rescue is something to know about whether in Space on Mars, or while aimlessly assumed dead on Mars,  and lost somewhere on Earth.

"The Martian" also has some interesting action sequences which unbelievably does not have a single crash. Very interesting and hopeful outlook regarding overcoming challenges in Space and on Mars!

The Martian is the story of a man rescued after he was accidentally stranded on Mars by his teammates.  It is a great story.  The astronaut, Mark Watney, goes through a lot of difficult times in trying to survive and he does it with a great sense of humor.  What else can he do?  I really, really, really enjoyed the Audible.com version of the story over the movie version, and R.C. Bray who read all the parts, did a fantastic job, carrying all the parts with just the right amount of humor, sarcasm and disbelief in his voice characterizations. His name is Mark Watney, and hes an astronaut on a mars mission.  When a freak storm comes up out of the blue, his team needs to evacuate, right away.  A freak accident causes him to be blown away and his suit is reported as breached.  Admitting to the worse, his crew makes the difficult decision to leave his body behind  he is beyond saving in the low pressure and freezing temperature of Mars.

But he has against all odds survived.  The puncture in his suit was sealed, by his explanation, by the coagulation of his own blood from the wound he sustained when he was impaled by something sharp.  He awakens on a cold, red planet to find his only means home, gone.  His crew, gone.  No access to NASA, Earth, or anyone at all that might be able to save him.

Because of the storm, the 30 day mission he and the other 5 members of his crew were a part of was terminated early.  This gives him some supplies  5 peoples worth for the rest of the month, and the habitation unit which was never taken down.  But  the next mission to mars isn't schedule for another four earth years.  There is no way his meager supplies can last that long.

Determined to not lose this fight, Mark employs his extensive knowledge of botany, a surprise stash of potatoes sent up vacuum packed for the crews Thanksgiving feast, and out of the box thinking to solve immediate and long term problems with his survival.  Against all odds, he continues, day after day, to make Mars work for him.

I think it will be hard to continue without giving away more of the movie plot, and I so hate spoliers.  If you are a fan of science fiction, suspense, drama, Matt Damon  you will not regret watching this movie.  It was intense at times, light hearted at other times, and gives you a warm feeling of what human beings are capable of when it comes to survival.  I practically cheered at the end and I cant wait to watch it again with my husband.

Also, this movie has spawned a ton of delightfully funny memes about how much America has spent retrieving Matt Damon in all his movies  from Saving Private Ryan, to Interstellar, to The Martian.  The estimate from one fellow with a bit too much time on his hands, was $900B, across all movies he was saved in (some of which I haven't seen  I know what Ill be doing this weekend!).  Its actually quite funny when you think about it.  I never thought of Matt Damon as type-cast, but maybe he has been, if all we are doing is rescuing him?

That is the only part of the movie that sucked, and a few f-bombs here and there.  Besides that it was a great movie that has my kids and I really hoping we can send a man to Mars.

I saw Gravity for the first time in the week before I saw The Martian. As disasters in space go, Gravity is a sprint whereas The Martian is a marathon. I prefer the sprint. I could feel that the Sandra Bullock character was always in physical danger and psychological turmoil; the music underscored these feelings. In The Martian the Matt Damon character experienced little psychological turmoil and only marginal physical danger; the music undermined the seriousness of the situation. Sandra Bullock's performance makes Matt Damon look like a high school actor. The Martian has been nominated for a Golden Globe in the Comedy or Musical Film category. That seems appropriate.

As a real Ridley Scott fan, I hate to say this, but the director has lost his spark and talent in recent years. In other words, do you remember "A Ridley Scott movie". You can't feel this anymore which is sad for fans like me. The Martian is another disappointment, so if you don't know about the fact that this film was shot by Scott before watching the film, you cannot understand until the end credits. As for the problem of the movie, the movie is not "Cast Away on space". I wish it was, but it is not. Why? Because there is no suspense, no mystery and no horror. The film ignores the psychological nature of the character and he doesn't face with any real challenge or trouble. Do you remember? When After Earth was released, it was mostly criticized for not being "too dangerous". http://www.rlsscene.com/category/movies/ The Martian is much worse. You cannot feel the danger, so does character! Because there is no real danger in the film. The main character behaves like John McClane at times, but he is not John McClane though. I mean a witty John McClane perfectly fits Die Hard franchise, but here it doesn't work. Most of the time, our man alone is "happy". And this "happy" mood defines the tone of the film. I would even prefer Red Planet over The Martian, because despite Red Planet was just a passable popcorn flick, it was mysterious, dark, suspenseful and interesting. The story in The Martian is not interesting, because it is not a survival type of a movie! I am a Matt Damon fan, I can watch him peeling potatoes and onion for hours, I am such a fan, but even he was dull here. The Martian is also a talky film, in fact too much talky, but the story needs more visuals than chatting, in other words more silence than words. 3D was just fine except for a few dazzling Mars images. The film reminded me the masterpiece Silent Running and I wish it would have been as great as that movie. The final chapter of the movie becomes lazy, dull and clich unfortunately and it cannot add something fresh to the story. And do I have to say the film lacks emotion and real entertainment which is weird. Additionally, some supporting characters were supposed to be funny, but actually they are not. I can prefer even Prometheus over The Martian honestly.

this book was a really good book I love how detailed the book was the way its written, there was no relaxation it was a problem left and right. in the book he explains what it takes to live an mars if you like science this is the book for you. its not about emotion or love its about pure survival in a place where survival is little to none.

Undoubtedly, I would agree, with the rest of film lovers, with the assessment of the quality of this film. Definitely worth watching and one of best films I've ever seen. Scott Ridley at his best as always. The production and screenplay, for the first that I know, makes the true science of Astrophysics Sexy! Not an easy thing to do. Of course there was some cheating (no such strong storms and gravity in Mars), but relatively minor fiction is a necessary evil for Hollywood.

I would disagree that casting was out of place. It was superb, no doubt. Jessica Chastian and Micheal Pena, where a delight working together as military pilots. This is what makes the film for me, and not the stereo-typed super space heroes (to wit: flash Gordon) we're accustomed to seeing. These are the real pilots you'd fine in the military, if you truly understood the book's attempt on realism. And of course, the true star was Damon. I agree he mirrored the book's character to a 'T'. I'd rate this a 5-star classic and a must see, over and over again.

Matt Damon is left for dead during the rushed evacuation of a small-scale Martian expedition. It's like Apollo 13 on steroids, mixed with short dashes of 127 Hours, MacGyver and Survivorman. Much less of a one-man show than I was expecting, which gives the film a little more spirit but also a more conventional structure. I think it would've been a far more interesting, daring picture if we'd seen more personal video journals from space and less debate around a round table at NASA, if just because we've seen the latter film several times already. Damon is excellent, bringing a blend of hopeless desperation and punchy good humor that gives him credence as both a technical expert and a likable, relatable everyday guy. The supporting cast is scattered with some strange choices, though - Kristen Wiig in a dead-serious role and Sean Bean as a kind-hearted supervisor are particularly out of place - which left me enjoying the scenes with Damon alone in the red landscape much more than the rescue effort. Still, the epic moments far outweigh the sub-standard ones, there's a strong sense of humor beneath all the suspense, and the visuals are really pretty incredible. Bonus points for getting so much of the science right, too. I'm conditioned to expect a lot of flaws when I dig deeper into sci-fi like this, but apart from one notable exception (the weather on Mars), the experts looked at this one and said "Yeah, that could actually work." Cool stuff.

Totally overrated. Everyone raved about this film, but we found it to be more of the same from Hollywood. Astronauts acting like children, B-list actors chewing up scenery (everyone in the space program looks like a super-model!), distracting 70's disco soundtrack trope, and predictable emotional cliches.  All wrapped up in a thin veneer of pretend hollywood science.

The dialogue in this movie was atrocious. It was like listening to a frat brother the entire time. I feel like the makers elected to pander to pop culture rather than explain important, technically interesting details as to how challenges were solved. (For example, how the rover was outfitted for survival rather than just glossing over it with "the greatest minds" helping out from Earth.) Every opportunity for a snarky joke was taken, at the expense of credibility. How was a heater created from a radioactive core the team had buried upon arrival? Don't worry about it, Matt Damon's verbal assurance that he will "science the s*** out of it" should be more than enough of a technical explanation. Even the PR lady HAD to say "I hate all of you guys right now" in response to a nerdy Lord of the Rings reference as opposed to a response that would have made sense. A PR rep who is always blunt and mean behind the scenes...what a complex, interesting character.

I'm sorry but it's really hard to forgive the implausibility of some of the events in the film when the dialogue is so populated with gibberish meant to appeal to teens and twenty-somethings. On the whole, it is a watchable and engaging movie, but not a very good piece of SCIENCE fiction. The premise of the story is that there are very, very difficult technical challenges involved in surviving on the surface of a planet that cannot support human life so ignoring details with smoke and mirrors in unacceptable.

I'll leave the tech talk to others, but the author of the book on which the film is based set out to create a story that was more science and less fiction with results that are both intellectually interesting and entertaining.  Both Matt Damon and Jessica Chastain had roles in the science fiction film Interstellar, which leaned more towards the conjectural science fiction of worm holes and the multiverse. Martian is much more like the film Gravity which exists in a realistic near future, and deals with the known laws of the universe, and this makes it much more compelling.
As an aside, it was funny to see actor Sean Beam sitting in a room while the other cast members talk about the Council of Elrond from the Lord of the Rings - Beam played the part of Boromir in the LOTR and was present at the Council in the film.  How many takes did they have to shoot before he got through this scene without laughing?

Fortunately, my husband agreed to watch the film The Martian as a favor to me. The Martian stars Matt Damon as an astronaut named Mark Watney who is fighting to stay alive after the rest of the crew reluctantly and mistakenly leave him for dead.  There is an all-star cast of some very multiple well-known celebrities in this film (also easily found via an online search) and a great plot of how the other crew members end up working together for key missions (including plot and character development as Damons Watney  character figures out ways to strive to stay alive).  There is also a good music soundtrack to go with The Martian, with some of the songs playing during the course of the film.
Great story, incredibly well told.  Science Fiction at its best!

I came into this movie pretty blind. Lately I avoid movie trailers until *after* I see a movie, if I can help it (the art of mystery and intrigue is lost on most trailer editors these days). I didn't know who directed 'The Martian', I didn't know who was in it, other than Matt Damon, I didn't know what it was about. All I knew is that people said it was good.

 THE STORY 
To say 'The Martian' was just "good", is an understatement. It has elements of action, servings of science (points to you if you know your botany and physics), tough decisions, suspense, a healthy dose of humor, topped with a thrilling conclusion. It's darn good story-telling. Read other reviews if you would like a recap of the plot, but there are certain movies where the less you know the better it is, so for this movie, it's a must-watch, that's all you need to know.

There are a few memorable lines and potential catchphrases (as a Botanist, I laughed out loud at the botany zingers), but telling you would spoil the fun. One thing you might take with you after the film is over is this quote: "If you solve enough problems, you get to come home." Another way one could interpret that is: If you can figure out and solve problems in life, for yourself or other people, you'll end up getting what you want. Knowledge is power, so learn as much as you can about anything and everything you're interested in; you never know when it'll pay off.

 3D 
This film was shot natively in 3D. Compositions were pre-planned from the start and you can tell because every shot makes great use of depth. You'll see depth in the beautiful Martian landscape, HUDs (Heads-Up Displays) are given visual life, and planetary storms will make you feel like you're in the middle of it.

This is one of the must-watch (3D) films of 2015, and a truly enjoyable movie experience. Highly recommended.

*** UPDATE ***
'The Martian' has now won two Golden Globes for:
 'Best Motion Picture - Musical or Comedy' (which is pushing it, for the category).
 'Best Performance by an Actor in a Motion Picture - Musical or Comedy' for Matt Damon.

It has also been nominated for multiple Academy Awards, including Best Picture. I wouldn't be surprised if it won, making it the first ever science fiction film to win Best Picture.

I give bonus points for the times the movie explained it's logic.  Often it is just left up to the audience to accept the tech speak and move on.  In fact two times during this movie I went to google to figure out what the hell they were going on about only to have the movie explain the methods as I was typing.  The best part was it didn't feel contrived, it was well written into the plot so it didn't feel like he was just looking at the audience and saying "Hey you, this is what I am doing".

The only other part of the movie I didn't much care for was the way they handled telling the crew their guy was left behind.  They SHOULD of went with the, "If we tell them, they will lose focus and may screw up the return to Earth."  Because hey, you just left your friend/coworker behind and he is still alive and slowly starving to death is soooooooooooo much better than letting them think he is dead.  At least until they had a solid functioning rescue plan in hand to save him.

Outside of that how was it?

I actually gave a damn about the story, the cast were phenomenal, everyone felt like believable in their roles and no one felt out of place.  Even more impressively, Sean Bean SURVIVED!!!!!  I won't spoil it for anyone who hasn't seen it but it is a great movie to own.

My husband and I watched this movie together on Christmas day as a splurge gift to each other.  We loved it from the very first moment to the very last moment.  Matt Damon was phenomenal in his role.  I've heard the movie compared to Tom Hanks's "Cast Away," but I would disagree because there is so much interaction between NASA and crew members and so many cuts to people in the U.S. and China trying to solve the Mars dilemma.  I don't think it was nearly as drawn-out as "Cast Away."  Both my husband and I appreciated Matt Damon's excellent comedic timing; he has some very funny lines to break the tension.  In addition, we enjoyed seeing China portrayed as our friend for a change.  Our daughter is adopted from China, and we often find that American movies portray China as the enemy.  The Martian was a nice departure in that area too.  If I could give this movie ten stars, I would.

This is a fabulous movie about one man's struggle to survive, against seemingly insurmountable odds.  Without committing any spoilers, astronaut Mark Watney is left behind and believed dead on Mars when America's Mars expedition is forced to make an emergency take-off from Mars for return to Earth.  But Watney is alive, and finds within himself the determination, ingenuity, and training necessary for survival.  This all makes for an incredibly uplifting and magnificent story.

Matt Damon is perfect as Mark Watney and the supporting cast is uniformly excellent.  This is a fine film.  It is rare that I find a film that leaves me with nothing to criticize, but this is one.  The storyline is gripping, the acting is first-rate, the direction and cinematography are all superb.  (No small feat for a story supposedly mostly filmed on another planet.)

No one should miss this wonderful film.  RJB.

Let me warn you in advance. This isn't Star Trek. It also isn't Star Wars. The book or this movie is not thrown together to cater to those with low attention spans. No advanced aliens come to save the day or to lay a larva in anyone's chest. There isn't any Mary Sue characters who seem to be perfect at everything they do. Nor are any problems solved easily or without trouble.

There also isn't extra filler here or added drama to appease people interested in anything else. I really admire the book and film for these efforts. Not to mention there are some really awesome Easter eggs. I wasn't expecting them due to my focus on the survival situation. That made them even more amazing and this movie has a great humor sprinkled within.

This is survival Science Fiction at it's best. It showcases the spirit of human beings at their best, against the odds, and how solving enough problems shows you can get past anything. To sum up The Martian as quickly as possible, I would call it Survivor Man meets Apollo 13. What makes this film so special is Apollo 13 was real and although this movie is pure fiction it feels real, because of the hard research the author did in regards to NASA.

Nobody looking for a movie with regards to what I wrote above could ever be disappointed with this movie overall. At least in my mind it offers everything you could ever want in this genre. You don't have to be a lover of science fiction to enjoy this movie about the true strength of the human spirit and mind.

Pros
The Acting. Damon was great but the support cast was also amazing. This could have very easily been the Matt Damon show with below average support actors to save money. Doesn't happen here.
Dialog
Characters
Authentic atmosphere
Pacing
Easter Eggs
Sense of Humor

Cons
Soundtrack. While I enjoyed the humor behind what music he was left with to listen too. The dramatic elements from the instrumental aspect of the more dramatic scenes and movie lacked. I felt more could have been added here and it could have been better. A small stupid thing I know but I had to find some fault with this gem.

Grade A+

Martian is a great film and probably one of the best films that you will see in 2015. It is great to see Ridley Scott back in action and Matt Damon in a funny role about an astronaut stranded on Mars after a freak storm. This is a film that is similar to Gravity but without the dramatic emotions, Martian is light and very funny film about science fiction but is not too complex and the ending is amazing. Matt Damon is great and so is the supporting cast - Chiwetel Ejiofor, Jessica Chastain, Jeff Daniels, Sean Bean, Michael Pea, Donald Glover . I watched this film in 3d but it would be fine to see it in the regular format.

I enjoyed this film and recommend it. The reason I gave it only four stars is because, I believe, it's not quite on the level of all time great sci-fi films that most everyone would give 5 stars. Films like 2001, Star Wars episodes 4,5, 6, Interstellar and Ridley Scott's own Bladerunner and Alien are generally considered to be 5 star films. Having said that The Martian does not disappoint. It's stays engaging from start to finish. The near future plot revolves around Astronaut Mark Watney's (Matt Damon's) attempt to survive long enough to be rescued after being inadvertently left behind by a NASA crew that thought he was dead. And we see NASA scientists back on Earth pull out all the stops to get him back home. The movie is scientifically and technically accurate in a lot of ways. The special effects, the images of the Martian landscape are striking (at least in the IMAX format I saw). The movie has it's humorous moments and presents NASA at it's best, working for the general good of mankind. In this film the Mars mission's are seen as a natural and universally supported next step for human beings. In one way I would compare it with the film "Battleship." I took my Mother to see that upbeat 2012 film. The movie placed the United States Navy in a such a positive light that my 82 year old Mom commented half seriously that she wanted to enlist. Similarly The Martian entertains and excites the viewer with the possibility of what NASA could become if given the political and public support it deserves.
Very much enjoyed the movie (and the book).  For once, it's not the mindless drivel or over-wrought "tug on the heartstrings" BS that Hollywood usually pumps out.

The movie was good overall. But the one problem I had with it, was that it was unrealistic. Putting all the scientific inaccuracies aside, there is no way that people on Earth would be so supportive and happy about the government spending trillions of dollars trying to get back one person. It would just never happen. There would be extreme outrage. People would be very upset. There would be riots in the streets, and protests outside of every government building. And that would just be in America alone. There is no way that that every other country, especially China, would give a darn one bit. We would get zero help from China, and people would definitely not be celebrating all over the world that the US government spent trillions to save one single person.
